Policy text:
**TitanCorp Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Family and Medical Leave (California Employees Only)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

This section outlines TitanCorp’s policy regarding family and medical leave for employees working within the State of California. It's important to understand the interplay between federal and state laws, especially FMLA (Federal Family and Medical Leave Act) and California PFL (Paid Family Leave). Because TitanCorp recognizes the value of our team members and strives to comply with all relevant laws, we offer leave options based on eligibility.

Federal FMLA generally provides up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave in a 12-month period for qualifying reasons, such as the birth or adoption of a child or to care for a seriously ill family member. More details on FMLA eligibility can be found in Section 3.4(a). However, California PFL offers a benefit unique to California: partial wage replacement while you take time off. Specifically, if an employee's request for bonding leave is approved, or leave to care for a seriously ill family member, and they contribute to California State Disability Insurance (SDI), then they may be eligible for up to eight (8) weeks of paid family leave, receiving approximately 60-70% of their usual wages as determined by California's Employment Development Department (EDD). It is important to note that SDI contributions are mandatory for most California employees. Therefore, any leave type falling under CA PFL that is not already covered by company-provided benefits, such as short-term disability (STD), will not be covered, even if the request might otherwise have been approved. For clarity, Section 3.4(c) further details the conditions pertaining to company-provided STD. Employees are encouraged to contact HR with any questions regarding FMLA, PFL, or company STD options.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.14: Workforce Adjustments and Reduction in Force (RIF)**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

Acme Corp is committed to treating all employees with respect and dignity during any workforce adjustment. This section outlines the procedures regarding reductions in force, mass layoffs, plant closures, and relocations. Please refer to Section 1.0 for definitions of key terms.

**3.14.1 WARN Act Notification**

Acme Corp will comply with the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act (both federal and California state laws) when implementing a qualifying plant closing or mass layoff. To the extent that federal and California WARN Acts conflict, the company will adhere to the standard most beneficial to impacted employees. This can be complex, so if a triggering event is anticipated, HR will immediately consult with Legal to confirm compliance.

Generally, if Acme Corp has at least 100 employees company-wide, a federal WARN notice is required if there is a plant closing affecting 50 or more employees at a single site of employment or a mass layoff affecting at least 50 employees comprising at least 33% of the workforce at a single site, or 500 employees at a single site, all within a 30-day period. However, in California, a mass layoff affecting 50 or more employees at a single worksite within a 30-day period triggers California's WARN Act if Acme Corp has 75 or more employees in total, irrespective of where the employees are located, including those on temporary layoff or leave. So, if Acme Corp has at least 75 employees but less than 100 employees across all of its locations, and a mass layoff of 50 or more employees is planned at a California worksite within a 30-day window, then California's WARN Act notice requirements are triggered.

**3.14.2 Notification Timeline**

As required by federal and California WARN Acts, Acme Corp will provide affected employees with written notice at least 60 calendar days prior to the date of the plant closing or mass layoff. Notice will also be provided to the California Employment Development Department (EDD), and any applicable local government.

**3.14.3 Exemptions**

[Further sections covering exemptions, voluntary separations, and benefit continuation omitted for brevity.]

Policy text:
**Acme Corp Employee Handbook - Section 3.12: Family and Medical Leave (California)**
*Revision Date: 2024-10-26*
*Effective Date: 2025-01-01*

This policy outlines Acme Corp's approach to family and medical leave for employees working in California. We aim to comply with both the federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) and the California Paid Family Leave (PFL) program, but interpretation and application can be complex.

**3.12.1 General Provisions**

Eligible employees working in California are generally entitled to take leave for qualifying family or medical reasons, subject to the conditions outlined below. Please note that eligibility for FMLA and PFL may differ. It is the employee's responsibility to understand the requirements of each.

**3.12.2 California Paid Family Leave (PFL) and Interplay with FMLA**

California employees who contribute to State Disability Insurance (SDI) are generally eligible for California Paid Family Leave (PFL). PFL provides partial wage replacement (currently 60-70% of your usual earnings) for up to eight (8) weeks to care for a seriously ill family member, or to bond with a new child. To be eligible for PFL while also remaining in active employment status, which allows for reinstatement to your position upon return from leave, your tenure at Acme Corp must be 12 months or less. In cases where an employee has been employed for more than twelve (12) months and contributes to SDI, that employee is ineligible to take PFL and retain active employment status. See Section 3.12.5 for information regarding FMLA leave. Please note that the Company may require medical certification to support a leave request under PFL. Section 3.14 covers return to work rights for employees following any period of leave.

**3.12.3 Notice Requirements**
Employees must provide at least 30 days' advance notice of the need for leave when the need is foreseeable. When the need for leave is unforeseeable, the employee must provide notice as soon as practicable. Failure to provide timely notice may result in delay or denial of leave.

**3.12.4 Coordination with Other Leave**
PFL may run concurrently with FMLA leave, where applicable.

**3.12.5 Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**
The Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) provides eligible employees up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave for certain family and medical reasons. See Section 3.13 for details of FMLA eligibility.

**3.12.6 Questions**

If you have questions about this policy, please contact Human Resources.

Policy text:
**Titan Industries Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 500: Leave Policies**
**Policy 500.3: Family and Medical Leave**
**Revision Date: 2024-07-01**

500.3.1. **Eligibility and Entitlement to Leave**.

Titan Industries provides unpaid family and medical leave to eligible employees pursuant to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993, 29 U.S.C. § 2601 et seq. ("FMLA"). To be eligible for FMLA leave, an employee must have been employed by Titan Industries for at least twelve (12) months, have worked at least 1,250 hours during the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding the commencement of leave, and be employed at a worksite where Titan Industries employs fifty (50) or more employees within seventy-five (75) miles. Subject to the conditions outlined below, eligible employees may take up to twelve (12) weeks of unpaid leave in a twelve (12) month period for the birth or adoption of a child, to care for a spouse, child, or parent with a serious health condition, or for the employee’s own serious health condition that renders the employee unable to perform the functions of their position.

500.3.2. **Termination of Employment During Leave**.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this policy, and to the fullest extent permitted by applicable law, any employee on FMLA leave who fails to return to work immediately following the expiration of their approved leave period, or who provides documentation or statements during the leave request process subsequently discovered to be deliberately false or misleading for the express purpose of fraudulently obtaining an otherwise unauthorized leave of absence, shall be considered to have voluntarily resigned their position with Titan Industries, effective the day following the date of leave expiration, irrespective of whether the employee has accrued vacation time or other paid time off that might otherwise have been available. It is the employee's responsibility to communicate any unavoidable delays or extenuating circumstances to their supervisor and HR in advance of the leave expiration date, with credible documentary evidence.

Policy text:
**Veridian Dynamics Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Compensation and Payroll**
**Policy 3.2.4: Final Paycheck (California Employees)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

This policy outlines the procedures for the issuance of final paychecks to employees of Veridian Dynamics working in the state of California. This policy is intended to comply with California Labor Code Sections 201-203. Please note that this policy applies *only* to employees whose primary work location is within California. Employees working outside of California are subject to the final paycheck laws of their respective states (see Policy 3.2.5: Final Paycheck (Non-California Employees)).

**Final Paycheck Timing**

Veridian Dynamics is committed to ensuring that all employees receive their final wages in a timely and compliant manner. For employees working in California, the timing of the final paycheck is dependent on the circumstances of their separation from employment.

*   **Involuntary Termination:** If an employee is involuntarily terminated from employment with Veridian Dynamics, all wages earned and unpaid at the time of termination are due and payable immediately at the time of discharge. The final paycheck will include wages for all hours worked, any accrued and unused vacation time (as per Policy 3.3.2: Vacation Accrual and Use), and any other compensation owed to the employee. This immediate payment requirement applies only to employees whose primary work location is in California. Should the employee's location_state not be California, then the employee is paid their final paycheck on the next regular payday.

*   **Voluntary Resignation:** The requirements for voluntary resignation are outlined further in Policy 3.1.6 (Resignation Procedures).

Employees are encouraged to contact the Human Resources Department with any questions or concerns regarding their final paycheck.

Policy text:
**Sterling Innovations, Inc. - HR Policy Manual**
**Section 5.2: Paid Family Leave and FMLA**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01, Revision 1.2**

This policy outlines Sterling Innovations’ approach to Family and Medical Leave, balancing both federal and California state regulations. We are committed to supporting our employees' needs to care for their families and manage personal health matters.

**5.2.1 Eligibility Overview**

Sterling Innovations complies with both the federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) and California Paid Family Leave (PFL). It's important to understand that FMLA provides *unpaid*, job-protected leave for up to 12 weeks in a 12-month period for qualifying reasons, such as the birth or adoption of a child, caring for a seriously ill family member (spouse, child, or parent), or the employee's own serious health condition. FMLA applies to employees who have worked for Sterling Innovations for at least 12 months, have worked at least 1,250 hours in the 12 months before the leave, and if Sterling Innovations has 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of your worksite.

California PFL, on the other hand, provides *partial wage replacement* (currently 60-70% of your usual wages) for up to 8 weeks for bonding with a new child or caring for a seriously ill family member (child, parent, spouse, grandparent, grandchild, sibling, or registered domestic partner). To be eligible for CA PFL, you must contribute to California State Disability Insurance (SDI). Employees who are not SDI contributors are not eligible for PFL benefits, even if they are eligible for FMLA. If you work in California, you likely contribute to SDI, but please confirm this on your paystub. You may take PFL to care for family members NOT residing in California, so long as you otherwise meet the eligibility requirements. Note that, depending on the timing and overlap between FMLA and PFL, FMLA runs concurrently with PFL where applicable. The laws are often paired together when leave is requested.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation**
**Revision Number:** 1.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01

**3.2.1 Overtime Eligibility:** This policy outlines the circumstances under which Acme Corp employees are eligible for overtime pay. It applies to all non-exempt employees working within the United States. Please note that this policy is governed by federal law, specifically the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). For clarification on employee classifications (exempt vs. non-exempt), please refer to Section 2.1 of this manual. This policy does *not* cover state-specific regulations.

**3.2.2 Overtime Rate:** Non-exempt employees who work more than 40 hours in a workweek will be paid overtime at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for each hour exceeding 40 hours. "Regular rate of pay" includes base hourly rate plus any nondiscretionary bonuses earned during the workweek.

**3.2.3 Overtime Authorization:** All overtime work must be pre-approved by the employee's manager. Working unauthorized overtime may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination. Employees are responsible for accurately recording their hours worked each day, including any overtime hours. Failure to accurately record hours worked may also result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination. Furthermore, repeatedly working unapproved overtime may be considered insubordination.

**3.2.4 Overtime Calculation:** Overtime is calculated on a weekly basis. Hours worked in excess of 40 in a workweek will be paid at the overtime rate, regardless of the number of hours worked on any given day.

Policy text:
**Synergy Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.0: Employment Termination**
**Policy 3.2: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**
**Revision 1.0**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**

Synergy Corp. is committed to complying with all applicable federal and state laws regarding workforce reductions. In the event of a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation that triggers the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act or the California WARN Act, the company will provide advance written notice to affected employees. This policy applies to all Synergy Corp. employees across all locations.

Generally, the federal WARN Act requires employers with 100 or more employees to provide 60 calendar days’ advance written notice before a plant closing or mass layoff affecting 50 or more employees at a single site of employment. California has a more stringent requirement; The California WARN Act (California Labor Code Sections 1400 et seq.) requires 60 calendar days’ advance written notice if a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation affects 50 or more employees within a 30-day period at a covered establishment. A covered establishment includes any industrial or commercial facility or part thereof that employs, or has employed within the preceding 12 months, 75 or more persons. Therefore, if Synergy Corp. has 75 or more employees company wide and is conducting a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation impacting 50 or more employees at a single site of employment in California, then 60 days advance notice is required, regardless of the total Synergy Corp employee count. If the affected employees are not located in California and Synergy Corp. has fewer than 100 employees company wide, then neither federal nor California WARN apply, and the 60-day notification is not required. Refer to Policy 1.2 for definitions of key terms.

Synergy Corp. will also adhere to any additional state or local requirements regarding workforce reductions, as applicable.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp – Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision Number: 1.0**

This policy outlines Acme Corp’s commitment to complying with the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act (29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq.). This policy applies to all Acme Corp employees across all locations within the United States. The purpose of the WARN Act is to provide employees and communities with sufficient advance notice of qualified plant closings and mass layoffs, providing time to prepare for potential job loss.

Acme Corp is required to provide at least 60 calendar days advance written notice of any plant closing or mass layoff that meets the following criteria:

*   **Mass Layoff Defined:** A "mass layoff" occurs when there is a reduction in force, not resulting from a plant closing, that results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for at least 50 employees and if those 50 employees represent at least 33% of the employees at the single site of employment, or 500 employees regardless of percentage.
*   **Plant Closing Defined:** A "plant closing" occurs when a permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, results in an employment loss during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees.
*   **Federal Threshold Applies:** If Acme Corp has fewer than 100 employees company-wide, the notification requirements of this policy do not apply.

Notice will be provided to affected employees or their representatives, the State Rapid Response Coordinator, and the chief elected official of the local government. The notice will contain the information required by the WARN Act. See Policy 3.13 for related information on employee separation benefits.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks (California Employees)**
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01
**Revision:** 2.0

This policy outlines Acme Corp.'s requirements for meal and rest breaks for employees working in California, in accordance with California Labor Law. Federal law has no bearing on these rules for adult employees. All California employees are entitled to meal and rest breaks as described below. This policy is intended to comply with California Labor Code Sections 226.7 and 512, as well as relevant Wage Orders.

**Meal Breaks:**

*   Employees working more than five (5) hours in a workday are entitled to an unpaid meal break of at least thirty (30) minutes. This meal break must begin before the end of the employee's fifth (5th) hour of work.
*   Employees working more than ten (10) hours in a workday are entitled to a second unpaid meal break of at least thirty (30) minutes. This second meal break must begin before the end of the employee's tenth (10th) hour of work.
*   Employees must be completely relieved of all duties during their meal breaks.
*   Employees may voluntarily waive their meal break, subject to certain conditions, as described in Section 3.4.1 of this policy. The employee and manager must sign a form to document this agreement.

**Rest Breaks:**

*   Employees are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks should be taken in the middle of each four-hour work period, as reasonably as possible.
*   Employees must be relieved of all duties during their rest breaks.

**Premium Pay for Missed Breaks:**

If Acme Corp. fails to provide an employee with a compliant meal or rest break, the employee shall be paid one (1) hour of premium pay for each workday that a meal or rest break is not provided. Premium pay shall be paid at the employee's regular rate of pay. If an employee's shift lasts for twelve hours or less and employee.shift_hours is less than or equal to 12, then premium pay will be provided for any shift where a break is missed.

**Recordkeeping:**

Acme Corp. will maintain accurate records of all meal and rest breaks taken by employees. Employees are responsible for accurately recording their break times in the company's timekeeping system. Any questions regarding meal or rest breaks should be directed to the HR department.

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics, Inc. – Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.7: Workforce Reductions and WARN Act Compliance**
**Policy Number:** HR-3.7-2024
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01
**Revision:** 1.0

**Purpose:** To establish guidelines for workforce reductions, ensuring compliance with the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act. This policy applies to all employees of Sterling Dynamics, Inc. across the United States.

Sterling Dynamics, Inc. is committed to treating its employees with respect and dignity. In the event that a workforce reduction becomes necessary, the company will strive to provide as much advance notice and support as possible, while ensuring compliance with applicable federal laws.

**3.7.1 WARN Act Notice Requirements:**

The federal WARN Act requires covered employers to provide 60 calendar days' advance written notice of a plant closing or mass layoff to affected employees. A "plant closing" is defined as the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding any part-time employees. A "mass layoff" is defined as a reduction in force which is not the result of a plant closing, but which results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 500 or more employees, or for 50-499 employees if they make up at least 33% of the employer's active workforce. In determining whether a WARN Act notice is required, if the number of employees affected by a mass layoff is less than 50, and the layoff type is not a relocation or plant closure, Sterling Dynamics is not required to provide affected employees with a 60-day notice. For additional information, please refer to the Department of Labor guidelines regarding WARN Act regulations.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**

**Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation (California Employees Only)**
*Revision 1.0, Effective Date: 2024-07-01*

Acme Corp is committed to complying with all applicable wage and hour laws. This section details the Company’s policy regarding overtime pay for non-exempt employees physically working within the State of California. Overtime compensation is provided to employees who work beyond the standard work day or work week, as defined by California law.

Non-exempt employees are eligible for overtime pay at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of eight (8) hours in any workday or for more than forty (40) hours in any workweek. Acme Corp will pay overtime wages in compliance with California Labor Code Sections 510, 511, and 515. In addition, employees who work more than twelve (12) hours in a workday will be compensated at a rate of two (2) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked beyond twelve (12) hours. Additionally, and with no exception, if a non-exempt employee works more than eight (8) hours on their seventh consecutive day in a workweek, they will be compensated at two (2) times their regular rate of pay for those hours worked over eight (8).

For clarity, the workweek is defined as Sunday at 12:00 AM through Saturday at 11:59 PM. Please also see Section 3.5, "Meal and Rest Breaks," for additional information on legally required breaks, which do not count as time worked for overtime purposes. Overtime must be pre-approved by the employee's supervisor; unauthorized overtime may be subject to disciplinary action as detailed in Section 9.2 "Employee Conduct." It is the employee's responsibility to accurately record all hours worked, including overtime hours, on their timesheet. Failure to do so may result in delay of payment, or disciplinary action. Salaried employees who are misclassified as exempt are also subject to this policy; please refer to the Legal Department for classification questions.

Policy text:
**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks**
*Effective Date: 2024-01-01*
*Revision: 2.0*

3.4.1 General Policy. It is the policy of Acme Corp. to provide meal and rest breaks to its employees in compliance with applicable federal and state laws. This policy is designed to ensure the health and well-being of our employees while maintaining operational efficiency. Acme Corp. complies with all applicable federal and state laws concerning meal and rest periods. This policy applies to all employees of Acme Corp.

3.4.2 California Employees. Notwithstanding the provisions outlined in Section 3.4.1, employees whose primary work location is in the State of California are subject to the following provisions, which are intended to comply with California Labor Code Sections 226.7 and 512.

3.4.2.1 Meal Breaks. Pursuant to California law, all non-exempt employees working shifts longer than five (5) hours shall be provided with a thirty (30) minute uninterrupted, duty-free meal break. If a non-exempt employee works a shift longer than ten (10) hours, they shall be provided a second thirty (30) minute uninterrupted, duty-free meal break. Employees shall not be required to remain on the premises during their meal break, unless the nature of the work prevents the employee from being relieved of all duty, and the employee and Acme Corp. agree to an on-duty meal period in writing.

3.4.2.2 Rest Breaks. Non-exempt employees working at least three and one-half (3.5) hours in a workday are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest period for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. To clarify, a "major fraction thereof" is defined as any work period exceeding two (2) hours.

3.4.2.3 Premium Pay. Should Acme Corp. fail to provide a required meal or rest break, or should an employee be required to work during a scheduled meal or rest break, the employee will be paid one (1) hour of premium pay at the employee’s regular rate of compensation for each workday that the meal or rest period is not provided, pursuant to California Labor Code Section 226.7.

3.4.3 Employees Outside of California. For all employees located outside of California, Acme Corp. will abide by all applicable federal and state laws regarding meal and rest periods. To the extent that federal law does not mandate meal or rest periods, Acme Corp. will comply with applicable state laws governing meal and rest breaks where legally obligated.

3.4.4 Enforcement. All supervisors and managers are responsible for ensuring that employees are provided with the meal and rest breaks required by this policy and applicable law. Any violations of this policy should be reported to the Human Resources Department immediately.

3.4.5 Policy Changes. Acme Corp. reserves the right to amend or modify this policy at any time, with or without notice.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.2: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision Number: 1.0**

This policy outlines Sterling Consolidated's approach to meal and rest breaks, ensuring compliance with applicable state and federal laws. It applies to all active employees of Sterling Consolidated and its subsidiaries, including those in California, but excluding those subject to collective bargaining agreements that address break times (see Section 1.4, Collective Bargaining).

**General Provisions:** Sterling Consolidated generally aims to comply with all applicable state and federal laws regarding meal and rest breaks. However, the specific rules governing break times vary depending on the employee’s location and employment classification. In cases where state and federal law differ, Sterling Consolidated will generally provide breaks in accordance with the stricter of the two, subject to exceptions as described below. Refer to Appendix A for a summary of applicable state break laws. Employees are responsible for accurately recording their break times in the timekeeping system.

**California-Specific Provisions:** For employees working in California, the following provisions apply: Non-exempt employees are entitled to a 30-minute unpaid meal break for every five (5) hours worked. A second 30-minute unpaid meal break is required if the employee works more than ten (10) hours in a workday. Employees are also entitled to a paid 10-minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked or major fraction thereof. If an employee is not provided a compliant meal or rest break as required under California law and the employee is terminated after working less than 12 months for the company, Sterling Consolidated may choose to not pay the employee any additional wages, subject to review by the HR department, as outlined in section 4.1 regarding involuntary termination procedures.

**Federal Law:** Federal law does not require meal or rest breaks for adult employees. However, if Sterling Consolidated provides breaks of short duration (generally, five (5) to twenty (20) minutes), these breaks must be paid. Meal breaks of thirty (30) minutes or longer are generally unpaid if the employee is completely relieved of all duties during the break period.

**Policy Interpretation:** This policy is intended to be a general guideline. The HR department is responsible for interpreting and applying this policy in specific situations. In the event of a conflict between this policy and applicable law, the applicable law will govern.

Policy text:
**SparkleClean Inc. - HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.7: Workforce Reductions and the California WARN Act**
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01
**Revision:** 1.0

SparkleClean Inc. is committed to complying with all applicable labor laws and regulations, including the California Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act. This policy outlines the company's procedures regarding workforce reductions that may trigger the requirements of the California WARN Act. This policy applies to all SparkleClean Inc. employees located in California.

The California WARN Act mandates that employers with 75 or more employees provide 60 calendar days' advance written notice to affected employees, the California Employment Development Department (EDD), and local government officials before any "mass layoff," "plant closure," or "relocation," as those terms are defined under the Act, affecting 50 or more employees within a 30-day period. A mass layoff excludes terminations for cause, voluntary departures, or retirements. A plant closure occurs when an employment site is shut down, and 50 or more employees suffer an employment loss within a 30-day period. A relocation is the removal of all or substantially all of the industrial or commercial operations of an employer to a different location 100 miles or more away.

Therefore, if SparkleClean Inc. has at least 75 employees in California and plans a mass layoff affecting 50 or more employees within a 30-day period due to economic reasons, the company must provide 60 days advance written notice to the affected employees, the EDD, and the relevant local government officials. Refer to Section 3.7.1 for specific notification requirements and contact the Legal Department for guidance in these situations. Failure to do so may result in significant penalties under California law.

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics Inc. - Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Leave Policies**
**Revision Date:** 2024-01-15
**Effective Date:** 2024-02-01

**3.2.3 Paid Family Leave (PFL) and Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

Sterling Dynamics Inc. recognizes the importance of employees being able to care for their families and themselves during times of need. This section outlines our policy regarding Paid Family Leave (PFL) in conjunction with the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA).

*   **California Paid Family Leave (PFL):** As a California-based company, Sterling Dynamics Inc. complies with the California PFL program, administered through the Employment Development Department (EDD). Employees who contribute to State Disability Insurance (SDI) are eligible to receive partial wage replacement benefits (currently 60-70% of wages) for up to eight (8) weeks within a 12-month period to bond with a new child (birth, adoption, or foster care placement) or to care for a seriously ill family member (child, parent, spouse, registered domestic partner, grandparent, grandchild, or sibling). More information can be found on the EDD website at [fictitious website]. See Section 3.2.5 for return-to-work requirements post-PFL.
*   **Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA):** FMLA provides eligible employees with up to twelve (12) weeks of *unpaid*, job-protected leave for certain family and medical reasons. These reasons include the birth and care of a newborn child, placement of a child for adoption or foster care, to care for a seriously ill family member (spouse, child, or parent), or for the employee's own serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the essential functions of his or her job. To be eligible for FMLA leave at Sterling Dynamics Inc., an employee must have been employed by the company for at least twelve (12) months and must have worked at least 1,250 hours during the twelve-month period immediately preceding the leave.

Importantly, any employee whose employment status is 'terminated', is not eligible to file or receive paid family leave.

*   **Coordination of Leave:** Employees are encouraged to utilize both PFL and FMLA concurrently where applicable. The company will coordinate these leaves to provide employees with the maximum benefits available. While FMLA provides job protection, PFL provides partial wage replacement, offering comprehensive support during eligible leave periods.

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Compensation & Benefits**
**Policy 3.2.4: Overtime Compensation (California Employees)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

This policy outlines Sterling Dynamics' procedures for compensating overtime hours worked by non-exempt employees in California. It is designed to comply with both California Labor Code and the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). This policy applies exclusively to employees whose primary work location is within the State of California. For questions regarding your exempt or non-exempt classification, please refer to Policy 3.1.2: Employee Classifications.

Sterling Dynamics generally expects employees to complete their assigned duties during their regularly scheduled work hours. However, situations may arise that necessitate overtime work. Non-exempt employees who are required or authorized to work overtime will be compensated as follows: Overtime compensation is calculated on a weekly basis, but with consideration given to daily work hours. In California, non-exempt employees are eligible for overtime pay at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours in a workweek. However, this is subject to the following provision: for non-exempt employees working in California, and only when employee.hours_worked_weekly is less than or equal to 40 hours, if employee.hours_worked_daily exceeds eight (8) hours on any workday during the workweek, then those hours exceeding eight (8) on that specific workday will be compensated at the overtime rate of 1.5 times the regular rate of pay. Please note that the calculation yielding the greatest overtime compensation will be applied. All overtime must be pre-approved by the employee's supervisor, as outlined in Section 3.2.4(a): Overtime Authorization. Failure to obtain pre-approval may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment.

Policy text:
**OptiCorp Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance (Revision 1.2)**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**

OptiCorp is committed to complying with all applicable federal and state laws regarding workforce reductions, including the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act. This policy outlines the procedures for providing notice in the event of a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation as defined under both federal and California law.

**Notification Requirements:**

In the event of a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation, OptiCorp will provide written notice to affected employees, employee representatives (if any), the State of California Employment Development Department (EDD), and the chief elected official of the local government.

Notice will be provided at least 60 calendar days prior to the date of separation unless an exception applies under the WARN Act. The determination of whether a 'mass layoff,' 'plant closure,' or 'relocation' has occurred will be assessed based on both the federal WARN Act (29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq.) and the California WARN Act (California Labor Code Sections 1400-1408). To ensure compliance across our operational footprint, we will adhere to the stricter of the two laws, meaning that for California based employees, if 50 or more employees at a single site of employment are to experience an employment loss within any 30-day period due to a mass layoff, closure, or relocation, OptiCorp will adhere to the 60-day notification requirement. However, for locations outside of California, the federal employee threshold of 100 employees applies before notification becomes necessary. It is also crucial that employees in locations that are not California, but where the total number of employees within a 75-mile radius is greater than or equal to 75, the company will proceed with the assumption that the California WARN Act provisions for layoff count also apply, as any separation from employment could affect an employee that has historically reported to a California location.
For any clarification of this policy, please contact the Human Resources Department.

Policy text:
**The TechForward Employee Handbook**

**Section 3: Compensation and Benefits**

**Policy 3.2: Overtime Compensation (California Employees Only)**

**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

This policy outlines TechForward’s overtime compensation practices for non-exempt employees working in California. Because TechForward values its employees and adheres to all applicable labor laws, this policy explains when and how employees will be compensated for overtime work. This policy specifically applies to employees whose primary work location is in the State of California. (See Policy 1.1: Geographic Scope of Policies).

**Overtime Pay**

In California, overtime is generally defined as any hours actually worked beyond eight (8) hours in a single workday or forty (40) hours in a single workweek, as described below. TechForward’s standard workweek runs from Monday at 12:00 AM to Sunday at 11:59 PM. The rate of pay for overtime work is one and one-half (1.5) times the employee's regular rate of pay. For employees whose primary location is in California and who are classified as non-exempt, if an employee works more than eight hours in a workday or more than forty hours in a workweek, the employee is entitled to overtime pay at one and one-half times their regular rate of pay. Employees who are classified as exempt are not eligible for overtime pay. Employees must accurately record their time worked each day, including all start and stop times, and submit their timesheets in accordance with Policy 3.3: Timekeeping. Failure to accurately record time worked may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination.

Please note that while federal law also requires overtime pay for hours worked over 40 in a week, California law is more protective of employee rights, and this policy is based on California law. If you have any questions about overtime pay, please contact the HR department.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Final Wage Payment**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision Number: 1.0**

3.12.1. It is the policy of Acme Corp. to ensure that all employees are paid their final wages in a timely manner, pursuant to all applicable federal laws and regulations, specifically the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). Notwithstanding any other provision within this policy manual, including but not limited to Section 2.05 regarding regular payroll schedules, final wage payments shall be issued in accordance with the following guidelines.

3.12.2. For any employee whose employment is involuntarily terminated by Acme Corp., their final paycheck, encompassing all earned and unpaid wages, including but not limited to accrued vacation time (subject to the limitations outlined in Section 5.07), shall be available for distribution no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following the date of termination.

3.12.3 Employees who voluntarily resign from their position with Acme Corp. are subject to the same payment schedule as employees who are involuntarily terminated. However, if an employee resigns and provides less than two weeks (14 days) written notice of their intention to resign, Acme Corp reserves the right to process their final paycheck on the subsequent regularly scheduled payday after the resignation takes effect, as long as it is within the permissible timelines under applicable federal regulations.

3.12.4. In the event of a plant closure or mass layoff (as defined by the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN)), final wage payments for affected employees will be issued no later than the next regularly scheduled payday. This is irrespective of employee classification or length of service. Acme Corp will make every effort to expedite the payment process in these circumstances, although adherence to federal law is paramount.

Policy text:
**Evergreen Solutions, Inc. - Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Paid Family Leave and FMLA Policy (Rev. 2.0)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**

Evergreen Solutions is committed to supporting our employees during significant life events. This section outlines our policy regarding Paid Family Leave (PFL) and the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA). Employees working in California, who contribute to State Disability Insurance (SDI), are eligible for California Paid Family Leave (PFL) benefits, which provides partial wage replacement (approximately 60-70%) for up to 8 weeks to bond with a new child or care for a seriously ill family member. PFL runs concurrently with any applicable FMLA leave. To be eligible for PFL, the employee.sdi_contributor must be true.

The federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) provides eligible employees with up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave for certain family and medical reasons. At Evergreen Solutions, to be eligible for FMLA, employees must have been employed for at least 12 months (employee.tenure_months >= 12) and must have worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12 months immediately preceding the leave (employee.hours_worked_12_months >= 1250), and Evergreen Solutions must employ 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of the employee's worksite (employer.employee_count_within_75_miles >= 50). FMLA covers leave for the birth and care of a newborn child, placement of a child for adoption or foster care, to care for a spouse, child, or parent with a serious health condition, or for the employee’s own serious health condition. Because FMLA is unpaid, employees who qualify for both FMLA and California PFL will receive wage replacement through PFL for up to 8 weeks, while the remaining portion of their 12-week FMLA leave will be unpaid. If an employee is not eligible for California PFL because they do not contribute to SDI (employee.sdi_contributor is false), they may still be eligible for up to 12 weeks of unpaid FMLA leave, provided they meet the other eligibility requirements. All leave requests must be submitted to Human Resources at least 30 days in advance when the need for leave is foreseeable.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation**
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01
**Revision Number:** 2.0

This section outlines Acme Corp.'s policy regarding overtime pay. It's important to understand that overtime regulations can be complex and vary depending on where you work. This policy is intended to comply with both federal law (Fair Labor Standards Act - FLSA) and applicable state laws, including those of California. Where state and federal laws differ, Acme Corp. will adhere to the law that is more beneficial to the employee.

Non-exempt employees (as defined in Section 2.1 of this handbook) are eligible for overtime pay. Generally, federal law requires overtime pay at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times your regular rate of pay for all hours worked over forty (40) in a workweek.

However, for employees working in California, the rules are somewhat different. In California, employees are entitled to overtime pay at one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked over eight (8) in a workday, or over forty (40) in a workweek. Furthermore, in California, if an employee works more than twelve (12) hours in a workday, they will be compensated at twice their regular rate of pay for all hours worked over twelve. This also applies to all hours worked over eight (8) on the seventh (7th) consecutive day in a workweek for those working in California.

It is the employee’s responsibility to accurately record all hours worked. Any discrepancies or questions about overtime pay should be immediately brought to the attention of your supervisor or the HR department. Note that pre-approval from your supervisor is required for all overtime hours. Failure to obtain pre-approval does not negate your right to overtime pay for hours actually worked, but may result in disciplinary action per Section 8.3. This policy does not create any contractual rights and may be modified at any time.

Policy text:
**Sterling Innovations HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.2: Final Paycheck Disbursement (California Employees Only)**
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01
**Revision:** 1.0

This policy outlines the procedures for distributing final paychecks to employees whose employment with Sterling Innovations ends. Please note that this section applies only to employees whose primary work location is in California.

Upon termination of employment, whether voluntary or involuntary, final paychecks will be issued in accordance with California Labor Code Sections 201-202, except as noted below. Generally, an employee who is involuntarily terminated will receive their final paycheck, including all accrued but unused vacation time (see Policy 5.1 for Vacation Accrual details), immediately upon termination. In instances where immediate payment is not feasible due to payroll processing constraints, the final paycheck will be available for pickup at the employee's usual work location no later than 72 hours after termination, excluding weekends and holidays. Employees will be notified of the exact time and location for paycheck pickup.

For employees who voluntarily resign, the timing of the final paycheck depends on the amount of notice provided. If an employee provides at least 72 hours advance notice of their resignation, they will receive their final paycheck on their last day of employment. However, if an employee resigns without providing at least 72 hours notice, the final paycheck will be available within 72 hours of their last day of employment. Despite the language above, the company may elect to pay a voluntarily terminated employee under the rules that apply to involuntary terminations at the discretion of the VP of Human Resources.

It is the employee's responsibility to ensure that Sterling Innovations has their current mailing address to facilitate timely delivery of the final paycheck if direct deposit is not elected. Failure to provide an accurate address may result in delays in receiving the final paycheck.

Policy text:
**Veridian Dynamics HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.7: Paid Family Leave and FMLA (California Employees)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 1.2**

This policy outlines Veridian Dynamics' approach to Paid Family Leave (PFL) and the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) for employees working in California. We are committed to supporting our employees through significant life events. Please note that this policy applies *only* to employees whose primary work location is in California.

**3.7.1 California Paid Family Leave (PFL) & FMLA Coordination**

California Paid Family Leave (PFL) and the federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) offer different types of leave for eligible employees. FMLA provides up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave for qualifying events, while PFL provides partial wage replacement (typically 60-70%) for up to 8 weeks for bonding with a new child or caring for a seriously ill family member. PFL is managed by the California Employment Development Department (EDD).

An employee who is actively employed, whose primary work location is California, and who does *not* pay into the California State Disability Insurance (SDI) program due to their employment classification being exempt, will not be eligible for California Paid Family Leave (PFL) benefits. This means that the employee will not receive partial wage replacement from the EDD during their leave period. To determine if you pay into SDI, please review your paystub. You may, however, still be eligible for up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) if all other FMLA eligibility requirements are met, as outlined in Section 3.7.2.

Employees are responsible for understanding the specific requirements and limitations of both PFL and FMLA. Contact the HR Department with any questions.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Compensation and Overtime**
**Revision Date:** 2024-01-01

Acme Corp. is committed to complying with all applicable wage and hour laws. This section outlines the policies regarding overtime compensation for our non-exempt employees. Understanding these policies is crucial for ensuring accurate pay and compliance.

For non-exempt employees working in states other than California, overtime will be paid at one and one-half (1.5) times their regular hourly rate for all hours worked over forty (40) in a workweek, pursuant to the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). However, for our California-based non-exempt employees who also contribute to California's State Disability Insurance (SDI) program, the rules are a little different. Overtime compensation will be provided for any time exceeding eight (8) hours in a single workday. Additionally, if a California-based non-exempt employee works more than forty (40) hours in a workweek, they will also receive overtime compensation for those excess hours, but only if those hours weren't already counted as daily overtime. If an employee works more than twelve (12) hours in a workday, they are entitled to double time pay for all hours exceeding twelve (12), as per California law, unless their employee.age is greater than 65, in which case standard overtime rules apply per FLSA guidelines. Furthermore, if a California-based non-exempt employee works more than eight (8) hours on their seventh consecutive day of work in a workweek, they shall be compensated at double their standard hourly rate for each such hour worked.

Please see Section 3.2.1 (Payroll Procedures) and 3.2.2 (Timekeeping) for related policies and procedures regarding the accurate recording of hours worked. Failure to accurately record time worked could result in disciplinary action. This policy is subject to change without notice.

Policy text:
**GLOBAL DYNAMICS CORP. – HUMAN RESOURCES POLICY MANUAL**

**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck Distribution (California Employees Only)**

**Effective Date: 2024-07-01, Revision 1.2**

3.  12.  1 General Policy

This section outlines Global Dynamics Corp.’s policy regarding the distribution of final paychecks to employees whose primary work location is in the State of California. Notwithstanding any conflicting provisions within this policy manual, the provisions of this Section 3.12 shall govern the timing of final wage payments for California-based employees.

3.  12.  2 Final Pay Distribution

Pursuant to California Labor Code Sections 201 and 202, and subject to the conditions outlined below, employees who are involuntarily terminated from Global Dynamics Corp. shall receive their final paycheck, including all earned and unpaid wages, commissions, and accrued vacation time, immediately upon separation. However, where immediate payment is not feasible due to circumstances beyond the control of Global Dynamics Corp., such as payroll processing limitations, the final paycheck shall be provided as soon as reasonably practicable, but in no case later than 72 hours following the termination.

Employees who voluntarily resign their employment must provide at least seventy-two (72) hours’ advance notice of their intended resignation. Employees who provide such notice shall receive their final paycheck on their last day of employment. Employees who voluntarily resign without providing at least seventy-two (72) hours’ advance notice shall receive their final paycheck within seventy-two (72) hours of their last day of employment. These requirements notwithstanding, salaried employees will have their final paycheck issued on the company's standard payroll date, provided that date is within 72 hours of their termination. This policy applies to California employees regardless of employment status, but is subservient to valid collective bargaining agreements. Global Dynamics Corp. reserves the right to pursue legal remedies for any damages incurred as a result of an employee's failure to provide adequate notice of resignation. In cases of dispute, the HR department will evaluate the facts and circumstances and make a final determination pursuant to company policy 8.1 which governs dispute resolution.

Policy text:
**Ardent Technologies, Inc. - Employee Handbook**
**Policy 3.4: Overtime Compensation (California Employees Only)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

**3.4.1 Overtime Eligibility and Calculation**

This section pertains exclusively to employees whose primary work location is within the State of California. In accordance with California Labor Code Sections 510 and 515, non-exempt employees are entitled to overtime compensation for hours worked beyond eight (8) hours in any workday or forty (40) hours in any workweek. For purposes of calculating overtime, the workweek is defined as Sunday at 12:00 AM to Saturday at 11:59 PM. All overtime must be pre-approved by the employee’s direct supervisor, or it may be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination, depending on the frequency of unapproved overtime hours worked.

**3.4.2 Overtime Rates**

Pursuant to California law, overtime compensation shall be paid at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times the employee’s regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of eight (8) hours in any workday, or in excess of forty (40) hours in any workweek, whichever calculation yields the greater overtime payment. Furthermore, employees shall be compensated at a rate of two (2) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of twelve (12) hours in any workday or for all hours worked in excess of eight (8) hours on the seventh (7th) consecutive day of work in a workweek. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if an employee's primary function at Ardent Technologies involves technical expertise related to network maintenance, and the employee is non-exempt and under the age of 25, their eligibility for the double-time rate is subject to review and may be denied if the number of hours worked over 12 are deemed unreasonable given the circumstances. This decision is at the sole discretion of the HR Manager, under Policy 2.11 (Disciplinary Action Procedures). In such cases, the employee will instead receive 1.5 times their regular rate of pay.

**3.4.3 Reporting Overtime Hours**
All overtime hours must be accurately recorded in the employee's timesheet and approved by their supervisor.

Policy text:
**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck Disbursement**

3.12.1. **General Policy.** AgileTech Solutions ("the Company") is committed to complying with all applicable federal and state wage and hour laws regarding the timely payment of final wages to employees whose employment with the Company has ended. This policy applies to all employees of the Company, irrespective of their employment status or location of employment, but is particularly relevant for employees located in jurisdictions with specific final pay requirements, such as California.

3.12.2. **Federal Requirements.** Notwithstanding any state law to the contrary, the Company will generally issue final paychecks to departing employees on the next regularly scheduled payday following the employee's termination date, as required by the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). The final paycheck will include all earned but unpaid wages, including salary, hourly wages, accrued vacation time (where applicable under state law and Section 4.01 of this Policy), and any other earned compensation.

3.12.3. **California Employees - Involuntary Termination.** Pursuant to California Labor Code Section 201, for employees whose primary work location is in California and whose employment is involuntarily terminated by the Company (e.g., through layoff or termination for cause), the final paycheck, including all wages and accrued vacation time, shall be made available to the employee immediately upon termination. If a physical paycheck is issued, it must be provided to the employee at the time of termination. If the employee elects to receive their final wages via direct deposit, the Company shall ensure the wages are available to the employee no later than the end of the business day on which the termination occurs. However, this immediate payment requirement shall not apply if the employee’s employment_status is active.

3.12.4. **California Employees - Voluntary Resignation.** The payment of final wages to California employees who voluntarily resign their employment is governed by California Labor Code Section 202 and is addressed in Section 3.13.

3.12.5. **Recordkeeping.** The Company shall maintain accurate and complete records of all final wage payments, including the date of termination, the method of payment, and the amount of wages paid.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Workforce Reductions and WARN Act Compliance**
**Revision Date: 2024-10-26**
**Effective Date: 2025-01-01**

This policy outlines Acme Corp’s requirements regarding workforce reductions that may trigger obligations under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, both federal and California-specific. Acme Corp values its employees and strives to provide as much advance notice as possible in the event of a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation. However, compliance can be complex, and this policy is intended only to provide guidance; consultation with Legal and HR is always required. This policy is applicable to all Acme Corp employees working within the state of California.

A "mass layoff" under California law is defined as a reduction in force affecting 50 or more employees within a 30-day period. It is Acme Corp's policy to provide at least 60 calendar days' written notice to affected employees before any mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation that results in termination of employment for 50 or more California-based employees at a single site of employment within a 30-day period, where Acme Corp employs 75 or more employees. For the avoidance of doubt, this applies even if the federal WARN Act (which has a 100-employee trigger) does not apply, as long as we meet the California threshold of 75 or more employees.

If a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation affects 50 or more employees in California, then at least 60 days’ notice is required. The 60-day notice requirement may be reduced under certain unforeseeable business circumstances, and any exceptions must be approved by the VP of HR and General Counsel. The determination of whether 60 days’ notice is required takes into account all terminations occurring within any 30-day period. See also Section 3.15 on Severance Pay. This policy is subject to change without notice.

Policy text:
**Golden Gate Technologies - Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.7: Compensation and Benefits**
**Policy 3.7.4: Final Paycheck Timing (California Employees)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

This policy outlines the timing of final paycheck distribution for employees of Golden Gate Technologies working in the state of California. Golden Gate Technologies is committed to complying with all applicable California labor laws regarding final pay.

The requirements for final paychecks differ depending on the circumstances of the termination of employment. In general, federal law (Fair Labor Standards Act) stipulates that final wages are due by the next regularly scheduled payday. California law, however, has stricter requirements in certain situations. Therefore, this policy applies to Golden Gate Technologies employees who work primarily in California. Employees working outside of California should refer to Policy 3.7.5 for final paycheck details applicable to their respective state of employment.

Specifically, if an employee working in California is involuntarily terminated (meaning Golden Gate Technologies ends the employment relationship), the employee's final paycheck, including all earned and unpaid wages, vacation time, and other accrued benefits, will be available to the employee *immediately* upon termination. This immediate payment requirement applies regardless of whether the employee is salaried or hourly and includes all wages earned up to and including the date of termination. We encourage terminated employees to contact Human Resources immediately if there is any discrepancy. For information on paid time off payout upon separation of employment, see policy 3.8.1. For definitions of terms used in this policy, see section 1.2.

Policy text:
**Veridian Dynamics Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.2: Compensation and Payroll**
**Policy 3.2.4: Final Paycheck Disbursement**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision Number: 2.0**

Veridian Dynamics is committed to complying with all applicable federal and state wage and hour laws. This policy outlines the procedures for the timely disbursement of final paychecks to employees whose employment with Veridian Dynamics has ended.

3.2.4.1 Final Paycheck Timing General Rule: Except as otherwise provided in Section 3.2.4.2 below and notwithstanding any provision to the contrary in any other Veridian Dynamics policy, and pursuant to the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), employees who are terminated or who resign from Veridian Dynamics, shall receive their final paycheck, including all earned wages, accrued but unused vacation time (if applicable and pursuant to Section 3.3.1 regarding vacation accrual), and any other compensation owed, no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following the date of termination or resignation.

3.2.4.2 California Exception: Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 3.2.4.1, for employees whose primary work location is in the State of California, and who are covered by California Labor Code Sections 201 and 202, the following shall apply. If an employee is involuntarily terminated from Veridian Dynamics, their final paycheck shall be made available to them immediately upon termination, or if they request, mailed to them. If an employee voluntarily resigns, and provides at least seventy-two (72) hours prior notice of their resignation, their final paycheck shall be made available to them on their last day of employment. In the event an employee voluntarily resigns without providing at least seventy-two (72) hours notice, their final paycheck shall be made available within seventy-two (72) hours of their last day of employment. For purposes of clarity, the seventy-two (72) hour period specified herein excludes weekends and holidays, unless the employee's regular work schedule includes weekend or holiday work, in which case the seventy-two (72) hour period shall be calculated to include such days. The provisions of this section shall take precedence over section 3.2.4.1 in the event of any inconsistency.

3.2.4.3 Compliance: It is the responsibility of the Human Resources Department and Payroll Department to ensure compliance with this policy and all applicable laws and regulations.

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics, Inc. - Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Workforce Adjustments and WARN Act Compliance**
**Revision Date: 2024-03-15**
**Effective Date: 2024-04-01**

This policy outlines Sterling Dynamics, Inc.'s (the "Company") procedures regarding workforce adjustments, including mass layoffs, plant closures, and relocations, to ensure compliance with both federal and California Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Acts. The Company recognizes its obligations to provide timely notice to affected employees, government agencies, and applicable labor organizations when such actions meet the thresholds defined by these laws.

**3.12.1 WARN Act Notification Requirements**

Generally, and subject to applicable exceptions detailed below, if the Company anticipates a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation as defined under the WARN Acts, it will provide written notice at least sixty (60) calendar days in advance of the event. For the purposes of this policy, a “mass layoff” means a reduction in force that results in an employment loss at a single site of employment during any 30-day period for (a) at least 50 employees, not counting any part-time employees, if the 50 employees represent at least 33% of the employees at the single site of employment; or (b) 500 or more employees, regardless of the percentage of the employees at the single site of employment. A "plant closure" means the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees.

However, for employees located in California, this notification requirement extends to mass layoffs affecting 50 or more employees if the company employs 75 or more individuals in California, regardless of the percentage threshold defined above. If, on the other hand, the affected employee count is more than 50, but our total employee count company-wide is less than 100, the federal WARN act does not apply. Under those circumstances, the California employee's entitlement will vary depending on the site location. Specific guidelines on site location requirements are outlined in Section 4.0, Subsection B.

The Company may reduce the notification period only under unforeseen business circumstances or natural disasters, as defined by the applicable WARN Act regulations.

Policy text:
**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck Distribution**

**3.12.1 General Policy:** Notwithstanding any provisions within the Employee Handbook to the contrary, including but not limited to Section 2.0 (Compensation and Benefits) and Section 4.5 (Termination Procedures), and subject to the limitations outlined in Section 3.12.2, Pinnacle Global Solutions shall adhere to the following procedure for the distribution of final paychecks to employees whose employment with the company has concluded.

**3.12.1.1 Distribution Timing:** Final paychecks, encompassing all earned and unpaid wages, including but not limited to regular wages, accrued vacation time (if applicable under the employee’s agreement), and any other earned compensation, will be issued to employees in accordance with federal law. Specifically, and without diminishing from the generality of the preceding clause, for any employee whose employment status is *terminated* (as defined in Section 4.5) and whose tenure with Pinnacle Global Solutions *exceeds* twelve (12) months, the final paycheck distribution will occur on the next regularly scheduled payday following the date of termination, provided the termination is not categorized as "voluntary resignation" wherein the employee gave at least 72 hours of notice. In such cases, the final paycheck will be provided in accordance with applicable law, potentially differing from the next regularly scheduled payday. The provisions of this section are applicable to all employees in the United States and take into consideration all federal wage and hour laws. The issuance of final payment will be made via the employee's selected method of pay, whether that is through direct deposit or physical check. The provisions of this section are subject to change at the sole discretion of Pinnacle Global Solutions.

**3.12.2 Exceptions:** The timing requirements outlined in Section 3.12.1.1 may be modified or superseded by legally binding agreements between Pinnacle Global Solutions and individual employees or collective bargaining agreements with recognized labor organizations.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook – Section 3.2: Meal and Rest Breaks**
Effective Date: 2024-07-01 Revision: 2.0

Acme Corp. is committed to providing employees with appropriate meal and rest breaks as required by law. This policy applies to all Acme Corp. employees. The provisions of this section are intended to comply with both California law for employees working in California and applicable federal law.

**3.2.1 Meal Breaks:** Non-exempt employees are generally entitled to a 30-minute unpaid meal break if they work more than five (5) hours in a workday. If an employee works more than ten (10) hours in a workday, a second 30-minute unpaid meal break is required. *However*, under certain documented circumstances approved by a supervisor, an employee may waive their second meal period provided that they do not work more than twelve (12) hours. The first meal period cannot be waived. As required by California law, Acme Corp. will pay one hour of pay at the employee’s regular rate of compensation for each workday that a meal period is not provided, and is not properly waived pursuant to the procedure outlined above. Refer to policy 3.2.3 for information about break tracking.

**3.2.2 Rest Breaks:** Non-exempt employees are entitled to a paid rest break of at least ten (10) minutes for every four (4) hours worked or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks should be taken in the middle of the work period, if practical. Please see Section 3.2.4 for rules concerning scheduling.

**3.2.3 Break Tracking:** It is the employee’s responsibility to accurately record all meal and rest breaks using the company’s timekeeping system. Failure to record breaks properly may impact compliance with applicable wage and hour laws. See policy 5.1 concerning Timekeeping Procedures.

**3.2.4 Break Scheduling:** Supervisors must make a good faith effort to schedule meal and rest breaks in accordance with this policy. Meal breaks should be scheduled no later than the end of the employee’s fifth hour of work, and the second meal break, where applicable, no later than the end of the employee's tenth hour of work, except as specified in section 3.2.1.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.2: Compensation and Payroll**
**Policy 3.2.4: Final Paycheck Distribution (California Employees)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision Number: 1.0**

This policy outlines the procedures for distributing final paychecks to employees of Sterling Consolidated working within the state of California. It is designed to ensure compliance with California Labor Code Sections 201-203. Please note that this policy applies exclusively to employees whose primary work location is within California. Employees working outside of California should refer to the HR policies specific to their state of employment.

The timing of your final paycheck depends on the circumstances of your separation from Sterling Consolidated. For employees who are involuntarily terminated (e.g., laid off or fired), Sterling Consolidated is required to provide your final paycheck, including all earned and unpaid wages, immediately upon termination. This means that the final paycheck will be made available to you on your last day of employment. "Earned wages" includes not only your regular hourly or salary rate, but also any accrued and unused vacation time. If you are unsure about the amount of accrued vacation you have, please consult with the HR department prior to your last day of employment.

If you voluntarily resign, the timing of your final paycheck will depend on whether you provide at least 72 hours’ advance notice of your resignation. If you provide at least 72 hours’ notice of your resignation, your final paycheck, including all earned wages and accrued vacation time, will be available to you on your last day of employment. If you do not provide at least 72 hours’ notice, your final paycheck will be available within 72 hours of your last day of employment. Sterling Consolidated will make reasonable efforts to contact you and arrange for you to pick up your final paycheck. If you are unable to pick up the paycheck in person, it will be mailed to your address of record. Employees are responsible for keeping their address current with HR.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated, Inc. - Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.0: Compensation and Overtime**
**Policy 3.2: Overtime Compensation for California Employees**
**Revision Date:** 2024-01-01

**3.2.1 General Overtime Policy**

This policy governs overtime compensation for all non-exempt employees of Sterling Consolidated, Inc. working within the State of California. It is the policy of Sterling Consolidated, Inc. to comply with all applicable state and federal laws regarding overtime compensation, including the California Labor Code Sections 510 and 515, as well as the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). This policy supersedes any prior policies or practices regarding overtime compensation.

**3.2.2 Overtime Eligibility**

Overtime compensation shall be provided to all non-exempt employees working in California pursuant to the following provisions. For any active non-exempt employee located in California, if employee.hours_worked_daily exceeds eight (8) hours in a single workday, the employee shall be compensated at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of eight (8) hours up to and including twelve (12) hours in that workday. Furthermore, if an active non-exempt employee located in California works more than twelve (12) hours in any single workday, they shall be compensated at a rate of two (2) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of twelve (12) hours in that workday. This policy applies to any employee with active employment_status, and working employee.location_state of 'CA', and classification of non_exempt. All overtime must be pre-approved by the employee’s supervisor or manager, pursuant to Policy 3.1 (Work Schedules and Timekeeping). Failure to obtain pre-approval may result in disciplinary action.

**3.2.3 Meal and Rest Breaks**

Compliance with meal and rest break requirements does not excuse or reduce the obligation to pay overtime compensation pursuant to this policy.

**3.2.4 Recordkeeping**

Accurate and complete timekeeping records are essential for compliance with this policy and applicable law. All employees are responsible for accurately recording their work time. Any falsification of time records may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section:** 3.4
**Policy Name:** Final Paycheck

**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01
**Revision:** 2.0

**3.4.1 Final Paycheck Timing (California Employees)**

This policy outlines the timing of final paycheck distribution for employees located and working in the State of California. Acme Corp is committed to complying with all applicable California Labor Laws, including Sections 201 and 202 of the California Labor Code, regarding final wage payments. This policy applies exclusively to employees whose primary work location is within California. Employees working outside of California are subject to different final pay regulations, as outlined in policy 3.4.2.

The timing of your final paycheck depends on the nature of your separation from Acme Corp.

*   **Involuntary Termination:** If your employment is involuntarily terminated by Acme Corp (e.g., layoff, termination for cause), your final paycheck, including all earned but unpaid wages, overtime, and accrued vacation time, will be available to you immediately upon termination. This is in accordance with California Labor Code Section 201.

*   **Voluntary Resignation with 72 Hours' Notice:** If you voluntarily resign your employment with Acme Corp and provide at least 72 hours' advance notice of your resignation date, your final paycheck will be available to you on your last day of employment. If you do not pick up the check, it will be mailed to your address of record.

*   **Voluntary Resignation without 72 Hours' Notice:** If you voluntarily resign your employment with Acme Corp and fail to provide at least 72 hours' advance notice of your resignation date, your final paycheck will be available to you within 72 hours of your last day of employment. This 72-hour period excludes weekends and holidays. The paycheck will be mailed to your address of record.

*   **Federal Law Considerations:** While federal law (Fair Labor Standards Act) generally requires payment by the next regular payday, Acme Corp adheres to the more stringent California regulations for all employees working in California. See policy 3.2.1 regarding federal regulations, which may apply in other jurisdictions.

Any questions regarding your final paycheck should be directed to the HR Department.
