Policy text:
**TitanCorp HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.2: Final Paycheck Disbursement**
**Revision: 1.0**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**

This policy outlines the procedures for the timely disbursement of final paychecks to employees of TitanCorp working in California. TitanCorp is committed to complying with all applicable wage and hour laws. However, to ensure consistency and administrative ease, the timing of final paycheck distribution may vary based on the circumstances of the employee’s separation from the company.

Generally, in accordance with California Labor Code Sections 201 and 202, an employee who is involuntarily terminated will receive their final paycheck, including all accrued but unused vacation time, immediately upon termination. This paycheck will be provided at the time of termination or mailed to the employee’s last known address if immediate in-person delivery is not feasible.

For employees who voluntarily resign, the timing depends on advance notice. If an employee provides at least 72 hours’ notice of their resignation, their final paycheck will be available on their last day of employment. However, if an employee quits without providing at least 72 hours’ advance notice, the final paycheck, inclusive of accrued vacation as detailed in Section 4.5 (Vacation Accrual and Use), will be made available no later than 72 hours following their last day of work.

Notwithstanding the above, and to facilitate timely processing, for all employees with less than six (6) months tenure who separate employment during the first week of a pay period, TitanCorp reserves the right to disburse final pay on the next regularly scheduled payday. This exception does not apply to instances of involuntary termination, and the employee will be notified of the reason for delayed disbursement. Additionally, the payroll department retains the right to make alternative arrangements for paycheck delivery, ensuring the payment of all wages due within the legally mandated timeframe. The Payroll Manager can approve exceptions in documented hardship cases on a case-by-case basis. Any questions regarding final paycheck disbursement should be directed to the HR department.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.4: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

Acme Corp is committed to complying with all applicable laws and regulations regarding workforce reductions. This policy outlines the company's approach to Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act compliance. Note that this policy is governed by federal law only.

**3.4.1 WARN Act Notification Requirements:**

In the event of a plant closing or mass layoff, Acme Corp will provide advance written notice to affected employees as required by the federal WARN Act (29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq.). A "plant closing" is defined as the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding any part-time employees. A "mass layoff" is defined as a reduction in force that is not the result of a plant closing, but which results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for at least 50 employees if those 50 employees make up at least 33% of the employer’s active workforce at that site, or at least 500 employees, regardless of the percentage of the workforce. For the purposes of this policy, an employee shall only be covered by the WARN Act protection if the employer has 100 or more employees. Advance notice of at least 60 calendar days will be provided before any plant closing or mass layoff that meets the above criteria. Acme Corp is not required to provide WARN Act notice if the total number of affected employees at a single site of employment is less than 50. This is consistent with our company's commitment to ethical and legally compliant business practices.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.7: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

Acme Corp. is committed to providing employees with legally compliant meal and rest breaks. This policy outlines the requirements for meal and rest breaks, adhering to both federal and state regulations. Federal law doesn't require meal or rest breaks for adult employees, but when provided and they are between 5 and 20 minutes, they must be paid.

For employees working in California, state law requires specific meal and rest breaks. Non-exempt employees in California who work more than five (5) hours in a workday are entitled to a thirty (30)-minute unpaid meal break. This meal break must start before the end of the employee’s fifth (5th) hour of work. If a non-exempt California employee works more than ten (10) hours in a workday, they are entitled to a second thirty (30)-minute unpaid meal break. Furthermore, non-exempt employees in California are entitled to a paid ten (10)-minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks should, to the extent possible, be taken in the middle of each four-hour work period.

Acme Corp. will pay one (1) hour of premium pay to any non-exempt California employee who is not provided a compliant meal or rest break as required by California law. It is the employee's responsibility to accurately record all meal and rest breaks taken on their timesheet. Please refer to Section 4.2: Timekeeping for additional information. Exempt employees are not subject to these meal and rest break requirements.

Policy text:
**SparkleClean Inc. – Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck (California Employees)**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

This section outlines SparkleClean's policy regarding the timing of final paychecks for employees working in California. This policy is designed to comply with California Labor Code Sections 201 and 202, which have stricter requirements than federal law.

**3.12.1 Timing of Final Paycheck**

The timing of your final paycheck depends on whether your termination was voluntary or involuntary. Please note that this policy ONLY applies to employees whose work location is in California, as indicated by their primary work address in our HR system.

**(a) Involuntary Termination:** If SparkleClean terminates your employment (e.g., layoff, termination for cause), your final paycheck, including all earned but unpaid wages, must be available to you immediately upon termination. This means your check will be ready for pickup at your usual worksite at the time of termination. If your final paycheck is not immediately available at the time of termination, you are required to notify HR immediately for assistance.

**(b) Voluntary Resignation with 72 Hours’ Notice:** If you resign from SparkleClean and provide at least 72 hours’ advance notice of your resignation date, your final paycheck will be available to you on your last day of employment. You must provide a formal resignation letter or email through the HR portal with at least 72 hours notice.

**(c) Voluntary Resignation without 72 Hours’ Notice:** If you resign from SparkleClean without providing at least 72 hours’ advance notice, your final paycheck will be available to you within 72 hours of your last day of employment. SparkleClean will make reasonable efforts to prepare the final paycheck as soon as possible, but the final date will be no later than 72 hours from the date of separation.

**(d) Exemption for Collective Bargaining Agreements:** In some cases, a collective bargaining agreement may supersede portions of this policy. Check with your union representative and HR for clarification.

SparkleClean is committed to complying with all applicable laws and regulations regarding final paychecks. Employees with questions or concerns about this policy should contact the Human Resources department.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 4.2: Leave Policies**
**Revision Date: 2024-10-26**
**Effective Date: 2025-01-01**

**4.2.3 Paid Family Leave (PFL) and Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

Acme Corp. is committed to supporting our employees' needs to balance work and family life. This section outlines our policies regarding Paid Family Leave (PFL) and the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA).

The Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) is a federal law that provides eligible employees with up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave for certain family and medical reasons. To be eligible for FMLA, employees must have worked for Acme Corp. for at least 12 months (which need not be consecutive) and for at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period immediately preceding the leave. Also, Acme Corp. must employ 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of the employee's worksite. Reasons for FMLA leave include the birth and care of a newborn child, placement of a child for adoption or foster care, to care for a spouse, child, or parent with a serious health condition, or for the employee’s own serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the functions of the employee’s job. See Section 4.2.7 for detailed FMLA eligibility guidelines.

California Paid Family Leave (PFL) provides partial wage replacement benefits to eligible employees who take time off work to care for a seriously ill family member (child, spouse, parent, grandparent, grandchild, sibling, or registered domestic partner) or to bond with a new child. To be eligible for California PFL, employees must contribute to California State Disability Insurance (SDI). California PFL runs concurrently with FMLA leave when the leave qualifies for both.

However, employees who work in California and do not contribute to SDI are not eligible for California Paid Family Leave (PFL), even if they meet all other FMLA requirements, and need to care for a qualifying family member. Employees should contact Human Resources to determine their eligibility for PFL and FMLA.

Policy text:
**Sunrise Technologies Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Workforce Reductions and WARN Act Compliance**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

Sunrise Technologies is committed to treating all employees with respect and fairness during workforce reductions. This policy outlines the company’s obligations under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, a federal law designed to protect workers, their families, and communities by requiring employers to provide notification of plant closings and mass layoffs.

**3.12.1 WARN Act Notification Requirement**

In compliance with the federal WARN Act, Sunrise Technologies will provide written notice at least 60 calendar days in advance of any plant closing or mass layoff that meets the following criteria:

*   **Plant Closing:** The permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding part-time employees.

*   **Mass Layoff:** A reduction in force which is not the result of a plant closing, but which results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 500 or more employees, or 50-499 employees if they make up at least 33% of the employer’s active workforce at that site.

For the purposes of this policy, an “employment loss” means a termination of employment, other than a discharge for cause, voluntary departure, or retirement; a layoff exceeding 6 months; or a reduction in hours of work of more than 50 percent during each month of any 6-month period.

If Sunrise Technologies employs 100 or more employees company-wide, and a layoff is anticipated affecting 500 or more employees, a WARN notice is required to be issued to affected employees, the State Rapid Response Team and local government officials. Employees are required to continue working their normal schedule until their employment termination date unless otherwise notified by their manager. This policy is in compliance with the Federal WARN Act (29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq.).

Policy text:
**ThePetStoreCo HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation (California Employees)**
**Revision:** 1.2
**Effective Date:** 2024-08-01

This section outlines ThePetStoreCo's policy regarding overtime compensation for employees located in California, in compliance with California Labor Law. This policy applies to all non-exempt employees who are employed in the state of California. For employees working in other states, please refer to Section 3.3, Overtime Compensation (Non-California Employees).

**Overtime Compensation:** Non-exempt California employees will be compensated for all hours worked over eight (8) in a single workday, or over forty (40) hours in a workweek, at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay. However, if an employee’s hours worked daily exceeds 12 hours in a single workday, that employee's pay rate will be doubled for each hour exceeding 12 hours. Furthermore, if a California employee works more than eight (8) hours on their seventh (7th) consecutive day in a workweek, they will also receive double their regular rate of pay for those hours exceeding eight (8) on that seventh day. For the avoidance of doubt, this policy will not be interpreted to provide for compensatory time off, which is not permitted under applicable California labor law for private sector employees. If you have any questions regarding your overtime eligibility or the calculation of your overtime pay, please contact the Payroll Department for clarification. Managers are responsible for accurately tracking employee time and ensuring that all overtime hours are properly recorded and paid. This policy is subject to change at any time with or without notice, consistent with applicable law.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated HR Policy Manual**

**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks (California Employees Only)**
**Revision Number:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01

This policy outlines Sterling Consolidated’s requirements for meal and rest breaks for employees working in California. These requirements are mandated by California state law, which provides greater protections than federal law in this area. This policy applies only to employees physically working in California. Employees working outside of California should refer to the employee handbook supplement applicable to their work location. This policy is intended to ensure compliance with California Labor Code Sections 226.7 and 512.

All non-exempt Sterling Consolidated employees in California are entitled to meal and rest breaks as follows:

*   **Meal Breaks:** Employees who work more than five (5) hours in a workday are entitled to a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. This meal break should ideally be scheduled near the middle of the shift. Employees working more than ten (10) hours in a workday are entitled to a second thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. It is the employee's responsibility to accurately record their break times. Sterling Consolidated will not permit employees to work through their meal periods.

*   **Rest Breaks:** Employees are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks should ideally be scheduled near the middle of each four-hour work period. To be clear, if an employee works at least 3.5 hours, then a 10 minute break is required. Rest breaks are considered "on-duty" breaks, meaning employees must remain available to perform their duties if needed.

Sterling Consolidated understands that from time to time employees may miss meal or rest breaks due to legitimate business needs. To ensure compliance with California law, it is Sterling Consolidated's policy that, in the event that a non-exempt employee working in California misses a required meal or rest break, they must immediately notify their supervisor. If employee.hours_worked_daily is greater than 5 hours and break.type is 'meal' and break.duration_minutes is less than 30 minutes, the employee must report the missed meal break to their supervisor within 24 hours so that any required premium pay can be promptly calculated and disbursed.

**Policy Updates:** This policy will be reviewed annually and updated as necessary to comply with applicable laws and regulations.

**Employee Responsibilities:** It is the employee's responsibility to understand and comply with this policy. Any questions regarding this policy should be directed to the HR Department.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.2 Final Paycheck**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision Number: 2.0**

3.  2.  1 General Policy: Upon termination of employment, whether voluntary or involuntary, Acme Corp shall provide a final paycheck to the departing employee. The timing of the final paycheck will depend on the employee's location of employment and the circumstances surrounding the termination, as further detailed below. In all circumstances, the final paycheck will include all earned but unpaid wages, including accrued vacation time where applicable pursuant to Section 4.1 of this policy.

4.  2.  2 California Employees: Notwithstanding Section 3.2.1, for employees whose primary work location is within the State of California, the following provisions shall apply pursuant to California Labor Code Sections 201 and 202. If an employee is involuntarily terminated, the final paycheck shall be provided to the employee immediately upon termination. If an employee resigns and provides at least 72 hours advance notice of their resignation, the final paycheck shall be provided to the employee on their last day of employment. If an employee resigns without providing at least 72 hours advance notice, the final paycheck shall be available for the employee within 72 hours of their resignation. Failure to collect the final paycheck within this timeframe does not relieve Acme Corp of its obligation to provide payment.

5.  2.  3 Employees Outside of California: For employees whose primary work location is outside of the State of California, the final paycheck shall be provided no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following the termination of employment, consistent with applicable federal law (Fair Labor Standards Act). However, if an employee is terminated and their last regular payday falls within 72 hours of the termination date, the provisions of Section 3.2.2 shall apply regardless of work location. It is the responsibility of the HR department to ascertain employee location and comply with all applicable laws.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook – Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation (California)**

**3.2.1. Effective Date:** January 1, 2024. **Revision:** 1.0

This policy outlines Acme Corp.'s overtime compensation practices for non-exempt employees working in California, in compliance with applicable California and federal law. Please note that this policy applies exclusively to employees physically working within the state of California.

**3.2.2. Overtime Eligibility and Calculation**

Non-exempt employees are eligible for overtime pay. For such employees, overtime compensation will be paid in accordance with California law. An employee will be paid one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked over eight (8) in a workday, or for the first eight hours worked on the seventh consecutive day of work in a workweek. Should an employee work more than twelve (12) hours in a single workday, they will be compensated at two (2) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked over twelve (12).

Further, non-exempt employees shall also be paid one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked over forty (40) in a workweek. Note that hours paid at the daily overtime rate (1.5x for hours exceeding 8 in a day) will count towards the 40 hour workweek threshold.

For purposes of calculating overtime, the workweek is defined as Sunday at 12:00 AM to Saturday at 11:59 PM. Any exceptions to this overtime policy, including those due to special project needs, require prior written approval from the employee’s direct supervisor and the HR department. Employees over the age of 18 are subject to all overtime rules unless otherwise exempted per federal and state law. If an employee's classification changes to exempt, overtime is no longer applicable starting with the effective date of the change. See section 2.1.4 regarding employee classifications.

Policy text:
**Sterling Financial Services - HR Policy Manual - Section 5.0 - Leave Policies**
**Policy 5.3: Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) Leave**
**Revision Date:** 2024-01-01
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01

5.3.1 Eligibility: Sterling Financial Services is committed to complying with the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 (FMLA), 29 U.S.C. § 2601 et seq. Eligible employees, as defined herein, may be granted up to twelve (12) weeks of unpaid leave during any twelve (12) month period for qualifying reasons.

5.3.2 Qualifying Reasons: FMLA leave may be granted for the following reasons: (a) the birth of a child and to bond with the newborn child within one year of birth; (b) the placement of a child with the employee for adoption or foster care and to bond with the newly placed child within one year of placement; (c) to care for the employee’s spouse, child, or parent who has a serious health condition; (d) a serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the essential functions of his or her job; (e) any qualifying exigency arising out of the fact that the employee’s spouse, son, daughter, or parent is a covered military member on active duty (or has been notified of an impending call or order to active duty) in the Armed Forces.

5.3.3 Eligibility Requirements: Notwithstanding Section 5.3.2, an employee is eligible for FMLA leave if he or she (a) has been employed by Sterling Financial Services for at least twelve (12) months, which need not be consecutive; and (b) has worked for Sterling Financial Services for at least 1,250 hours during the twelve-month period immediately preceding the commencement of the leave; and (c) works at a location where Sterling Financial Services employs fifty (50) or more employees within a 75-mile radius. Further, such eligibility is contingent upon the employee maintaining an active employment status and the leave being requested for a qualifying reason as outlined in Section 5.3.2. Employees who are terminated or have resigned their position prior to the commencement of leave, or while on leave, may have their leave request denied or terminated at the discretion of Sterling Financial Services.

5.3.4 Leave Duration: As stated in 5.3.1, eligible employees may be granted up to twelve (12) weeks of unpaid leave. However, the duration of leave may be reduced in certain situations at the discretion of management. The 12-month period is measured forward from the date any employee’s first FMLA leave begins.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.2: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01
**Revision:** 1.0

It is the policy of Sterling Consolidated to provide meal and rest breaks to employees in accordance with applicable state and federal laws. Because Sterling Consolidated operates in multiple states, the specific requirements may vary depending on the employee's work location. Employees are responsible for understanding and adhering to the break policies applicable to their work location.

For employees working in California, the following rules apply: If an employee works more than five (5) hours in a workday, they are entitled to a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. A second thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break is required if an employee works more than ten (10) hours in a workday. Employees are required to take their meal breaks no later than the end of their fifth (5th) hour of work, or sixth (6th) hour with a valid waiver, as described in Section 3.2.a.

In addition to meal breaks, employees working in California are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks should, to the extent feasible, be taken in the middle of each work period. If an employee does not receive their legally mandated meal or rest break, they are entitled to one (1) hour of pay at their regular rate for each missed break. Please note, these California-specific rules supersede any conflicting general guidance in Section 3.0 pertaining to employee breaks. For employees working outside of California, Sterling Consolidated will provide breaks in accordance with applicable federal and state law. Employees are expected to return to their work duties immediately upon the conclusion of any meal or rest period. See Section 6.4 for information on how to accurately record time, including meal and rest breaks, in the company timekeeping system.

Policy text:
**ACME Corp Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.4: Final Paycheck Disbursement (California Employees)**
**Revision Number:** 2.1
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01

3.4.1. **General Policy**: This policy section governs the disbursement of final paychecks to employees of ACME Corp whose primary work location is within the State of California. This policy is intended to comply with the provisions of California Labor Code Sections 201-203, *et seq.*, and related regulations. Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary, this policy shall be interpreted and applied in accordance with applicable California law. To the extent this policy is silent on any aspect of final paycheck disbursement, relevant provisions of the California Labor Code shall govern.

3.4.2. **Timing of Final Paycheck**: Except as otherwise specifically provided in this Section 3.4, and subject to the provisions of Section 1.2 regarding policy interpretation, final wages shall be paid in accordance with the following guidelines:

(a) Where an employee’s employment is involuntarily terminated by ACME Corp, provided the employee's work location is within the State of California and the employee is not classified as exempt, the employee’s final paycheck, inclusive of all earned but unpaid wages, accrued vacation time, and any other compensation legally due, shall be made available to the employee immediately upon termination. If the employee is classified as exempt, then the final wages, in accordance with the previous language, shall be paid no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following the termination, however, should the employee be terminated on the final day of the regular pay period, the final paycheck will still be available immediately. For purposes of this policy, "immediately" means within a reasonable time period, not to exceed two (2) hours from the time of termination during regular business hours. Should termination occur after regular business hours, ACME Corp will make every effort to process final payment within 2 hours, however, payment may not be available until the next business day, in which case it will be made available as soon as is reasonably possible.

Policy text:
**Skybound Dynamics, Inc. – Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.4: Overtime Compensation (California Employees)**

**3.4.1 General Policy**

This Section 3.4 outlines Skybound Dynamics, Inc.’s policy regarding overtime compensation for non-exempt employees whose primary work location is within the State of California. This policy is effective as of January 1, 2024, and supersedes any prior overtime policies. Skybound Dynamics, Inc. is committed to complying with all applicable California and federal laws concerning employee compensation.

**3.4.2 Overtime Eligibility and Rate**

Notwithstanding Section 3.4.1, and subject to the conditions set forth below, eligible employees shall be compensated for overtime hours at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours in a workweek, or for all hours worked in excess of eight (8) hours in any workday. However, if an employee works more than twelve (12) hours in a single workday, and provided that such employee's classification is non-exempt and their employee status is active, or works more than eight (8) hours on the seventh consecutive day worked in a workweek, such employee shall be compensated at a rate of two (2) times their regular rate of pay for all hours exceeding twelve (12) in a workday, or eight (8) hours on the seventh consecutive day. For purposes of clarity, the determination of whether an employee is entitled to overtime compensation shall be governed by the most beneficial interpretation for the employee under applicable California Labor Code provisions.

**3.4.3 Calculation and Payment**

Overtime compensation will be calculated based on the employee's regular rate of pay, which includes all non-discretionary bonuses and other forms of compensation as required by applicable law. Overtime pay will be included in the employee's regular paycheck for the pay period in which the overtime hours were worked, pursuant to California Labor Code Section 204.

**3.4.4 Policy Exceptions**

Nothing in this policy shall be construed as creating any contractual rights, and Skybound Dynamics, Inc. reserves the right to modify or terminate this policy at any time, with or without notice, subject to applicable law. Further, any exceptions to this policy must be pre-approved in writing by the Human Resources Department.

Policy text:
**The Daily Grind Corp. – Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Revision Number:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01

The Daily Grind Corp. is committed to providing employees with legally compliant meal and rest breaks. This policy outlines our practices and procedures for ensuring that employees receive the breaks to which they are entitled under applicable federal and state laws. This policy applies to all employees regardless of their employment status (full-time, part-time, or temporary).

**3.4.1 Meal Breaks**

Federal law does not require meal breaks for adult employees. However, Daily Grind Corp. provides meal breaks as outlined below and in accordance with California law for employees working in California.

**3.4.2 Rest Breaks**

Federal law requires that breaks lasting less than 20 minutes be paid.

**3.4.3 California-Specific Requirements:**

Employees who work in California are entitled to specific meal and rest breaks according to California law. If an employee works more than five (5) hours in a workday, they are entitled to a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. Employees must be relieved of all duties during the meal break. Unless otherwise agreed to in a collective bargaining agreement, if any employee works over ten (10) hours in a workday, they are entitled to a second thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. In California, employees are also entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked or major fraction thereof. If The Daily Grind Corp. fails to provide any meal or rest break required by California law, the affected employee will be paid one (1) hour of premium pay for each workday in which the meal or rest break was not provided. Employees are responsible for accurately recording their break times in the timekeeping system. Repeated failure to accurately record time may result in disciplinary action.

**3.4.4 Premium Pay**

Employees in California who do not receive their legally required meal or rest breaks due to company reasons are entitled to one hour of premium pay for each violation.

Policy text:
**GlobalCorp HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.4: Workforce Reductions and WARN Act Compliance**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01; Revision 2.0**

GlobalCorp is committed to complying with all applicable federal and state laws regarding workforce reductions. This policy outlines the procedures for mass layoffs, plant closures, and relocations affecting our employees, particularly in states with stricter regulations, such as California. It is important to note that compliance with this policy does not create any contractual rights for employees. This policy is subject to change without notice.

**3.4.1 WARN Act Notification Requirements**

In the event of a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation, GlobalCorp will adhere to the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, both at the federal and state levels. A "mass layoff" is defined as a reduction in force that is not the result of a plant closing and results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for either: (1) at least 50 employees if the employees represent at least 33 percent of the employees at the single site of employment; or (2) 500 or more employees. A "plant closure" means the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees excluding any part-time employees.

For locations in California, because the California WARN Act may have lower thresholds, GlobalCorp will provide written notice to affected employees and the California Employment Development Department (EDD) at least 60 days in advance if a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation affects 50 or more employees, and GlobalCorp’s total employment is 75 or more employees at the location or worksite. All other US locations will follow the federal WARN Act where 100 or more employees triggers the 60 day notice period. While GlobalCorp strives to provide as much notice as possible, this is ultimately contingent upon business needs and operational constraints, and it should be noted that in all instances, whether or not the company opts to offer severance, such severance does not supplant or constitute meeting the requirements of 60-day notice period. This notice requirement applies only to involuntary terminations due to a qualifying event. For more information regarding severance, refer to section 3.5 of this policy.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated, Inc. – Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 4.0: Leave Policies**
**Policy 4.3: Paid Family Leave (PFL) and Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) Integration**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01, Revision 1.0**

4.  3.1. **Eligibility for California Paid Family Leave (PFL) Benefits**: Pursuant to California Unemployment Insurance Code Sections 3300 et seq., employees whose primary work location is within the State of California and who contribute to the State Disability Insurance (SDI) program shall be eligible for California Paid Family Leave (PFL) benefits. Such PFL benefits provide partial wage replacement, currently at a rate of sixty (60) to seventy (70) percent of the employee’s usual weekly wage, up to a statutory maximum, for a period not to exceed eight (8) weeks within any twelve (12) month period.

5.  3.2. **FMLA Leave**: Eligible employees, as defined by the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993, 29 U.S.C. §§ 2601 et seq., working for Sterling Consolidated, Inc. at worksites where fifty (50) or more employees are employed by the company within seventy-five (75) miles of that worksite, and who have been employed by Sterling Consolidated, Inc. for at least twelve (12) months, and have worked at least 1,250 hours for the company during the twelve (12)-month period immediately preceding the commencement of leave, are eligible for up to twelve (12) weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave for qualifying reasons, including but not limited to, the birth of a child, the adoption of a child, or to care for a spouse, child, or parent with a serious health condition.

6.  3.3. **Integration of PFL and FMLA**: For California employees eligible for both California PFL and federal FMLA leave for the same qualifying event (e.g., bonding with a newborn child), Sterling Consolidated, Inc. will administer these leaves concurrently. The employee shall initially utilize their PFL benefits, and the period of PFL leave will run concurrently with the employee's FMLA leave. However, the total combined leave period shall not exceed twelve (12) weeks.

7.  3.4 **Notification Requirements**: Employees seeking to utilize either PFL or FMLA shall notify the HR department at least thirty (30) days in advance of the anticipated leave commencement date, if the need for leave is foreseeable. If the need for leave is unforeseeable, the employee must provide notice as soon as practicable, generally within one (1) to two (2) business days of learning of the need for leave. Failure to provide timely notice may result in a delay in the commencement of leave.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated HR Policy Manual**

**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Revision Date:** 2024-07-26
**Effective Date:** 2025-01-01

Sterling Consolidated is committed to providing a productive and healthy work environment for all employees. This section outlines the company's policy regarding meal and rest breaks. As a general principle, Sterling Consolidated strives to comply with all applicable federal regulations regarding employee breaks.

All non-exempt employees are eligible for breaks, although the specific timing and duration of such breaks may vary depending on operational needs and departmental schedules. Specifically, should a non-exempt employee work at least eight (8) hours during a single workday, they are generally expected to take at least a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. Such meal breaks should ideally be scheduled near the midpoint of the shift, but supervisors retain discretion in determining the precise timing, taking into account workload and coverage requirements. Rest breaks, typically of shorter duration, may be provided at the supervisor's discretion, considering factors such as employee fatigue, the nature of the work being performed, and applicable safety regulations. While Sterling Consolidated endeavors to offer convenient break opportunities, the failure to take a break does not create any separate or additional rights or remedies for employees, provided management makes a reasonable effort to provide the opportunity. Note that nothing in this policy shall be interpreted to contravene applicable regulations, as per Section 1.2, "Interpretation of Policy". As a reminder, Sterling Consolidated employees must accurately record all time worked, including break periods, as outlined in Section 3.1, "Timekeeping Procedures".

Supervisors are responsible for ensuring adequate coverage during break periods and for addressing any questions or concerns employees may have regarding this policy. Employees are encouraged to communicate with their supervisors if they have difficulty taking scheduled breaks.

Policy text:
**Veridian Dynamics Employee Handbook**
**Section 3: Employment Termination and Layoff Procedures**
**Policy 3.2: Workforce Reductions and WARN Act Compliance**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

3.2.1 General Policy. It is the policy of Veridian Dynamics to manage workforce reductions in a manner that is both compliant with applicable state and federal laws and respectful of affected employees. This policy applies to all employees whose primary work location is within the State of California.

3.2.2 California WARN Act Notification. Notwithstanding any provisions to the contrary in other company policies, in the event of a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation, as those terms are defined under the California Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act (California Labor Code Sections 1400 et seq.), Veridian Dynamics shall provide written notice to affected employees at least sixty (60) calendar days prior to the date of separation, provided that the mass layoff affects 50 or more employees at a single site of employment within a 30-day period. For purposes of determining whether the 50-employee threshold is met, only employees whose primary work location is in California shall be counted. However, in determining applicability of this section 3.2.2, the foregoing is contingent upon the employer.employee_count being greater than or equal to 75, calculated using the total number of employees employed by Veridian Dynamics across all its locations, including those outside of California, because federal WARN notice obligations may apply depending on employee headcount in other states. The precise content and delivery method of such notices shall conform to the requirements of the California WARN Act and any applicable federal regulations.

3.2.3 Exceptions. Nothing in this policy is intended to create any contractual rights or obligations not otherwise required by law. Veridian Dynamics reserves the right to modify or terminate this policy at any time, with or without notice, subject to applicable legal requirements. This section does not apply to terminations for cause, voluntary resignations, or retirement.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Workforce Reductions and WARN Act Compliance**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

This section outlines Acme Corp’s policy regarding workforce reductions, including layoffs, plant closures, and relocations. Acme Corp is committed to treating all employees with respect and dignity during these transitions. This policy is intended to comply with the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, 29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq. Note that this policy applies to all US employees, irrespective of their state of residence.

Acme Corp will provide advance notice of any plant closing or mass layoff, as defined under the WARN Act, to affected employees. A "plant closing" means the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding any part-time employees. A "mass layoff" means a reduction in force which is not the result of a plant closing and results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, where these employees represent at least 33% of the employer's total active workforce at that single site of employment. Employees are considered part time if they have worked less than six months in the previous twelve months or averaged less than 20 hours a week.

Therefore, if Acme Corp employs 100 or more employees at a single site of employment and a mass layoff, as defined above, is planned which will result in an employment loss for 50 or more employees at that site during any 30-day period, then the company will provide at least 60 calendar days advance written notice to the affected employees. In the event a mass layoff occurs, and the affected employee count is equal to 50 or more, advance notice is required. However, in situations where an employee is terminated for cause and is immediately removed from their position, no advance notice is required.

Policy text:
**Sunrise Technologies Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

It is Sunrise Technologies' policy to comply with all applicable wage and hour laws, including those pertaining to overtime compensation. This section outlines the company's policy on overtime pay, which is designed to follow both federal and California state regulations. Given the complexities of these regulations, employees should consult with their supervisor or the HR department if they have any questions regarding their eligibility for overtime or the calculation of overtime pay.

Non-exempt employees, as defined under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), are generally eligible for overtime pay. Overtime is defined as time worked beyond 40 hours in a workweek. For employees working in California, overtime is also earned for time worked over eight hours in a workday. In accordance with California law, employees will receive one and one-half times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked beyond eight (8) in a single workday, up to twelve (12) hours, and for all hours worked beyond forty (40) in a workweek, if the weekly hours exceed the daily calculation. Furthermore, for California employees, two times the regular rate of pay will be paid for all hours worked over twelve (12) in a workday or for any hours worked beyond eight (8) on the seventh consecutive day of work in a workweek.

It is important to note that this policy is subject to change and does not create any contractual rights. The company reserves the right to modify or terminate this policy at any time, with or without notice. Some employees might be classified as exempt and are therefore not eligible for overtime, as outlined in section 3.3 of this handbook, "Exempt Employee Classifications". Questions regarding exempt status should be directed to the HR department. The calculation of overtime will be based on the employee’s regular rate of pay, as defined by applicable law, and will include all non-discretionary bonuses and commissions.

Policy text:
**Innovision Corp. Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks**
*Revision 1.2, Effective Date: 2024-01-01*

Innovision Corp. is committed to complying with all applicable state and federal laws regarding employee meal and rest breaks. This policy applies to all active employees of Innovision Corp., regardless of location, but provides specific guidance for employees working in California, given the state's more stringent requirements.

**3.4.1 California Employees:** Pursuant to California Labor Code Sections 226.7 and 512, all non-exempt employees working in California shall be provided with a 30-minute unpaid meal break for each work period exceeding five (5) hours. A second 30-minute unpaid meal break shall be provided for work periods exceeding ten (10) hours. These meal breaks must commence no later than the end of the employee’s fifth (5th) hour of work and tenth (10th) hour of work respectively. Furthermore, non-exempt employees working in California are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Employees are required to take all meal and rest breaks as required by law. Failure to do so may result in disciplinary action.

**3.4.2 Employees Outside of California:** For employees located outside of California, Innovision Corp. will adhere to applicable federal law. Federal law does not mandate meal or rest breaks for adult employees. However, if Innovision Corp. chooses to provide short breaks (typically lasting five (5) to twenty (20) minutes), these breaks shall be considered paid time. Bona fide meal periods (typically thirty (30) minutes or more) need not be compensated when the employee is completely relieved of duty for the purpose of eating a regular meal.

**3.4.3 Missed Breaks:** Notwithstanding the foregoing, in California, if a meal or rest break is not provided in accordance with Section 3.4.1, the employee shall be compensated with one (1) hour of premium pay for each missed meal or rest break. It is the employee’s responsibility to immediately report any missed meal or rest breaks to their supervisor or Human Resources department.

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Meal and Rest Breaks (Rev. 2.0)**
**Effective Date: 2024-10-26**

This policy outlines Sterling Dynamics' approach to meal and rest breaks for all employees. Sterling Dynamics strives to comply with all applicable state and federal laws, though certain provisions will vary depending on employee location and classification.

**General Provisions:**

Sterling Dynamics acknowledges the importance of providing employees with adequate breaks during their workdays. This policy is intended to comply with both California state law and applicable federal regulations concerning meal and rest breaks. Employees are responsible for adhering to this policy.

**California Employees:**

For employees working in California, the following provisions apply:

*   Any employee working more than five (5) hours in a workday is entitled to a thirty (30)-minute unpaid meal period.
*   A second thirty (30)-minute unpaid meal period is required for any employee working more than ten (10) hours in a workday. Such second meal period may be waived by mutual consent of the employer and employee only if the total hours worked in the workday do not exceed twelve (12) hours, and the first meal period was not waived.
*   Employees shall receive a paid ten (10)-minute rest period for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof.
*   If Sterling Dynamics does not provide a required meal or rest period, the employee will be compensated with one (1) hour of pay at their regular rate of compensation for each workday that the meal or rest period is not provided.

**Employees Outside of California:**

For employees working in states other than California, Sterling Dynamics will comply with all applicable state and federal laws regarding meal and rest breaks. It is Sterling Dynamics' policy to provide employees with appropriate break times, generally in accordance with federal guidelines. If an employee works a shift exceeding five hours, they will be offered an unpaid meal period lasting at least thirty minutes, during which the employee is completely relieved of all duties. Shorter breaks, if provided, will be considered paid time. This policy may be modified to comply with individual state law where applicable. See Section 3.2.1 for State-Specific Break Policies.

Sterling Dynamics reserves the right to modify this policy at any time.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook**
**Section 3: Employment Termination and Layoffs**
**Policy 3.2: Layoff Notification (WARN Act Compliance)**
**Revision Number:** 1.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01

Acme Corp. is committed to treating employees with respect and dignity during workforce reductions. This policy outlines our procedures for providing advance notice of layoffs, in compliance with the federal Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act and the California WARN Act.

**3.2.1 General Notice Requirement:**

Acme Corp. will provide employees with written notice at least 60 days before any plant closing or mass layoff, as defined by the WARN Acts. A "plant closing" means the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees excluding any part-time employees. A "mass layoff" means a reduction in force which is not the result of a plant closing, and results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for (a) 50 or more employees when the employer employs at least 100 employees excluding any part-time employees; or (b) 50 or more employees when the employer employs fewer than 100 employees, but at least 75 employees excluding any part-time employees.

If Acme Corp. employs 100 or more employees company-wide and plans a mass layoff affecting 50 or more employees at a single site, we are required to provide 60 days' notice under the Federal WARN Act. However, if those affected employees are in California, the threshold drops to 75 total employees company-wide including those in California, and the layoff affects 50 or more, then the CA WARN act will govern. Further details on employee separation policies can be found in Section 3.3.

**3.2.2 Exemptions and Exceptions:**

While we aim to provide 60 days' notice whenever possible, unforeseen business circumstances may necessitate shorter notice periods. In such cases, we will provide as much notice as is reasonably practicable. We will also make every effort to provide affected employees with resources and support to assist them in their job search.

Policy text:
**Sterling Fabricators Inc. - Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.2: Workforce Adjustments and WARN Act Compliance**
**Policy Number:** HR-320
**Revision:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01

Sterling Fabricators Inc. is committed to complying with all applicable federal and state laws regarding workforce reductions. This policy outlines the procedures we follow in the event of a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation, as defined by the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act and related state laws, specifically California's WARN Act.

To determine if the WARN Act applies to a particular situation, the following guidelines will be used. The federal WARN Act requires 60 days advance written notice if a plant closing or mass layoff affects 50 or more employees at a single site of employment, provided the employer has 100 or more employees company-wide. Please note that temporary employees, as defined in Section 1.4, and employees on approved leaves of absence, as defined in Section 4.1, may or may not be counted towards the 50-employee threshold depending on the specific circumstances and the guidance provided by legal counsel at the time of the event.

In California, the state WARN Act has slightly different requirements. If Sterling Fabricators Inc. employs 75 or more employees, the California WARN Act may be triggered if a mass layoff, relocation, or plant closure affects 50 or more employees within a 30-day period. In determining whether an event triggers the California WARN Act, all employees working in California are counted toward the 75-employee threshold. The HR department, in coordination with legal counsel, will be responsible for evaluating each situation to determine whether notification is required under either the federal or California WARN Act, or both. No such notice is required under any circumstances when the layoff is a direct result of a strike or lockout.

Policy text:
**The Golden Gate Corporation - HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Family and Medical Leave Policy (California)**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

3.12.1 **General Provisions:** This policy outlines The Golden Gate Corporation’s guidelines for Family and Medical Leave in compliance with the California Family Rights Act (CFRA), California Paid Family Leave (PFL), and the federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA). Employees working in California are eligible for leave benefits as outlined herein, which shall be interpreted in accordance with California law.

3.12.2 **Eligibility for California Paid Family Leave (PFL):** Pursuant to California Unemployment Insurance Code Sections 3300 et seq., employees who contribute to California State Disability Insurance (SDI) are eligible for up to eight (8) weeks of PFL benefits within a twelve (12) month period for qualifying events, including bonding with a new child or caring for a seriously ill family member. The employee's employment status must be active at the commencement of the leave. Employees whose employment status is terminated, resigned, or laid off prior to the commencement of the leave period are not eligible for PFL benefits through The Golden Gate Corporation, notwithstanding their prior SDI contributions. Eligibility for continued PFL benefits following a valid leave that was started prior to a change in employment status will be determined by the Employment Development Department (EDD).

3.12.3 **Interaction with FMLA:** While the federal FMLA provides for up to twelve (12) weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave, employees are eligible for unpaid leave under FMLA only if Golden Gate Corporation employs fifty (50) or more employees within a seventy-five (75) mile radius of the employee's worksite, and the employee has worked for the company for at least twelve (12) months and at least 1,250 hours in the preceding twelve (12) months. The employee’s leave type must also qualify under the Family and Medical Leave Act, such as being for a medical condition, or to bond with a child.

3.12.4 **Leave Termination:** Should an employee, who is receiving PFL benefits, voluntarily resign their position with The Golden Gate Corporation or be involuntarily terminated for cause, the employee’s participation in PFL will not be affected. The employee must notify the Employment Development Department of their termination if it occurs during their leave. Employees who fail to return to work at The Golden Gate Corporation upon expiration of their PFL leave may be subject to termination unless an approved extension of leave has been granted under separate policy.

Policy text:
**Momentum Global Solutions – Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Policy 3.2.7: Final Wage Payment**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

3.2.7.1 Final payment of wages to employees whose employment with Momentum Global Solutions terminates, whether voluntarily or involuntarily, shall be governed by the following provisions, notwithstanding Section 3.1.1 concerning standard payroll cycles.

3.2.7.2 For employees whose primary work location is within the State of California, and whose termination is involuntary, all wages earned and unpaid at the time of termination shall be due and payable immediately at the time of discharge, pursuant to California Labor Code Section 201. However, in cases where the employee's personnel file lacks complete contact information or where direct deposit information is unavailable, and the employee has not provided updated information despite reasonable attempts by the Company to obtain it, the Company may remit the final wage payment via mailed check within 72 hours of termination. Employees who voluntarily resign from their position at Momentum Global Solutions must be paid their final wages on their last day of employment if they provide at least 72 hours advance notice of their intent to resign. If an employee provides less than 72 hours’ notice, their final wages shall be available for pickup at the Momentum Global Solutions principal place of business within seventy-two (72) hours of their last day of employment.

3.2.7.3 For employees whose primary work location is outside of the State of California, or for California employees when federal law preempts state law, final payment of wages shall be made no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following the termination of employment, pursuant to the Fair Labor Standards Act. For the avoidance of doubt, this section applies irrespective of whether the termination was voluntary or involuntary.

3.2.7.4 Nothing in this policy shall be construed to permit the unlawful withholding of wages. The Company shall make a good faith effort to comply with all applicable federal and state laws regarding final wage payments. Any questions or concerns regarding final wage payments should be directed to the Human Resources Department.

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation**
**Revision:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01

Sterling Dynamics values its employees' dedication and understands that occasionally, business needs require employees to work beyond their regularly scheduled hours. This section outlines our policy regarding overtime compensation, which is designed to comply with both federal and California state law. Note: this policy is subject to change at any time, with or without notice.

**3.2.1 Overtime Eligibility & Calculation**

Non-exempt employees are eligible for overtime pay. “Non-exempt” refers to employees who are covered by federal and state wage and hour laws and therefore entitled to overtime compensation. Overtime pay will be calculated based on an employee’s regular hourly rate of pay. According to federal law and the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), overtime is earned when an employee works more than forty (40) hours in a workweek. However, employees located in California are also entitled to overtime compensation for any hours worked over eight (8) in a single workday. Therefore, if a non-exempt employee in California works more than eight (8) hours in a workday but does *not* exceed forty (40) hours in the workweek, they will be paid at one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for all hours exceeding eight (8) worked that day. Employees cannot waive their right to overtime pay. If the employee works over 40 hours in a week, even if they have daily overtime, they are entitled to 1.5x their wage for any hours worked over 40, regardless of previous daily calculations. This policy is intended to be interpreted in accordance with all applicable federal and California wage and hour laws, including, but not limited to, California Labor Code Sections 500 et seq. Please consult with HR if you have any questions.

Policy text:
**Titan Industries Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks (California Employees)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

3.4.1 Policy Statement

Titan Industries is committed to complying with all applicable California Labor Laws. This policy applies exclusively to employees whose primary work location is within the State of California. Notwithstanding any other provision in this handbook, the following meal and rest break requirements shall govern for all non-exempt employees.

3.4.2 Meal Breaks

Pursuant to California Labor Code Section 512, all non-exempt employees of Titan Industries who work more than five (5) hours in a workday shall be provided with a meal period of no less than thirty (30) minutes. The meal period must commence no later than the end of the employee’s fifth (5th) hour of work, except where a waiver is mutually agreed upon as outlined in section 3.4.4. If a non-exempt employee works more than ten (10) hours in a workday, they shall be provided with a second meal period of no less than thirty (30) minutes, which must commence no later than the end of the employee’s tenth (10th) hour of work, unless an applicable waiver is in place. These meal periods are unpaid, provided that the employee is completely relieved of all duty and responsibility during the meal period.

3.4.3 Rest Breaks

All non-exempt employees are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. To the extent feasible, rest breaks should be taken in the middle of each four-hour work period. Rest breaks shall not be taken at the beginning or end of the workday.

3.4.4 Meal Period Waivers

Where a workday of not more than six (6) hours will complete the day's work, the meal period may be waived by mutual consent of both the employer and the employee. Additionally, if an employee works more than ten (10) hours per workday, the second meal period may be waived if the employee and the employer consent, provided that the first meal period was not waived. Such waivers must be documented in writing and signed by both the employee and a representative of Titan Industries Human Resources.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.14: Final Paycheck Distribution**
**Revision Date:** 2024-10-26
**Effective Date:** 2025-01-01

3.  14.  1 General Policy
        Sterling Consolidated is committed to complying with all applicable federal and state wage and hour laws regarding the timely distribution of final paychecks to employees whose employment with the company has ended. This policy applies to all employees, irrespective of their employment status, classification, or location. This policy is intended to comply with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and relevant state labor codes.

4.  14.  2 Final Paycheck Timing
        Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary in this policy, and pursuant to California Labor Code Sections 201 and 202, if an employee's primary work location is within the State of California, and the employee is involuntarily terminated, all wages earned and unpaid at the time of termination shall be due and payable immediately at the time of termination. All other employees outside of California will receive their final paycheck on the next regularly scheduled payday following their termination date. For purposes of this section, "wages" shall be defined as set forth in Section 200 of the California Labor Code. Employees who voluntarily resign are subject to a different set of rules as outlined in Section 3.14.3.

5.  14.  3 Voluntary Resignation (California Employees)
        If a California-based employee voluntarily resigns, the timing of the final paycheck depends on the amount of notice provided. If the employee provides at least seventy-two (72) hours' notice of their intention to resign, their final paycheck will be available on their last day of employment. If the employee provides less than seventy-two (72) hours' notice, the final paycheck will be available within seventy-two (72) hours of the employee's last day of employment.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.0: Leave Policies**

**3.2 Family and Medical Leave (FMLA)**

**3.2.1 Eligibility and Entitlement**

Acme Corp. adheres to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 (FMLA), 29 U.S.C. § 2601 et seq., which entitles eligible employees to up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave for specified family and medical reasons. To be eligible for FMLA leave, an employee must have been employed by Acme Corp. for at least 12 months and must have worked for at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period immediately preceding the commencement of the leave. Furthermore, Acme Corp. must employ 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of the employee's worksite.

**3.2.2 Qualifying Reasons for Leave**

FMLA leave may be taken for any of the following reasons: (a) the birth of a child and to bond with the newborn child within one year of birth; (b) the placement of a child with the employee for adoption or foster care and to bond with the newly placed child within one year of placement; (c) to care for the employee's spouse, child, or parent who has a serious health condition; (d) a serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the essential functions of his or her job; (e) any qualifying exigency arising out of the fact that the employee's spouse, son, daughter, or parent is a covered military member on active duty (or has been notified of an impending call or order to active duty) in the Armed Forces.

**3.2.3 Policy Conflicts**

Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Section 3.2, should an employee's location state be California, and that employee pays into State Disability Insurance (SDI), they will not be eligible for any company-provided leave beyond what is legally mandated under California Paid Family Leave, regardless of FMLA eligibility.

**3.2.4 Employee Responsibilities**

Employees seeking FMLA leave are required to provide Acme Corp. with at least 30 days' advance notice of the need for leave when the need is foreseeable. When the need for leave is not foreseeable, employees must provide notice as soon as practicable.

**Revision 1.0 - Effective Date: 2024-01-01**

Policy text:
**Section 3.0: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Policy 3.2: Federally Mandated Break Periods**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision Number: 1.0**

3.2.1. This policy outlines the break requirements applicable to employees of Stellaris Technologies, Inc. within the United States, pursuant to applicable federal law. Notwithstanding any other Stellaris Technologies, Inc. policy, including but not limited to Section 2.1 regarding employee scheduling, the following shall apply. Because Federal law does not mandate meal or rest breaks for employees aged eighteen (18) or over, Stellaris Technologies, Inc. is not required to provide such breaks. However, where Stellaris Technologies, Inc. voluntarily provides breaks of a short duration, specifically five (5) minutes to twenty (20) minutes in length, such breaks shall be considered "rest periods" and shall be compensated as time worked. Conversely, meal periods, defined as periods of thirty (30) minutes or more during which the employee is completely relieved of all duties, are not required to be compensated, provided the employee is, in fact, completely relieved of all duties. Determination of complete relief shall be made at the sole discretion of the employee's supervisor or manager, and the employee bears the responsibility of bringing any concerns about non-compliant break periods to the attention of Human Resources within five (5) business days of the alleged infraction. Moreover, failure to comply with these federal standards concerning paid rest periods can result in disciplinary action up to and including termination. Should any portion of an authorized meal period require an employee to conduct work duties, that said meal period is considered a rest period under federal standards. Employees must report any time worked to their supervisor for accurate record keeping.

Furthermore, while Stellaris Technologies, Inc. endeavors to provide a work environment that complies with all applicable laws, employees are solely responsible for tracking their time and ensuring the accuracy of their timecards. Any disputes regarding break periods must be submitted in writing to Human Resources within the aforementioned timeframe for investigation and resolution.

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation**
**Revision:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01

Sterling Dynamics is committed to complying with all applicable federal laws regarding employee compensation. This Section 3.2 outlines the company’s policy concerning overtime pay. All non-exempt employees are eligible for overtime compensation as defined herein. Please note that this policy is governed solely by federal law, specifically the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). Any employee questions should be directed to the Human Resources department for clarification.

Overtime compensation is calculated at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times the employee’s regular hourly rate for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours in a workweek. For purposes of this policy, a workweek is defined as a consecutive seven (7) day period beginning at 12:00 AM on Sunday and ending at 11:59 PM on Saturday. It is important to note that while some states have specific laws surrounding daily overtime or other overtime rules, Sterling Dynamics adheres only to the federal requirements established by the FLSA.

Violation of Company Policy 3.2, including but not limited to, intentionally falsifying time records or working unauthorized overtime, may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment. Unauthorized overtime requires prior approval from a supervisor. Approval must be obtained *before* the overtime hours are worked.

Employees who fail to obtain prior supervisor authorization *and* who work more than fifty (50) hours in a workweek, *and* who have been previously warned about unauthorized overtime, may be subject to immediate termination, notwithstanding Section 7.1 (“Progressive Discipline”), unless the employee can provide a reasonable explanation that is deemed satisfactory by HR. Whether an explanation is reasonable or not is up to the sole discretion of the HR department. This termination is considered involuntary.

Policy text:
**Golden Gate Solutions, Inc. - Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks (Revised: 2.0)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**

Golden Gate Solutions, Inc. recognizes the importance of providing employees with adequate meal and rest breaks to maintain productivity and well-being. This policy applies to all non-exempt employees working in the state of California, and supplements any other applicable policies regarding employee welfare.

Consistent with California law, non-exempt employees who work more than five (5) hours in a workday are entitled to a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. The meal break should ideally begin before the end of the employee's fifth hour of work. In certain circumstances, if the nature of the work prevents an employee from being relieved of all duty during a 30-minute period, and by written agreement between the employer and employee, an on-duty meal period will be permitted which shall be counted as time worked.

Employees who work more than ten (10) hours in a workday are entitled to a second thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break, subject to the same on-duty meal period provisions.

Also per California requirements, non-exempt employees are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. As far as possible, rest breaks should be scheduled in the middle of the four-hour work period. An employee's failure to take a break is not a violation of the policy so long as it is not the result of the company preventing it.

Any employee who feels they were prevented from taking their meal or rest breaks should immediately notify their manager, and may be subject to termination as stated in Section 5.1 (disciplinary actions).

Policy text:
**Starlight Technologies Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Leave Policies**
**Policy 3.4.2: California Paid Family Leave (PFL) and Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

This policy outlines Starlight Technologies’ approach to California Paid Family Leave (PFL) and the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) for employees working in California. Starlight Technologies is committed to complying with both state and federal regulations regarding employee leave.

*   **Overview:** California Paid Family Leave (PFL) provides eligible employees with partial wage replacement benefits while they take time off to care for a seriously ill family member, bond with a new child, or participate in a qualifying event related to a family member's military deployment. FMLA provides eligible employees with unpaid, job-protected leave for similar reasons, as well as for their own serious health condition. These two leaves may run concurrently or consecutively, depending on the employee’s eligibility for each and the specific circumstances of the leave request.

*   **California Paid Family Leave (PFL):** Under California law, eligible employees who contribute to State Disability Insurance (SDI) may receive up to eight (8) weeks of partial wage replacement benefits (typically 60-70% of their usual wages) through the State of California Employment Development Department (EDD) while taking time off for qualifying family care or bonding purposes. This leave is administered by the EDD, not Starlight Technologies directly. Please consult the EDD website for complete information on eligibility requirements and benefit amounts. If an employee works in California, contributes to SDI, requests leave for bonding with a new child, and the leave duration is eight weeks or less, then Starlight Technologies will cooperate with the EDD to facilitate that employee's claim for PFL benefits. Employees must file a claim with the EDD to receive PFL benefits.

*   **Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA):** FMLA provides eligible employees with up to twelve (12) weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave in a twelve-month period for the birth or adoption of a child, to care for a seriously ill family member, or for the employee’s own serious health condition. To be eligible for FMLA, an employee must have worked for Starlight Technologies for at least twelve (12) months and have worked at least 1,250 hours during the twelve-month period immediately preceding the leave. Starlight Technologies adheres to the FMLA regulations for employers with 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of the employee's worksite.

*   **Coordination of PFL and FMLA:** Where an employee is eligible for both PFL and FMLA, the leaves may run concurrently. In such cases, the employee will receive PFL benefits from the EDD while their job is protected under FMLA. Starlight Technologies will provide the required notices for both FMLA and PFL.

*   **Employee Responsibilities:** Employees seeking PFL or FMLA leave must provide Starlight Technologies with as much advance notice as possible. Employees seeking FMLA leave for their own serious health condition or to care for a seriously ill family member may be required to provide medical certification to support their request.

*   **Return to Work:** Upon returning from PFL or FMLA leave, employees are generally entitled to be restored to their same position or to an equivalent position with equivalent pay, benefits, and other terms and conditions of employment.

Please see Policy 3.4.1 (General Leave Policy) for information on other types of leave, such as vacation, sick leave, and bereavement leave.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. - Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.4: Family and Medical Leave (California Employees)**
**Revision Date:** 2024-10-26
**Effective Date:** 2025-01-01

Acme Corp. is committed to supporting our California employees in balancing their work and family responsibilities. This policy outlines our approach to Family and Medical Leave, complying with both federal and California law. Please note that eligibility requirements and benefit levels differ between the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) and California Paid Family Leave (PFL). Employees should consult with HR for individual clarification.

Eligible California employees who contribute to State Disability Insurance (SDI) are generally entitled to participate in the California Paid Family Leave (PFL) program. PFL provides partial wage replacement, typically between 60% and 70% of your usual wages, for up to 8 weeks to bond with a new child or care for a seriously ill family member. This leave runs concurrently with any FMLA leave. For clarification, eligibility for PFL is determined by the State of California, not Acme Corp. Employees may also be eligible for up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave under the federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) if the employee has worked for Acme Corp. for at least 12 months and has worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period immediately preceding the leave.

While FMLA provides up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave, the amount of leave an employee is actually entitled to may be affected by any previous FMLA leave that has been used by the employee in the past 12 months. For employees who qualify for both FMLA and PFL, the leave will run concurrently. Note that FMLA is generally unpaid, with the exception of using accrued PTO or vacation time to offset some of the absence; while PFL is paid by the state and will not require using existing vacation time. Therefore, up to 8 weeks could be compensated by the state under PFL while the remaining 4 weeks of FMLA leave may be unpaid. It is imperative that employees review their specific circumstances with the HR department to confirm the exact amount of leave they can take and payment options.
