Policy text:
**Sterling Innovations, Inc. - Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.4: Overtime Compensation (California Employees)**
**Revision Date:** 2024-07-01
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01

This policy applies exclusively to Sterling Innovations, Inc. employees whose primary work location is within the State of California. It is designed to ensure compliance with both federal and California state law regarding overtime compensation. In cases where federal and state law differ, Sterling Innovations, Inc. will adhere to the law most beneficial to the employee.

**3.4.1 Overtime Eligibility and Calculation**

Non-exempt employees are eligible for overtime pay. For California-based non-exempt employees, overtime is calculated as follows:

*   **Daily Overtime:** Employees are entitled to overtime pay at one and one-half (1.5) times their regular hourly rate for all hours worked in excess of eight (8) hours in any workday. For example, if a non-exempt employee works 10 hours in a single day, they are entitled to overtime for the 2 hours exceeding 8.
*   **Double Time:** Employees will be paid two (2) times their regular hourly rate for all hours worked in excess of twelve (12) hours in any workday. Additionally, double time applies to all hours worked on the seventh (7th) consecutive day of a workweek. For example, if an employee works 14 hours one day, they are entitled to 2 hours of double time.
*   **Weekly Overtime:** Regardless of daily hours, employees also receive overtime pay at one and one-half (1.5) times their regular hourly rate for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours in a workweek. This ensures compliance with federal standards, even if the daily overtime rule has already been triggered. For instance, an employee might not work over 8 hours any single day, but if they accumulate more than 40 hours over the workweek, they are entitled to overtime for those excess hours.

Employees are responsible for accurately recording their work hours, in accordance with Section 2.2 (Timekeeping Procedures). Overtime must be pre-approved by the employee’s supervisor in order to be paid. Any unauthorized overtime may be subject to disciplinary action.

This policy is subject to change at any time, with or without notice.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.2: Final Paycheck Distribution**
**Revision 1.0**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**

Acme Corp is committed to ensuring that employees receive their final paycheck in a timely manner. This policy outlines the procedures for distributing final paychecks to employees whose employment with Acme Corp has ended, keeping in accordance with federal regulations.

Generally, final paychecks, including all accrued but unused vacation time (see Policy 4.1 Vacation and Paid Time Off), will be processed and distributed to the former employee on the next regularly scheduled payday following the employee’s last day of work. However, for employees who are involuntarily terminated as defined in Section 1.2 Definitions, and have completed at least twelve (12) months of continuous service with Acme Corp, the final paycheck will be made available for pick-up at the employee’s primary worksite within 72 hours of termination, provided the Payroll Department receives notification of the termination prior to 12:00 PM Pacific Time on the employee’s last day of work. If notification is received after this time, the paycheck will be available within 72 hours from the start of the next business day. Employees who voluntarily resign and have given at least two weeks written notice, should expect their final paychecks on the next regular pay date following their separation date. All final paychecks not picked up within 14 calendar days will be mailed to the employee’s last known address on file. This policy applies to all Acme Corp employees located within the United States, regardless of employee classification.

Policy text:
**Bright Future Corp. Employee Handbook**
**Section 5.0: Leave Policies**
**5.2 Family and Medical Leave (Revision 1.3, Effective January 1, 2025)**

Bright Future Corp. is committed to supporting our employees through significant life events. This policy outlines our approach to Family and Medical Leave, complying with both federal and California state law where applicable.

**5.2.1 Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

Eligible employees may be entitled to up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) for qualifying reasons, including the birth or adoption of a child, to care for a seriously ill family member (as defined by the FMLA), or the employee's own serious health condition. To be eligible for FMLA leave, an employee must have been employed by Bright Future Corp. for at least 12 months and have worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period immediately preceding the leave commencement date. Further, Bright Future Corp. must employ 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of the employee's worksite. FMLA leave runs concurrently with other applicable leaves, such as California Paid Family Leave (PFL), when the reason for leave qualifies under both statutes.

**5.2.2 California Paid Family Leave (PFL)**

For employees who pay into California State Disability Insurance (SDI), California Paid Family Leave (PFL) provides partial wage replacement benefits. Generally, PFL provides up to eight weeks of partial wage replacement (approximately 60-70% of wages, subject to change per state law) for bonding with a new child or caring for a seriously ill family member. However, if an employee's work location is not California or the employee's employment status is either terminated or resigned, they are not eligible for PFL benefits through Bright Future Corp, and should directly consult California state regulations for possible benefits eligibility. Coordination with FMLA leave is mandatory; the employee must simultaneously apply for both leaves if eligible.

**5.2.3 Interplay of FMLA and PFL**

It is Bright Future Corp.’s policy to comply with all applicable state and federal laws regarding family and medical leave. Employees are encouraged to consult with the Human Resources Department to determine their eligibility and understand the interplay of FMLA and PFL benefits. Bright Future Corp. reserves the right to modify this policy at any time to comply with changes in applicable law. See Section 5.5 for definitions of key terms used in this policy.

Policy text:
**NovaTech Solutions - Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.7: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01
**Revision:** 1.0

NovaTech Solutions is committed to complying with the federal Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act. This policy outlines the company’s responsibilities regarding advance notification in the event of a plant closing or mass layoff. The requirements outlined in this section are intended to comply with federal law only and do not address state-specific WARN regulations.

*   **General Notification Requirement:** NovaTech Solutions will provide at least 60 calendar days advance written notice to affected employees before any plant closing or mass layoff, as defined below, affecting a site of employment.

*   **Applicability:** This notification requirement applies if NovaTech Solutions employs 100 or more employees, not counting employees who have worked less than 6 months in the aggregate in the last 12 months or employees who work an average of less than 20 hours a week. A "plant closing" is defined as the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding part-time employees.

*   **Mass Layoff Definition:** A "mass layoff" is defined as a reduction in force that is not the result of a plant closing, and results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees if those 50 or more employees comprise at least 33% of the active employees at that site, or 500 or more employees are impacted regardless of percentage. Employees who are laid off for less than six months are not considered terminated and therefore not part of the WARN Act calculation. Employment loss includes termination, layoff exceeding six months, or a reduction in hours of more than 50 percent during each month of any 6-month period.

*   **Exclusions:** This policy does not apply to temporary layoffs, which are defined as layoffs lasting less than 6 months, or to employees who are offered a transfer to a different worksite within a reasonable commuting distance. This policy is subject to change as required by law. For any questions regarding this policy, please contact the HR Department. See Section 3.8 for policies related to severance pay.

Policy text:
**NovaTech Solutions Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.5: Family and Medical Leave**
*Revision Date: 2024-02-15*
*Effective Date: 2024-03-01*

NovaTech Solutions is committed to supporting our employees during significant life events. This section outlines our Family and Medical Leave policies, adhering to both federal and California state laws.

**3.5.1 Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

Eligible employees may take up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA). To be eligible for FMLA, an employee must have worked for NovaTech Solutions for at least 12 months and must have worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12 months immediately preceding the start of the leave. Additionally, NovaTech Solutions must employ 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of the employee's worksite. FMLA leave can be used for the birth and care of a newborn child, placement of a child for adoption or foster care, to care for a seriously ill family member (spouse, child, or parent), or for the employee's own serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the essential functions of their job. FMLA runs concurrently with other leaves where applicable. See Section 3.5.3 regarding interaction with California Paid Family Leave.

**3.5.2 California Paid Family Leave (PFL)**

For employees working in California who contribute to State Disability Insurance (SDI), California Paid Family Leave (PFL) provides partial wage replacement benefits. Specifically, if you're a California employee paying into SDI, you may receive up to 8 weeks of paid leave at approximately 60-70% of your usual wages to bond with a new child, care for a seriously ill family member (child, parent, spouse, or registered domestic partner), or participate in a qualifying event as defined by the California Employment Development Department (EDD). This leave runs concurrently with FMLA where applicable, but the key difference is that PFL provides partial wage replacement while FMLA is unpaid.

**3.5.3 Interaction of FMLA and PFL**

When an employee qualifies for both FMLA and PFL for the same event, such as bonding with a new child, the leaves will run concurrently. This means that the 12 weeks of unpaid FMLA leave and the 8 weeks of partially paid PFL leave will overlap.

**3.5.4 Requesting Leave**

Employees must provide NovaTech Solutions with advance notice of their intent to take family or medical leave, whenever possible. Requests should be submitted to the Human Resources Department using the designated forms and following the procedures outlined in Section 3.6 "Leave Request Process".

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated – Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Policy 3.2: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

3.2.1. **Purpose:** This policy outlines Sterling Consolidated's requirements for meal and rest breaks for all employees, pursuant to applicable federal and state laws.

3.2.2. **Applicability:** This policy applies to all Sterling Consolidated employees working within the United States. Where the laws of the state in which an employee is working provide greater protection or benefits than federal law, Sterling Consolidated shall comply with the applicable state law to the extent required by law. For example, employees working in California are afforded meal and rest breaks as described below.

3.2.3. **Meal Breaks:**

(a) Non-exempt employees who work more than five (5) hours in a workday shall be provided a duty-free meal period of no less than thirty (30) minutes. Pursuant to California Labor Code Section 512, if a non-exempt employee working in California works more than ten (10) hours in a workday, a second duty-free meal period of no less than thirty (30) minutes shall be provided. It is Sterling Consolidated's policy that employees working in California who routinely work shifts exceeding 10 hours, and whose employee.hours_worked_daily consistently exceeds 10 hours, may be required to sign a waiver to voluntarily waive their second meal period in accordance with applicable law, provided the total hours worked does not exceed twelve (12) hours. The specific requirements for the waiver of the second meal period are outlined in Appendix A.

3.2.4. **Rest Breaks:**

(a) All non-exempt employees are eligible for paid rest breaks.
(b) For every four (4) hours worked, non-exempt employees shall receive a paid rest period of no less than ten (10) minutes.
(c) Rest breaks are considered time worked and must be taken during the workday. Employees should endeavor to take rest breaks near the middle of each four (4) hour work period to the extent that it does not disrupt operations.
(d) Employees are required to record meal and rest breaks accurately in Sterling Consolidated's timekeeping system.
(e) Any employee who is denied a compliant meal or rest break should immediately report that matter to their supervisor.

Policy text:
**Section 3.05: Paid Family Leave and Family and Medical Leave**

**3.05.1. General Provisions**

StellarTech Solutions ("the Company") is committed to complying with both the California Paid Family Leave (PFL) program and the federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA). This section outlines the Company's policy regarding employee leave for family and medical reasons, as governed by California Unemployment Insurance Code Sections 3300 et seq. and the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993, 29 U.S.C. § 2601 et seq. This policy is effective as of January 1, 2024, and is subject to revision at the Company's discretion. (Revision 1.0).

**3.05.2. California Paid Family Leave (PFL)**

California PFL provides eligible employees who contribute to State Disability Insurance (SDI) with partial wage replacement benefits while they take time off work to bond with a new child or care for a seriously ill family member. Benefits are typically paid at approximately 60-70% of the employee's wages, up to a maximum benefit amount as determined by the State of California. Eligibility for PFL benefits is determined by the California Employment Development Department (EDD). The duration of paid leave under PFL is up to eight (8) weeks.

**3.05.3. Federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

FMLA provides eligible employees with up to twelve (12) weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave for certain family and medical reasons. To be eligible for FMLA leave, an employee must have been employed by the Company for at least twelve (12) months, and must have worked at least 1,250 hours during the twelve-month period immediately preceding the commencement of the leave. Furthermore, the Company must employ fifty (50) or more employees within a seventy-five (75) mile radius of the employee's worksite.

**3.05.4. Coordination of PFL and FMLA**

Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary, if an employee is employed in the State of California and is eligible for both California Paid Family Leave (PFL) and Federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), and the employee's leave.type is bonding, the employee will be granted leave under both statutes concurrently. Compensation will only be available under PFL. The employee will not receive company-sponsored supplemental pay for such time.

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics Inc. - Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.14: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance (California)**
**Revision Date:** 2024-07-01
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01

This policy outlines Sterling Dynamics Inc.'s procedures for workforce reductions in California, ensuring compliance with both the federal and California Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Acts. Sterling Dynamics is committed to treating employees with respect and dignity throughout any workforce transition.

**(a) WARN Act Applicability:**

The California WARN Act applies to Sterling Dynamics Inc. if we employ 75 or more employees in California at any time during the 12-month period preceding a covered action. This includes full-time, part-time and hourly employees. Should Sterling Dynamics Inc. plan a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation affecting 50 or more employees at a single site of employment within a 30-day period in California, the requirements of the California WARN Act will apply. Note: This is more stringent than the Federal WARN Act, which applies to employers with 100 or more employees.

**(b) Notice Requirements:**

If a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation as defined by the California WARN Act is planned, Sterling Dynamics Inc. will provide affected employees with a written notice at least 60 calendar days in advance of the effective date of the action. This notice will include, at minimum, the expected date of the first separation, the anticipated schedule for terminations, and contact information for company representatives who can provide further information. Notices will also be provided to the California Employment Development Department (EDD), the local workforce investment board, and the chief elected official of each city and county government where the layoff will occur.

**(c) Employee Eligibility:**

The notice requirement described above applies to all Sterling Dynamics Inc. employees in California regardless of employee.employment_status or employee.classification that may be impacted by a qualifying event. This includes, but is not limited to, temporary, part-time, and salaried employees. Employees outside of California do not fall under this policy, and will be governed by applicable employment laws in their respective locations.

**(d) Exceptions:**

Exceptions to the 60-day notice requirement may apply under certain circumstances, such as unforeseen business circumstances or natural disasters. Sterling Dynamics Inc. will consult with legal counsel to determine if any exception applies and document the reasons for any deviation from the standard notice period.

Policy text:
**Evergreen Solutions, Inc. – Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance (California)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01 Revision: 1.0**

This policy outlines Evergreen Solutions, Inc.'s obligations under the California Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, Cal. Labor Code Sections 1400 et seq. This policy applies exclusively to employees working in the state of California. It is the Company's policy to comply fully with the California WARN Act in the event of a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation, as defined under the Act. Please note that the federal WARN Act provides similar protections, but the California WARN Act offers additional coverage to California workers.

A "mass layoff" under the California WARN Act is defined as a layoff during any 30-day period of 50 or more employees at a covered establishment. A "covered establishment" is defined as any industrial or commercial facility or part thereof, that employs, or has employed within the preceding 3 years, 75 or more persons. Therefore, if Evergreen Solutions, Inc. employs 75 or more individuals in California and a layoff affects 50 or more employees within a 30-day window, 60 days advance written notice will be provided to affected employees. This requirement also applies if the layoff is due to the relocation of all or substantially all of the operations of the employer to a different location, or a plant closure. It is the responsibility of the Human Resources Department, in conjunction with legal counsel, to determine WARN Act applicability in any potential workforce reduction scenario. Employees must be advised of the layoff with at least 60 days notice. See Section 9.2 regarding Severance Pay for further details.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. HR Policy Manual**

**Section 3.4: Overtime Compensation**
**Revision Number:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01

Acme Corp. is committed to complying with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) regarding overtime pay. This policy outlines the company's guidelines for overtime compensation for all non-exempt employees working within the United States. For any questions or concerns regarding this policy, please contact the HR department.

**3.4.1 Overtime Eligibility**

Non-exempt employees are eligible for overtime pay as defined by the FLSA. Overtime compensation is paid at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times the employee’s regular rate of pay.

**3.4.2 Overtime Calculation**

Overtime is calculated on a weekly basis. An employee is eligible for overtime pay if their employee.hours_worked_weekly exceed forty (40) hours in a workweek. The workweek is defined as Sunday at 12:00 AM to Saturday at 11:59 PM. All hours actually worked (excluding paid time off, such as vacation, sick leave, or holidays) are included when calculating the total hours worked in a workweek. If an employee.classification is non_exempt and employee.hours_worked_weekly is greater than 40, then Acme Corp. will grant compensation at 1.5 times their regular rate of pay for those overtime hours. Overtime work must be pre-approved by the employee's supervisor. Failure to obtain pre-approval may result in disciplinary action.

**3.4.3 Record Keeping**

Accurate record-keeping of all hours worked is the responsibility of each employee. Employees must accurately record their start and end times, as well as any break periods, on their timesheets. Supervisors are responsible for reviewing and approving employee timesheets to ensure accuracy.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.2: Family and Medical Leave (California)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision Number: 2.0**

Acme Corp is committed to providing employees with leave benefits in accordance with applicable law. This section outlines our policy regarding Family and Medical Leave for employees working in California. For employees working outside of California, please see Section 3.3 regarding federal FMLA leave.

**3.2.1 California Paid Family Leave (PFL) and Federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

California employees who contribute to State Disability Insurance (SDI) may be eligible for California Paid Family Leave (PFL). PFL provides partial wage replacement benefits (typically 60-70% of your normal wages) for up to eight (8) weeks within a 12-month period. This benefit is administered by the California Employment Development Department (EDD), not Acme Corp directly.

To potentially qualify for both California PFL *and* Federal FMLA, a California employee must both contribute to SDI *and* have been employed by Acme Corp for at least twelve (12) months AND have worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period immediately preceding the commencement of leave. If all of these conditions are met, that California employee can take up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave under the FMLA as described in Section 3.3, and concurrently take up to 8 weeks of paid leave under California PFL if the leave reason also qualifies under California PFL guidelines. However, it should be noted that Acme Corp is not responsible for determining PFL eligibility, as the EDD makes the final determination. While FMLA leave runs concurrently with PFL (where applicable), an employee is *not* eligible for FMLA if they do not meet the requirements as described in Section 3.3.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated - Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.4: Family and Medical Leave (FMLA)**
**Policy Number:** HR-FML-2024-01
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01
**Revision:** 1.0

Sterling Consolidated is committed to complying with the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) of 1993. This policy outlines the provisions of FMLA and employee eligibility requirements. Please note this policy solely addresses FMLA, a federal law, and does not include any state-specific leave entitlements.

**Eligibility for FMLA Leave:**

Employees are eligible for FMLA leave if they meet *all* of the following conditions:

*   They have been employed by Sterling Consolidated for at least 12 months (employee.tenure_months >= 12).
*   They have worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period immediately preceding the commencement of the leave (employee.hours_worked_12_months >= 1250).
*   They are employed at a worksite where Sterling Consolidated employs at least 50 employees within 75 miles (employer.employee_count_within_75_miles >= 50).

**Entitlement to FMLA Leave:**

Eligible employees are entitled to up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave during any 12-month period for one or more of the following reasons:

*   The birth of a child and to bond with the newborn child within one year of birth.
*   The placement of a child with the employee for adoption or foster care and to bond with the newly placed child within one year of placement.
*   To care for the employee’s spouse, child, or parent who has a serious health condition.
*   A serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the essential functions of his or her job.
*   Any qualifying exigency arising out of the fact that the employee’s spouse, son, daughter, or parent is a covered military member on “covered active duty.”

Employees requesting FMLA leave must follow the procedures outlined in Section 3.5 ("Leave Request Process"). Failure to do so may result in delays in leave approval or denial of leave. Sterling Consolidated will maintain group health insurance coverage for employees on FMLA leave on the same terms as if they were actively employed. Upon return from FMLA leave, employees will be restored to their original or equivalent position with equivalent pay, benefits, and other terms and conditions of employment, as detailed in Section 3.6 ("Return from Leave").

Policy text:
**Veridian Dynamics Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks (California Employees Only)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

It is the policy of Veridian Dynamics to comply with all applicable California labor laws regarding meal and rest breaks for our valued California employees. This policy applies exclusively to employees physically working within the state of California, and this policy should be read in conjunction with Section 2.1 ("Employee Classifications") of this handbook to determine applicability. This policy supersedes any previous Veridian Dynamics policies related to meal and rest breaks for California employees.

**3.4.1 Meal Breaks**

All non-exempt employees in California are entitled to a duty-free meal break of at least thirty (30) minutes when their total daily work period is more than five (5) hours. Unless explicitly waived in accordance with California Labor Code Section 512, a second duty-free meal break of at least thirty (30) minutes is required if the employee works more than ten (10) hours in a workday. However, employees working less than six (6) hours, while still non-exempt, may be exempt from this thirty-minute meal break as specified by California state law. Such employees should consult their managers to determine applicability. As per California regulations, in the event that an employee works between five and six hours, a written agreement may specify the rules for waiving such a meal break. Veridian Dynamics may face penalties as provided by law for failing to provide employees with required meal breaks. Veridian Dynamics also does not tolerate employees taking unauthorized breaks, and may take corrective actions.

**3.4.2 Rest Breaks**

Non-exempt California employees are generally entitled to a paid rest period of at least ten (10) minutes for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof, during the workday. Rest breaks, to the extent feasible, should be taken in the middle of each work period.

**3.4.3 Enforcement**

Veridian Dynamics strives to adhere to the requirements of California law. In the event of a missed, shortened, or interrupted meal or rest break, employees should immediately notify their supervisor.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Workforce Restructuring and Reductions in Force**
**Revision Date: 2024-01-05**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-15**

This policy outlines the procedures Acme Corp will follow in the event of a workforce restructuring that includes reductions in force (RIF). Acme Corp is committed to treating all employees with respect and dignity throughout any restructuring process.

**3.12.A: Federal WARN Act Compliance**

Acme Corp adheres to the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act (29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq.) at the federal level. The WARN Act mandates that covered employers provide 60 calendar days advance written notice to employees in the event of a plant closing or mass layoff.

For the purposes of this policy and in accordance with federal regulations, a "plant closing" refers to the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding any part-time employees.

A "mass layoff," as defined under this policy, means a reduction in force that is not the result of a plant closing, but results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for (A) 50 or more employees and that constitutes 33 percent of the employees at the single site of employment, or (B) 500 or more employees. Note that this policy only covers layoff events when the employer.employee_count is greater than or equal to 100. Therefore, if Acme Corp's employer.employee_count is less than 100, this policy does not apply. If an employee's location_state is in California, it is acknowledged that more stringent regulations may apply, however, Acme Corp will only comply with federal WARN guidelines as outlined above. The decision regarding whether a layoff constitutes a "mass layoff" will be made in good faith, considering all available data and consulting with legal counsel as needed.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck Timing (California Employees Only)**

**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01
**Revision Number:** 1.0

This policy outlines the procedures for issuing final paychecks to employees separating from Acme Corp who are located in California. Because Acme Corp operates in multiple states, it's important to understand that this policy applies *only* to employees whose primary work location is in California. See Section 1.02 ("Geographic Scope of Policies") for clarification. Federal law generally dictates that final wages are due by the next regularly scheduled payday; however, California law provides stricter requirements.

For California-based employees whose employment ends involuntarily (e.g., termination or layoff), all earned wages, including accrued vacation time (see Section 3.07), must be made available for payment *immediately* at the time of termination. "Immediately" means wages are given to the employee at the time of separation or made available for pickup at the employee's regular work location, if reasonably feasible. If immediate payment is not feasible, wages must be mailed to the employee’s address of record, postmarked no later than 24 hours following the termination. If an employee resigns, the timing of the final paycheck depends on whether they provided at least 72 hours advance notice of their resignation. If an employee provides at least 72 hours of advance notice, their final paycheck will be available on their last day of employment. However, if an employee resigns without providing at least 72 hours advance notice, the final paycheck will be available within 72 hours of their last day of employment, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays. Please note that wages are usually paid on the 15th and last day of each month. Therefore, there might be a slight delay within the 72 hours to allow payroll to generate the checks, but we strive to comply with state law.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Leave Policies**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 1.2**

**3.4.2 Paid Family Leave (PFL) and Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

Acme Corp is committed to supporting our employees during significant life events. This section outlines our policy regarding Paid Family Leave (PFL) and the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA). Both laws may apply to you depending on your circumstances and location.

The Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) is a federal law that provides eligible employees with up to 12 weeks of *unpaid*, job-protected leave for certain family and medical reasons. FMLA applies to employers with 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of the employee's worksite. Reasons for leave include the birth or adoption of a child, to care for a seriously ill family member (child, spouse, or parent), or for your own serious health condition that makes you unable to perform the essential functions of your job. For more detailed information, refer to the official FMLA guidelines.

California Paid Family Leave (PFL) provides partial wage replacement benefits to eligible California employees who take time off work to bond with a new child (birth, adoption, or foster care placement) or to care for a seriously ill family member (child, spouse, parent, grandparent, grandchild, sibling, or registered domestic partner). If you work in California, contribute to California State Disability Insurance (SDI), and request leave for bonding with a new child, you are entitled to receive approximately 60-70% of your wages for up to 8 weeks through PFL. This benefit runs concurrently with any FMLA leave to which you are otherwise entitled. Please see Section 3.4.3 for short-term disability information.

Policy text:
**Veridian Dynamics Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.7: Workforce Reductions and WARN Act Compliance**
**Revision:** 1.2
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01

Veridian Dynamics is committed to complying with all applicable laws regarding workforce reductions, including the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, both federal and California’s version. This policy applies exclusively to employees whose primary work location is within the state of California.

In the event of a plant closure, mass layoff, or relocation that affects employees in California, Veridian Dynamics will provide advance written notice. Now, this notice is required if the event involves 50 or more employees at a single site of employment within a 30-day period. However, the need to provide notice also depends on the employer size. For California employees, if Veridian Dynamics employs 75 or more employees, not counting part-time employees, then this entire policy applies. The notice must be provided to affected employees (or their union representative, if applicable) at least 60 calendar days before the date of separation. If Veridian Dynamics does not employ at least 75 people, then this section does not apply. Veridian Dynamics strives to provide as much advance notice as possible. For events affecting fewer than 50 employees at a single site of employment, while not mandated, Veridian Dynamics managers should attempt to provide notice where feasible. See Section 1.2 ("Definitions") for site of employment definition and Section 3.8 ("Voluntary Separation") for alternative options. Nothing in this policy creates any contractual rights. Veridian Dynamic retains the right to terminate employment at any time.

Policy text:
**High Sierra Technologies - Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks (California Employees)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

3.4.1 Purpose. This section details High Sierra Technologies' policy regarding meal and rest breaks for its employees working in the State of California, pursuant to California Labor Code Sections 226.7 and 512. This policy is designed to ensure compliance with California law and to provide employees with necessary break periods during their work shifts. This policy specifically applies to all non-exempt employees of High Sierra Technologies who are working within the geographical boundaries of the State of California.

3.4.2 Meal Breaks. Non-exempt employees working shifts longer than five (5) hours shall be provided with a duty-free meal period of not less than thirty (30) minutes. The meal period should commence no later than the end of the employee’s fifth (5th) hour of work. A second meal period of not less than thirty (30) minutes shall be provided to non-exempt employees working shifts longer than ten (10) hours. The second meal period must commence no later than the end of the employee’s tenth (10th) hour of work. Employees are required to accurately record their meal periods.

3.4.3 Rest Breaks. Non-exempt employees are entitled to a paid rest period of ten (10) minutes for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest periods should, to the extent practicable, be taken in the middle of each four-hour work period.

3.4.4 Failure to Comply. High Sierra Technologies is committed to full compliance with California Labor Code requirements. Should High Sierra Technologies fail to provide a required meal or rest period, employees are entitled to one (1) hour of premium pay for each workday that the meal or rest period is not provided. This premium pay constitutes full compensation for the missed break.

3.4.5 Termination for Repeated Violations. Notwithstanding the foregoing, and consistent with Section 7.2 (Termination of Employment) of this Handbook, if an employee repeatedly, and without reasonable justification, fails to take required meal or rest breaks despite being provided the opportunity, and if such failure results in the Company being subject to penalties under California Law, that employee's employment may be subject to termination. For purposes of this section, "repeatedly" shall mean more than three (3) instances within a twelve (12) month period.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

This policy outlines Acme Corp.'s procedures for issuing final paychecks to employees whose employment ends with the company. This policy adheres to all applicable federal laws and regulations regarding wage payments. State laws may differ. Please note that this policy does not create any contractual rights. Acme Corp. reserves the right to modify or terminate this policy at any time, with or without notice.

Final paychecks include all earned but unpaid wages, including salary, hourly pay, accrued and unused vacation time (if applicable per Acme Corp. policy 4.01: Vacation Accrual and Usage), and any other compensation owed to the employee. Deductions will be made for applicable federal and state taxes, as well as any voluntary deductions authorized by the employee.

**Timing of Final Paycheck:**

Acme Corp. will issue the final paycheck to all terminated, resigned, or laid-off employees on the next regularly scheduled payday following the employee’s last day of work. Regardless of whether the employee is classified as exempt or non-exempt, or the reason for the employment ending, if an employee’s employment status changes to terminated, resigned, or laid_off, Acme Corp. will provide the final paycheck on the next regularly scheduled payday. This policy applies to all Acme Corp. employees located within the United States and is compliant with federal law.

Employees with questions regarding their final paycheck should contact the Human Resources Department.

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics, Inc. – Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Policy 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**
**Revision:** 1.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01

3.  12.  1 Purpose
This policy outlines Sterling Dynamics, Inc.’s (the “Company”) procedures for workforce reductions, including layoffs, plant closures, and relocations, to ensure compliance with the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN Act), 29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq. This policy applies to all employees of Sterling Dynamics, Inc. throughout the United States.

4.  12.  2 WARN Act Notice Requirements

Notwithstanding any other provision of this Policy or any other Company policy, Sterling Dynamics, Inc. shall provide sixty (60) calendar days advance written notice of any plant closing or mass layoff to affected employees, their representatives (if any), the State dislocated worker unit, and the chief elected official of the local government. For the purposes of this policy, a "mass layoff" is defined as a reduction in force, other than a plant closing, which results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding any employees who are part-time employees as defined under the federal WARN Act. "Plant closing" means the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding any employees who are part-time employees as defined under the federal WARN Act. This Policy applies only if employer.employee_count is greater than 100. The Company will make reasonable efforts to provide notice as early as possible when unforeseen circumstances prevent the full 60-day notice. Failure to comply with this policy may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination.

5.  12.  3 Exceptions

This policy does not create any contractual rights, express or implied, and may be modified or terminated at any time, with or without notice.

Policy text:
**Starlight Industries Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.7: Final Paycheck Disbursement**
*Revision 1.2*
*Effective Date: 2024-07-01*

Starlight Industries is committed to ensuring timely and accurate payment of all wages to its employees in accordance with applicable federal law. This section outlines the policy regarding the disbursement of final paychecks. The procedures described herein apply to all Starlight Industries employees within the United States.

Generally, and subject to the conditions outlined below, an employee’s final paycheck, which includes all accrued but unused vacation time as detailed in Section 5.2 (Vacation and Paid Time Off), will be issued on the next regularly scheduled payday following the employee's termination date. However, in cases of involuntary termination where the employee’s last day of work falls within three (3) business days of the next scheduled payday, every effort will be made to provide the final paycheck on the employee’s last day of work. This may be subject to administrative processing limitations. If an employee voluntarily resigns their position, and provides at least two (2) weeks' notice of their intent to resign, their final paycheck will also be issued on the next regular payday. Employees who resign without providing at least two weeks' notice may experience a delay in receiving their final paycheck, but it will be issued no later than the subsequent regular payday, contingent upon the return of all company property as specified in Section 8.1 (Company Property). In the event of any discrepancies, employees should immediately contact the Human Resources department for clarification. Nothing in this policy should be interpreted to supersede or conflict with applicable law, and where such conflict exists, applicable law shall control.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook**
**Section 5.0: Leave Policies**
**5.2 Paid Family Leave and Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision Number: 1.0**

Acme Corp. is committed to supporting its employees during significant life events. This section outlines our policies regarding Paid Family Leave (PFL) and the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA).

**5.2.1 California Paid Family Leave (PFL)**

Employees who contribute to California State Disability Insurance (SDI) are eligible for California Paid Family Leave (PFL) benefits. PFL provides partial wage replacement benefits for up to eight (8) weeks to employees who take time off work to:

*   Bond with a new child (birth, adoption, or foster care placement)
*   Care for a seriously ill family member (child, parent, spouse, registered domestic partner, grandparent, grandchild, or sibling).

The wage replacement benefit is typically 60-70% of the employee's usual wages, subject to state-mandated limits. PFL is administered by the California Employment Development Department (EDD). Please refer to the EDD website (www.edd.ca.gov) for detailed information on eligibility requirements and benefit amounts.

**5.2.2 Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

The Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) provides eligible employees with up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave per 12-month period for certain family and medical reasons. Acme Corp. adheres to all requirements under the FMLA. To be eligible for FMLA leave, an employee must:

*   Have been employed by Acme Corp. for at least 12 months (which need not be consecutive);
*   Have worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period immediately preceding the commencement of leave; and
*   Be employed at a worksite where Acme Corp. employs 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius.

FMLA leave may be taken for the following reasons:

*   Birth of a child and to bond with the newborn child within one year of birth;
*   Placement with the employee of a child for adoption or foster care and to bond with the newly placed child within one year of placement;
*   To care for the employee’s spouse, child, or parent who has a serious health condition;
*   A serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the essential functions of his or her job;
*   Any qualifying exigency arising out of the fact that the employee’s spouse, son, daughter, or parent is a covered military member on active duty (or has been notified of an impending call or order to active duty) in the Armed Forces.

**5.2.3 Coordinating PFL and FMLA**

Employees eligible for both PFL and FMLA may take both leaves concurrently where the qualifying reasons overlap (e.g., bonding with a new child in California). In situations where an employee in the state of California has been terminated from Acme Corp, and the employee's tenure was under 12 months, the employee is ineligible to apply for FMLA. In such cases, the employee should not be granted FMLA leave.

**5.2.4 Return to Work**

Upon returning from PFL or FMLA leave, employees are generally entitled to be restored to their original job or to an equivalent job with equivalent pay, benefits, and other terms and conditions of employment.

Employees should consult with HR for specific guidance on leave eligibility and coordination.

Policy text:
**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks**

**3.4.1 Policy Overview**

This section outlines GoodCorp’s policy regarding meal and rest breaks for all employees. This policy is intended to comply with both applicable federal and state laws. Where federal and state laws differ, GoodCorp will adhere to the law that provides the greater benefit or protection to the employee.

**3.4.2 California Employees**

Notwithstanding Section 3.4.3, for employees working in California, the following provisions shall apply. Pursuant to California Labor Code Sections 226.7 and 512, all non-exempt employees working shifts exceeding five (5) hours shall be provided with a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal period. Said meal period must commence before the end of the employee’s fifth (5th) hour of work. A second thirty (30) minute unpaid meal period is required if the employee works more than ten (10) hours in a workday, to commence before the end of the employee’s tenth (10th) hour of work. Further, for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof, non-exempt employees are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest period. Rest periods shall be scheduled, where feasible, in the middle of each four-hour work period. Non-exempt employees who are required to work through a compliant meal or rest break will be paid one (1) hour of premium pay for each day where one or more meal or rest breaks are missed. Employees that are classified as exempt are not entitled to meal or rest breaks under this section.

**3.4.3 Employees Outside of California**

For employees located outside of California, while federal law does not mandate meal or rest breaks, GoodCorp provides a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break for any employee working more than six (6) consecutive hours, provided that the employee is completely relieved of all duties during the break. Shorter breaks, up to twenty (20) minutes, provided during the workday will be treated as paid time.

**3.4.4 Recordkeeping**

Accurate recordkeeping of meal and rest breaks is essential to ensure compliance. Employees are responsible for accurately recording their meal periods in the timekeeping system. Any issues regarding break times should be immediately reported to the employee’s supervisor. Refer to Policy 5.2 regarding timekeeping procedures.

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamic Solutions Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks (California Employees)**
**Revision Date: 2024-01-01**

This policy outlines Sterling Dynamic Solutions' approach to meal and rest breaks for our valued employees working in the state of California. This policy is designed to ensure compliance with California state law. It is the employee's responsibility to become familiar with these rules and manage their work accordingly. For any conflict between this policy and California law, California law prevails.

**3.4.1 Meal Breaks**

Employees working shifts longer than five (5) hours are entitled to a thirty (30)-minute unpaid meal break. This meal break should ideally be taken before the end of the fifth hour of work. If an employee works more than ten (10) hours in a workday, they are entitled to a second thirty (30)-minute unpaid meal break. Employees must be completely relieved of all duties during meal periods. Performing any work during a meal period, even minor tasks, violates this policy and California law. Supervisors are responsible for ensuring employees take their meal breaks.

**3.4.2 Rest Breaks**

California employees are entitled to a paid ten (10)-minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks must be taken in the middle of each work period, as near as is practicable.

**3.4.3 Missed Breaks**

Sterling Dynamic Solutions strives to provide employees with all required meal and rest breaks. If an employee is unable to take a required meal or rest break due to business necessity, the employee must report this to their supervisor as soon as possible. In such instances, the company will comply with applicable California law, by paying the employee one hour of premium pay at the employee's regular rate of compensation for each workday that a required meal or rest period is not provided. However, if an employee's daily hours worked are less than 3.5 hours and their location_state is 'CA', then this one hour premium pay will not be provided. Please see section 3.5 "Overtime Pay" of this Handbook for details on calculating the regular rate of compensation.

Policy text:
**Apex Industries, Inc. - Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.7: Meal and Rest Breaks (Revision 1.2)**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**

3.7.1. *General Policy Regarding Breaks.* Apex Industries, Inc. recognizes the importance of providing employees with opportunities for rest and sustenance during their workdays. This policy aims to ensure compliance with all applicable federal laws regarding breaks, notwithstanding any interpretations to the contrary.

3.7.2. *Meal Breaks.* Unless explicitly dictated otherwise by an applicable collective bargaining agreement to which Apex Industries, Inc. is a party, for all employees, regardless of pay type or hours worked weekly, a meal period of at least thirty (30) minutes will be provided. However, this requirement applies only if the employee's shift duration is greater than five (5) consecutive hours and the employee is fully relieved of all duties during such thirty (30) minute period. The aforementioned meal period is considered unpaid time. Specifically, if an employee whose employment status is 'active' and whose shift_hours is greater than 5, and whose tenure_months is greater than three months, is entitled to a meal break. This entitlement shall be conditional on said employee's affirmation, in writing, that they understand that failure to take such break, or the taking of such break while performing work-related duties, will be considered a violation of company policy and may subject the employee to disciplinary action, up to and including termination, notwithstanding any other provision of this Employee Handbook. Employees shall be responsible for tracking their own meal breaks via the company's timekeeping system.

3.7.3. *Rest Breaks.* Apex Industries, Inc. provides paid rest breaks in accordance with federal regulations, specifically ensuring that any breaks of less than twenty minutes are considered work time and compensated accordingly.

3.7.4. *Policy Interpretation.* This policy shall be interpreted in accordance with applicable federal laws and regulations. In the event of any conflict between this policy and applicable federal law, federal law shall govern.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated - Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

This policy applies to all Sterling Consolidated employees working within the state of California. It is designed to comply with California Labor Code Sections 226.7 and 512, and related regulations. While federal law does not mandate meal or rest breaks for adult employees, Sterling Consolidated is committed to providing legally required breaks to its California workforce.

**3.4.1 Meal Breaks**

All non-exempt employees who work more than five (5) hours in a workday are entitled to a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. The meal break should commence no later than the end of the employee's fifth (5th) hour of work. If a non-exempt employee works more than ten (10) hours in a workday, they are entitled to a second thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. This second meal period shall commence no later than the end of the employee's tenth (10th) hour of work. Employees must be completely relieved of all duties during their meal break. If an employee is not relieved of all duties during their meal break, it is considered a missed meal break, which triggers premium pay as outlined in section 3.4.3.

**3.4.2 Rest Breaks**

Non-exempt employees are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks should be taken as near to the midpoint of the work period as possible. To clarify, an employee working 3.5 hours is eligible for a rest break.

**3.4.3 Premium Pay for Missed Breaks**

Sterling Consolidated recognizes its obligation to provide required meal and rest breaks. If a non-exempt employee is not provided with a meal or rest break that complies with California law, the employee shall be paid one (1) hour of pay at their regular rate of compensation for each workday that the meal or rest break is not provided. However, if an employee’s shift is less than six hours and their hours worked daily is less than 5.5 hours, Sterling Consolidated is not required to provide a meal break, even if the employee is classified as non-exempt and working in California.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Workforce Adjustments and Layoff Notification**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

Acme Corp is committed to treating its employees fairly and with respect during periods of workforce adjustment. This policy outlines the company's approach to layoff notification, aligning with applicable federal regulations, specifically the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN Act).

In the unfortunate event that Acme Corp must conduct a mass layoff, it is our policy to provide advance written notice to affected employees. However, providing such notice is only triggered based on the aggregate circumstances of the event in question, and provided further that these circumstances are within our direct control. Notice is required only if a mass layoff, as defined under the federal WARN Act (29 U.S.C. § 2101), is anticipated. For the purposes of this policy, a "mass layoff" is defined as a reduction in force, not resulting from a plant closing, which results in an employment loss at a single site of employment during any 30-day period for at least 50 employees who constitute at least 33% of the employees (excluding part-time employees) at the single site of employment, or 500 or more employees.

Therefore, in situations where *Acme Corp's* total employee count is greater than 100, and a layoff affecting at least 50 employees is anticipated, Acme Corp will provide those employees with a minimum of 60 days' written notice, unless unforeseen business circumstances prevent such advance notice, as defined in Section 3.13, Emergency Exceptions. All notifications must be issued in accordance with the regulations stipulated under the WARN Act. Compliance with the WARN Act is crucial, but this policy should not be interpreted as creating any contractual rights beyond those already provided by law. The determination of whether a layoff constitutes a mass layoff under the Act will be made by the Legal Department, in consultation with HR, considering the totality of circumstances.

Policy text:
**XYZ Corp Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck Disbursement**
**Revision Number:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01

This section outlines the procedures for the disbursement of final paychecks to employees upon separation from XYZ Corp. The policies outlined herein are governed by applicable federal laws.

**3.12.1 Timing of Final Paycheck**

Generally, employees separating from XYZ Corp, regardless of whether the separation is voluntary or involuntary, will receive their final paycheck, including all earned but unpaid wages, no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following their date of separation. This applies to all employees employed across the United States, subject to the condition that the employee has properly submitted all required paperwork to Human Resources, as detailed in Section 6.2 (Employee Separation Procedures).

However, in cases of involuntary termination, where an employee is terminated for cause as defined in Section 4.5 (Disciplinary Action), the final paycheck may be issued within a reasonable timeframe, not to exceed two (2) weeks from the date of termination, provided the Human Resources Department has completed a final audit of all time records and expense reports. Further, for employees classified as non-exempt who resign without providing at least two (2) weeks' written notice to their supervisor, as outlined in Section 6.1 (Voluntary Resignation), the final paycheck will be issued on the next regularly scheduled payday. All policies are subject to federal wage and hour laws. For further clarification or any questions, please contact your Human Resources representative.

Policy text:
**Northwind Traders Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**

**Revision Number:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** January 1, 2024

3.  12.1 Purpose: This policy outlines Northwind Traders' obligations under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act (29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq.), hereinafter referred to as the "Act," to provide advance notice of certain plant closings and mass layoffs. This policy is intended to ensure compliance with the Act and to minimize disruption to affected employees.

4.  12.2 Scope: This policy applies to all Northwind Traders employees throughout the United States. It is the responsibility of all managers and supervisors to adhere to the requirements outlined herein.

5.  12.  3 Definitions:

    *   "Plant Closing" shall mean the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding any part-time employees.

    *   "Mass Layoff" shall mean a reduction in force which is not the result of a plant closing, but which results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees and those employees constitute at least 33% of the employees at that site, or 500 or more employees, excluding any part-time employees.

6.  12.4 Notice Requirements: Northwind Traders shall provide written notice of a plant closing or mass layoff to affected employees, the chief elected official of the unit of local government within which the employment site is located, and the State dislocated worker unit, at least 60 calendar days prior to the date of the plant closing or mass layoff, if the employer.employee_count is greater than or equal to 100. The notice shall contain all information required by the Act, including the expected date of the first separation and the expected duration of the layoff.

7.  12.  5 Exceptions: This policy shall be interpreted consistent with the provisions of the WARN Act.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp - Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Workforce Reductions and the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act**

**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01
**Revision:** 1.0

Acme Corp is committed to treating its employees with respect and consideration during periods of workforce reduction. The Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act is a federal law designed to protect workers, their families, and communities by requiring employers to provide notification 60 calendar days in advance of plant closings and mass layoffs. This policy outlines Acme Corp's obligations under the federal WARN Act. Note this policy adheres only to the federal requirements, and does not provide additional or differing requirements of any state.

**3.12.1 WARN Act Notification Requirements**

Acme Corp will provide advance written notice of a plant closing or mass layoff as required by the federal WARN Act. A *plant closing* is defined as the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding any part-time employees. A *mass layoff* is defined as a reduction in force which is not the result of a plant closing, but results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees and represents at least 33% of the employees at the single site of employment, excluding any part-time employees, or 500 or more employees are affected regardless of percentage. For the purposes of this policy, *employment loss* means (1) an employment termination, other than a discharge for cause, voluntary departure, or retirement; (2) a layoff exceeding 6 months; or (3) a reduction in hours of work of more than 50 percent during each month of any 6-month period.

Therefore, Acme Corp will notify affected employees 60 calendar days in advance of a mass layoff if the number of affected employees in that mass layoff is greater than or equal to 50 and also represents at least 33% of the employees at the single site of employment, OR the number of affected employees is greater than or equal to 500, given the employer has 100 or more employees.

**3.12.2 Notice Content**

The WARN notice will include, but is not limited to, the following information: the name and address of the employment site where the plant closing or mass layoff will occur; the nature of the planned action; the expected date of the first separation; a statement as to whether the planned action is expected to be permanent or temporary; the job titles of positions to be affected and the number of affected employees in each job classification; and contact information for company officials to contact for further information.

**3.12.3 Exceptions**

[Further exceptions would be detailed here, such as unforeseen business circumstances, natural disaster exceptions, etc. - not included as requested]

Policy text:
**ABC Corp Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck Distribution**
**Revision Number: 2.0**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**

3.  1.  Final wages owed to employees of ABC Corp shall be disbursed in accordance with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), 29 U.S. Code § 201 et seq., and the regulations promulgated thereunder. Notwithstanding any other provision within this policy, final paychecks for terminated employees, whether such termination is voluntary or involuntary, will be processed and distributed no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following the date of termination. Employees classified as exempt under the FLSA who are involuntarily terminated will receive their final paycheck within two regular pay cycles, provided that all company property, including but not limited to laptops, mobile phones, and access badges, have been returned to the company within one week of the employee's last day of employment. Failure to return company property as specified may result in a delay in the issuance of the final paycheck, but in no instance shall the delay extend beyond the subsequent regular payday. If an employee resigns from ABC Corp, the final wages will be paid on the next regular payday regardless of whether notice was given. It is the employee's responsibility to provide a forwarding address to ABC Corp's Human Resources department. If an employee's employment status changes from active to terminated or laid_off, ABC Corp will mail the final paycheck to the employee's last known address. All final paychecks will include a detailed itemization of all wages paid, including regular wages, overtime pay, and any accrued vacation time, less applicable deductions for taxes, insurance premiums, and other authorized deductions as per company policy 3.09 and any applicable wage garnishments.

Policy text:
**DeltaTech Solutions, Inc. - Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 6.0: Leave Policies**

**Policy 6.2: Family and Medical Leave**

**6.2.1 General Provisions**

This policy outlines DeltaTech Solutions, Inc.'s compliance with both the federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) and the California Paid Family Leave (PFL) program for eligible employees in California. This policy is effective as of January 1, 2025, and supersedes any prior policies concerning family and medical leave. This policy is subject to change without notice, and DeltaTech Solutions, Inc. reserves the right to amend or terminate this policy at any time, consistent with applicable law. For purposes of this policy, "family member" shall be defined as spouse, domestic partner, child, parent, parent-in-law, grandparent, grandchild, or sibling.

**6.2.2 California Paid Family Leave (PFL) and FMLA Interaction**

Eligible employees working in California who contribute to California State Disability Insurance (SDI) may be entitled to California Paid Family Leave (PFL) benefits administered by the California Employment Development Department (EDD) pursuant to California Unemployment Insurance Code Sections 3300 et seq. PFL provides partial wage replacement benefits, currently sixty (60) to seventy (70) percent of wages, up to a maximum weekly benefit amount as determined by the EDD, for up to eight (8) weeks for the purpose of bonding with a new child or caring for a seriously ill family member. An employee *shall* be eligible for PFL if *all* of the following are true: the employee.location_state is 'CA', the employee.sdi_contributor is true, and leave.type is either 'bonding' or 'caregiver', then the employee is eligible to receive wage replacement benefits as defined by the state of California PFL law, subject to EDD eligibility determination. Employees taking PFL concurrently with FMLA leave will receive job protection under FMLA to the extent they are otherwise eligible. Employees should consult the EDD website (www.edd.ca.gov) for the most current information and to file a claim. This policy does not create any entitlement to PFL benefits beyond those provided by California law.

**6.2.3 Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

(The remainder of this section will detail FMLA provisions, but is not relevant to the specified prompt and will be omitted to save space).

Policy text:
**Golden Gate Technologies - Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.4: Leave Policies (Revised 2.0, Effective 2024-07-01)**

This section outlines Golden Gate Technologies' policies regarding employee leave. All policies described below are subject to change without notice and are governed by applicable federal, state, and local laws. Where inconsistencies exist between this policy and applicable law, the law governs.

**3.4.2 Paid Family Leave (California)**

Golden Gate Technologies supports California employees who need time off for qualifying family reasons. California's Paid Family Leave (PFL) program, administered by the Employment Development Department (EDD), provides partial wage replacement benefits to eligible employees who take time off work to care for a seriously ill family member or to bond with a new child.

Eligibility for PFL benefits is generally determined by the EDD and is based on whether an employee pays into State Disability Insurance (SDI). Employees who contribute to SDI are likely eligible. If a California employee's tenure is greater than 12 months AND they have worked at least 1250 hours in the preceding 12-month period, they *may* also be eligible for Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) leave, which runs concurrently with PFL. However, while FMLA provides job protection, it is typically unpaid. An employee taking leave for these reasons *shall* be granted PFL. However, for employees who *do not* pay into SDI, approval of an extended leave of absence is at the sole discretion of Human Resources, considering factors such as business needs and the employee's performance history, and this approval does *not* guarantee job protection. The maximum leave duration under PFL, as dictated by state law, is currently eight (8) weeks within a 12-month period, with wage replacement paid at approximately 60-70% of the employee's normal wages, subject to EDD calculations. Details regarding filing a PFL claim can be found on the EDD website (www.edd.ca.gov). Please note that using PFL does not necessarily protect your job; job protection is governed by other applicable laws such as FMLA and the California Family Rights Act (CFRA).

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics, Inc. – Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation (California Employees Only)**

**Revision 1.0 – Effective Date: 2024-01-01**

3.2.1. **Eligibility:** This section pertains exclusively to non-exempt employees of Sterling Dynamics, Inc. whose primary work location is within the State of California, as defined in Section 1.4 (Definitions). For the avoidance of doubt, this policy does not apply to employees whose work location is outside of California, notwithstanding their occasional travel to California for business purposes.

3.2.2. **Overtime Rate:** Subject to the provisions detailed herein, non-exempt employees in California shall be compensated for overtime hours worked. "Overtime hours" are defined as hours worked in excess of eight (8) hours in a single workday or forty (40) hours in a single workweek. The rate of overtime pay shall be one and one-half (1.5) times the employee's regular rate of pay, pursuant to California Labor Code Section 510, unless otherwise specified below.

3.2.3. **Daily and Weekly Overtime:** Notwithstanding the foregoing, should an employee work more than twelve (12) hours in a single workday, they shall be compensated at a rate of two (2) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked beyond the twelfth hour in that workday. Furthermore, if a non-exempt employee works more than eight (8) hours on their seventh consecutive day of work in a workweek, compensation for hours exceeding eight (8) shall be calculated at two (2) times their regular rate of pay. The determination of whether the employee is subject to California's overtime regulations will be based solely on their primary work location, irrespective of the location of the project or client they are assigned to. However, should an employee's classification change to exempt status pursuant to California law and this policy, the provisions outlined in this section shall no longer apply.

3.2.4. **Payment:** Overtime compensation shall be included in the employee's regular paycheck for the pay period during which the overtime hours were worked, in accordance with California Labor Code Section 204. Questions regarding overtime eligibility or calculation should be directed to the HR department.

Policy text:
**Section 3.09: Paid Family Leave and Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) Policy**

**3.09.1 General Provisions**

Effective Date: 2024-01-01. Revision Number: 1.2

It is the policy of Apex Solutions, Inc. to provide eligible employees with leave benefits in accordance with both the California Paid Family Leave (PFL) program and the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) of 1993, as amended. In circumstances where an employee is eligible for both PFL and FMLA, the leave entitlements shall run concurrently, to the maximum extent permitted by law. However, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, eligibility for continued employment with Apex Solutions, Inc. under this Section is explicitly contingent upon full compliance with Section 2.12 regarding employee conduct and performance expectations, as determined in the sole discretion of the Company.

**3.09.2 California Paid Family Leave (PFL)**

Pursuant to California Unemployment Insurance Code Sections 3300 et seq., employees who contribute to California State Disability Insurance (SDI) shall be eligible for up to eight (8) weeks of partial wage replacement benefits, calculated at approximately sixty percent (60%) to seventy percent (70%) of their regular earnings, while taking leave to bond with a new child or to care for a seriously ill family member, as defined by California law. Benefits are administered directly by the California Employment Development Department (EDD), and the employee’s continued employment with Apex Solutions, Inc. is subject to the employee not having any active performance improvement plans at the commencement of the leave, such performance plan having been initiated prior to the employee's notification of planned leave, and employee providing Apex Solutions, Inc. with medical documentation. Any employee found to be in violation of this, as determined by Apex Solutions in its reasonable discretion, will be terminated.

**3.09.3 Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

Eligible employees, as defined by the FMLA, are entitled to up to twelve (12) weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave for qualifying reasons, including the birth or adoption of a child, to care for a seriously ill family member, or for the employee’s own serious health condition. Eligibility for FMLA leave requires that the employee has been employed by Apex Solutions, Inc. for at least twelve (12) months and has worked at least 1,250 hours in the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding the leave. Apex Solutions, Inc. adheres to the FMLA regulations concerning employee eligibility and reinstatement rights.
