Policy text:
**Globex Corporation Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.12: Family and Medical Leave Policy (FMLA)**
**Revision 2.0**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**

Globex Corporation is committed to supporting our employees during times of significant family or medical need. This policy outlines our compliance with the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), a federal law that provides eligible employees with unpaid, job-protected leave for specified family and medical reasons.

**3.12.1 Eligibility**

To be eligible for FMLA leave, an employee must meet the following criteria:

*   Have been employed by Globex Corporation for at least 12 months (which need not be consecutive); and
*   Have worked for Globex Corporation for at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period immediately preceding the start of the leave; and
*   Be employed at a worksite where Globex Corporation employs 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius.

**3.12.2 Leave Entitlement**

Eligible employees are entitled to up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave during any 12-month period for one or more of the following reasons:

*   The birth of a child and to bond with the newborn child within one year of birth;
*   The placement with the employee of a child for adoption or foster care and to bond with the newly placed child within one year of placement;
*   To care for the employee's spouse, child, or parent who has a serious health condition;
*   A serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the essential functions of his or her job;
*   Any qualifying exigency arising out of the fact that the employee's spouse, son, daughter, or parent is a covered military member on active duty (or has been notified of an impending call or order to active duty) in the Armed Forces.

**3.12.3 Certification and Notice**

Employees requesting FMLA leave are required to provide appropriate certification from a health care provider to support the need for leave due to a serious health condition, or documentation supporting the need for leave related to military family leave. Employees must provide 30 days' advance notice when the need for leave is foreseeable. If 30 days' notice is not practicable, such as in cases of medical emergencies, the employee must provide notice as soon as practicable.
Globex Corporation may delay or deny FMLA leave if an employee fails to provide timely notice or certification.

If an employee has worked less than 1250 hours in the past 12 months, they will not be granted FMLA leave.
This FMLA policy is intended to comply with federal law only and does not provide any additional state-specific benefits or protections. Refer to Section 3.15 regarding company-specific short-term and long-term disability benefits.

Policy text:
**Synergistic Solutions Inc. - Employee Handbook - Section 3.12: Family and Medical Leave (Revised 07/01/2024)**

Synergistic Solutions Inc. is committed to supporting our employees' needs to balance their work and personal lives. This policy outlines the requirements for Family and Medical Leave (FMLA) and California Paid Family Leave (PFL). Eligibility for both FMLA and PFL may run concurrently where applicable.

**3.12.1 Federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

Eligible employees may be granted up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave in a 12-month period for qualifying reasons, as defined under the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993. To be eligible for FMLA, an employee must have been employed by Synergistic Solutions Inc. for at least 12 months and have worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period immediately preceding the leave. Furthermore, FMLA only applies to sites with 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius. Leave may be taken for the birth and care of a newborn child, placement of a child for adoption or foster care, to care for a spouse, child, or parent with a serious health condition, or for a serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the functions of the employee's job. Please refer to Appendix A for the full definition of "serious health condition."

**3.12.2 California Paid Family Leave (PFL)**

California employees who contribute to State Disability Insurance (SDI) may be eligible for California Paid Family Leave (PFL). PFL provides partial wage replacement benefits for up to eight (8) weeks when taking time off to bond with a new child or to care for a seriously ill family member (child, spouse, parent, grandparent, grandchild, sibling, or registered domestic partner). The wage replacement rate is currently 60-70% of the employee's wages. This policy does not create an independent entitlement to leave, and the availability of PFL benefits is contingent on meeting the requirements set forth by the California Employment Development Department (EDD). While FMLA leave is unpaid, employees may be eligible to receive PFL benefits concurrently with their FMLA leave, provided they meet the eligibility requirements for both. Employees who are not eligible for FMLA due to employer size (fewer than 50 employees within 75 miles) but do contribute to SDI may still be eligible for PFL benefits.

Policy text:
**Veridian Dynamics Employee Handbook – Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks**
*Effective Date: 2024-01-01, Revision 2.0*

This policy outlines Veridian Dynamics' approach to meal and rest breaks, ensuring compliance with both federal and state regulations. This policy applies to all employees working in the United States.

**3.4.1 General Principles:**

Veridian Dynamics is committed to providing employees with legally required meal and rest breaks. To ensure a productive and healthy work environment, we adhere to the following guidelines. The details of these guidelines depend on the laws of the jurisdiction where the employee works. Please consult with HR if you have any questions.

**3.4.2 Federal Regulations:**

Under federal law, Veridian Dynamics is not required to provide meal or rest breaks to adult employees. However, when provided, any breaks shorter than 20 minutes are counted as hours worked and must be paid. Meal periods (typically 30 minutes or more) do not need to be compensated when the employee is completely relieved of all job duties during the break.

**3.4.3 California Regulations:**

For Veridian Dynamics employees working in California, the following regulations apply in addition to the federal regulations noted above:

*   **Meal Breaks:** Employees working more than five (5) hours in a workday are entitled to a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. Employees working more than ten (10) hours in a workday are entitled to a second thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. The meal break must commence before the end of the employee’s fifth (5th) hour of work, and the second meal break (if applicable) must commence before the end of the employee’s tenth (10th) hour of work. Employees are required to accurately record their meal breaks on their timesheets.

*   **Rest Breaks:** Employees are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks must be taken in the middle of each four (4) hour work period, as much as is practicable.

*   **Premium Pay for Missed Breaks:** Consistent with California law, if Veridian Dynamics does not provide an employee with a required meal or rest break, the employee will be paid one (1) hour of premium pay for each missed break.

**3.4.4 Policy Enforcement:**

Supervisors are responsible for ensuring that all employees, particularly those in California, have the opportunity to take their required meal and rest breaks. Employees are responsible for taking their breaks and accurately recording them on their timesheets. Willful failure to adhere to this policy can result in disciplinary action. Any employee who believes that they have been improperly denied a meal or rest break should report the matter immediately to their supervisor or Human Resources. The Company prohibits any retaliatory action against any employee who reports a violation or suspected violation of this policy. For more on reporting concerns, please refer to Section 5.2 of this handbook on Ethical Conduct.

**3.4.5 Exceptions**
Non-exempt Veridian Dynamics employees in California who work shifts longer than ten hours are eligible for a second 30 minute unpaid meal break.

Policy text:
**Evergreen Solutions Corp. – Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck Procedures**
**Revision Number:** 1.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01

This section outlines Evergreen Solutions Corp.’s policy regarding the timing of final paycheck distribution for employees whose employment with the company has ended. This policy is intended to comply with both federal and state regulations, and where conflicts arise, the more stringent regulation will apply.

*   **General Policy:** It is Evergreen Solutions Corp.'s policy to provide final paychecks to separating employees in a timely manner. The specific timing of the final paycheck distribution will depend on the reason for separation (termination, resignation, layoff), the employee’s location of employment, and any applicable state laws.

*   **California Employees:** Evergreen Solutions Corp. adheres to California Labor Code Sections 201 and 202 concerning final paychecks for employees working in California. If an employee is involuntarily terminated from Evergreen Solutions Corp. while working in California, their final paycheck, including all earned but unpaid wages, must be provided to them immediately upon termination. However, If an employee working outside California is involuntarily terminated, Evergreen Solutions Corp. will provide the final paycheck on the next regularly scheduled payday, as required by federal law. Employees should contact the Human Resources department with any questions regarding their final paycheck. Please refer to Section 2.15 for details on our standard payday schedule.

*   **Federal Compliance:** Evergreen Solutions Corp. will adhere to the requirements of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) regarding final paychecks for all employees, regardless of location. In general, federal law requires that final paychecks be issued no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following the employee's last day of employment.

Evergreen Solutions Corp. is committed to ensuring compliance with all applicable wage and hour laws. This policy is subject to change at any time, with or without notice.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**

**Section 3.7: Overtime Compensation**
**Revision Number:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01

**3.7.1 Overtime Eligibility**

This policy outlines the requirements for overtime compensation for non-exempt employees of Acme Corp. Overtime pay is governed by the federal Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). All employees are expected to accurately record all hours worked in the company’s timekeeping system, as detailed in Section 2.4: Timekeeping Procedures. Any falsification of time records will result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination.

**3.7.2 Overtime Compensation Rules**

Acme Corp strictly adheres to federal overtime regulations. Non-exempt employees will be compensated for all hours worked over 40 in a workweek at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay. For the purpose of calculating overtime, a workweek is defined as Sunday at 12:00 AM to Saturday at 11:59 PM. Hours worked in excess of 40 hours within this defined workweek will qualify for overtime compensation. Overtime must be pre-approved by the employee's direct supervisor. Working overtime without pre-approval may result in disciplinary action, as outlined in Section 5.1: Disciplinary Actions. Please direct any questions about overtime eligibility or calculation to your direct supervisor or the HR department. This policy applies to all Acme Corp employees within the United States.

**3.7.3 Overtime Approval**

Overtime must be approved by the employee's supervisor before it is worked, whenever possible.

**3.7.4 Rest Periods and Meal Breaks**

Please refer to Section 3.8 for Acme Corp's policies on rest periods and meal breaks.

Policy text:
**Skyline Dynamics Corporation – Employee Handbook**
**Section 4.0: Leave Policies**
**Policy 4.3: California Paid Family Leave (PFL) and Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 1.2**

Skyline Dynamics Corporation is committed to supporting our employees' needs for both family care and medical leave, while adhering to all applicable California and Federal laws. This policy outlines the provisions for California Paid Family Leave (PFL) and the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA).

**4.3.1 California Paid Family Leave (PFL)**

California employees who contribute to State Disability Insurance (SDI) are eligible for PFL benefits. PFL provides partial wage replacement benefits (approximately 60-70% of wages, subject to change based on state law) for up to eight (8) weeks within a twelve (12) month period. PFL can be used to bond with a new child (birth, adoption, or foster care placement) or to care for a seriously ill family member (child, parent, spouse, registered domestic partner, grandparent, grandchild, or sibling). Eligibility for PFL is determined by the California Employment Development Department (EDD), and employees must meet their criteria to qualify. Please refer to the EDD website ([invalid URL removed]) for comprehensive details regarding eligibility and benefit amounts.

**4.3.2 Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

Eligible employees are also covered under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), which provides up to twelve (12) weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave within a twelve (12) month period. To be eligible for FMLA, an employee must (a) have worked for Skyline Dynamics Corporation for at least twelve (12) months, and (b) have worked at least 1,250 hours during the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding the start of the leave. FMLA leave can be used for the birth or adoption of a child, to care for a seriously ill family member (child, parent, or spouse), or for the employee's own serious health condition. The determination of what constitutes a "serious health condition" will be based on federal regulations.

**4.3.3 Coordination of PFL and FMLA**
It is Skyline Dynamics Corporation’s policy to have PFL and FMLA run concurrently when the leave qualifies under both laws. However, should an employee take leave for bonding, and subsequent action is taken by the employee that results in termination within thirty (30) days of the end of said leave due to the employee having provided false information regarding their need for leave, then the employee may forfeit rights under both PFL and FMLA depending on the nature of the deception. See policy 6.2 regarding dishonesty, and how this affects terminations.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated - Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.7: Meal and Rest Breaks - Effective 2024-01-01 - Revision 3.1**

Sterling Consolidated is committed to complying with all applicable federal and state laws regarding employee meal and rest breaks. This policy outlines our requirements for providing such breaks. Employees are responsible for adhering to this policy and accurately recording their break times.

**General Policy:** All non-exempt employees are generally entitled to rest and meal breaks. The specific requirements vary depending on the state in which the employee works.

**California Employees:** In compliance with California law, non-exempt employees working shifts longer than five (5) hours are entitled to a thirty (30)-minute unpaid meal period. A second 30-minute meal period is required for non-exempt employees working shifts longer than ten (10) hours. Employees must be completely relieved of all duty during meal periods.

Additionally, California law mandates a paid ten (10)-minute rest period for every four (4) hours worked or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks must be counted as time worked. These rest periods should, to the extent practicable, be taken in the middle of each work period.

**Federal Considerations:** Federal law does not require meal or rest periods. However, any breaks of short duration (generally five (5) to twenty (20) minutes) offered to employees must be paid. Meal periods (typically thirty (30) minutes or longer) are generally not required to be paid, provided the employee is completely relieved of duty.

**Premium Pay for Missed Breaks:** It is Sterling Consolidated’s policy to provide compliant meal and rest breaks. However, if an employee is not provided with a compliant meal or rest period in accordance with California law, due to operational needs or other unforeseen circumstances, the employee may be entitled to one (1) hour of premium pay for each workday that the meal or rest period is not provided. If the employee’s shift is less than 3.5 hours, then the employee is not eligible to have a rest break provided as stated in the California Labor Code Section 512.

**Reporting Missed Breaks:** Any employee who believes they have been denied a compliant meal or rest break should immediately notify their supervisor and Human Resources. (See Section 5.2 – Complaint Procedures.) Failure to report missed breaks in a timely manner may affect the Company’s ability to investigate and resolve the issue.

**Policy Changes:** Sterling Consolidated reserves the right to modify this policy at any time. Employees will be notified of any changes.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.7: Overtime Compensation**

**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01
**Revision:** 2.0

Acme Corp is committed to complying with all applicable federal laws regarding employee compensation. This section outlines the company's policy on overtime pay for non-exempt employees. As a general rule, non-exempt employees are entitled to overtime pay for all hours worked over 40 in a single workweek. The calculation of overtime pay will be one and one-half (1.5) times the employee's regular rate of pay for each hour of overtime worked, as determined by the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA).

There are, however, some exceptions and clarifications to this rule. For example, if an employee's employment status is anything other than ‘active’ as defined in section 2.10, no overtime compensation will be provided. Furthermore, an employee must be on Acme Corp's payroll at the time overtime compensation is paid. Employees classified as ‘exempt’ under the FLSA are not eligible for overtime pay, regardless of the number of hours worked in a week. It is the employee's responsibility to accurately record all hours worked in the company's timekeeping system. Failure to do so may result in delays or inaccuracies in overtime pay calculations.

Specifically, for hourly non-exempt employees in good standing, Acme Corp will provide overtime pay at a rate of 1.5x their regular hourly rate when the employee's hours worked weekly exceeds 40, with consideration also given to section 4.2 regarding approved leave impacting overall workweek totals. This policy is intended to comply with all federal labor guidelines related to overtime, and applies to all employees regardless of where their work is physically performed. All calculations will be based on federal standards without regard to state or local laws.

Policy text:
**OptiCorp Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

This section outlines OptiCorp's policy regarding meal and rest breaks for all employees working within the United States. This policy is intended to comply with applicable federal laws and regulations.

**3.4.1 General Break Policy**

OptiCorp recognizes the importance of providing employees with adequate breaks during their workday. While federal law does not mandate meal or rest breaks for adult employees, OptiCorp provides breaks in accordance with the following guidelines:

*   **Rest Breaks:** Employees are permitted to take short, paid rest breaks during their work shift. These breaks are intended to allow employees to briefly step away from their work to refresh themselves.
*   **Meal Breaks:** Employees are permitted to take longer, unpaid meal breaks to eat a meal away from their workstation.

**3.4.2 Eligibility for Breaks**

As per federal law, OptiCorp does not require meal or rest breaks, but does permit employees to take them. If an employee works a shift that is six hours or longer, and employee.location_state is not California, OptiCorp permits the employee to take an unpaid meal break of at least 30 minutes in duration, during which the employee must be completely relieved of all duties. Please refer to Section 2.2, "Hours of Work," for additional information regarding overtime and scheduling. For questions regarding specific break schedules or needs, please contact your supervisor or the Human Resources Department. This policy is subject to change at any time, with or without notice.

**3.4.3 Recording Breaks**

It is the employee's responsibility to accurately record all meal and rest breaks taken, in accordance with company timekeeping procedures, as detailed in Section 4.5, "Timekeeping and Payroll." Failure to accurately record break times may result in disciplinary action.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**

**3.12.1 Purpose**

This policy outlines Acme Corp.'s requirements and procedures related to workforce reductions, including mass layoffs and plant closures, to ensure compliance with the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, 29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq. This policy applies to all Acme Corp. employees within the United States. It is Acme Corp.'s policy to comply with the federal WARN Act.

**3.12.2 Notification Requirements**

(a) In the event of a plant closing, defined as the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, Acme Corp. shall provide written notification to affected employees at least 60 calendar days prior to the date of such plant closing.

(b) In the event of a mass layoff, defined as a reduction in force that is not the result of a plant closing and results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for either (i) 500 or more employees or (ii) 50-499 employees if they make up at least 33% of the employer’s active workforce at the single site of employment, Acme Corp. shall provide written notification to affected employees at least 60 calendar days prior to the date of such mass layoff. For the purposes of determining the number of employees affected, employees on temporary layoff or leave of absence who have a reasonable expectation of recall or reinstatement are not included. However, employees who are terminated are always counted. Acme Corp. shall adhere to the stricter of these rules.

**3.12.3 Exceptions**

Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 3.12.2, Acme Corp. may, under limited circumstances, reduce the notification period to less than 60 days, pursuant to the unforeseen business circumstances exception or the faltering company exception as defined in the WARN Act. Any such exception must be documented in detail, and reviewed and approved by the Legal Department.

Policy text:
**Sunrise Technologies, Inc. - Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks (California Employees)**
**Revision Date:** 2024-01-01

**3.4.1 Policy Statement**

Sunrise Technologies, Inc. ("the Company") is committed to compliance with all applicable state and federal laws regarding employee meal and rest breaks. This policy specifically addresses meal and rest break requirements for employees located in California. Federal law does not mandate meal or rest breaks for adult employees; therefore, this policy applies solely to California employees and is governed by the California Labor Code, including but not limited to Sections 226.7 and 512. Nothing in this policy should be construed as creating a right to meal or rest breaks for employees outside of California. This policy supersedes any prior company policies relating to meal and rest breaks for California employees.

**3.4.2 Meal Breaks**

Non-exempt California employees shall be provided with a meal period of no less than thirty (30) minutes for each work period totaling more than five (5) hours, unless the employee's total hours worked for that day are no more than six (6) hours, in which case the meal period may be waived by mutual written agreement between the employee and the Company. Further, if an employee works more than ten (10) hours in a workday, the employee shall be provided with a second meal period of no less than thirty (30) minutes, unless the employee's total hours worked for that day are no more than twelve (12) hours, in which case the second meal period may be waived by mutual written agreement between the employee and the Company. The meal period shall be unpaid, and the employee must be completely relieved of all duties during this period. Employees are required to record their meal breaks accurately in the timekeeping system.

**3.4.3 Rest Breaks**

Non-exempt California employees shall be authorized and permitted to take a paid ten (10) minute rest period for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks shall be taken as near as practical to the midpoint of the four-hour work period.

**3.4.4 Premium Pay for Missed Breaks**

Pursuant to California Labor Code Section 226.7, if the Company fails to provide an employee with a meal or rest period in accordance with this policy, the Company shall pay the employee one (1) hour of pay at the employee’s regular rate of compensation for each workday that the meal or rest period is not provided. However, this provision shall not apply to employees whose employment status is terminated or laid off.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck Timing**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

This policy outlines Acme Corp's procedures for distributing final paychecks to employees whose employment with the company has ended. Acme Corp is committed to complying with all applicable federal wage and hour laws regarding final pay. This policy applies to all employees of Acme Corp throughout the United States.

Generally, Acme Corp will provide a final paycheck to a terminated employee on the next regularly scheduled payday following their termination date. This paycheck will include all earned but unpaid wages, including any accrued and unused vacation time (as described in Section 4.01, Vacation Policy). An employee's employment_status must be something other than *active* to trigger this final pay process. Employees classified as *exempt* or *non_exempt* will both receive final pay based on this policy. Regardless of whether the termination is *voluntary* or *involuntary*, the final paycheck will be issued on the next regularly scheduled payday.

For purposes of clarity, the phrase "regularly scheduled payday" refers to the standard payday schedule established by Acme Corp, which is bi-weekly on Fridays. Any wages earned up to and including the date of termination will be included in the final paycheck. If an employee's final paycheck cannot be delivered via the employee’s usual method of payment (e.g., direct deposit), it will be mailed to the employee's last known address as on file with the Human Resources department. Employees are responsible for ensuring their contact information is kept up to date. Questions about this policy should be directed to the HR department.

Policy text:
**Evergreen Solutions, Inc. - Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.04: Final Paycheck**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

This policy outlines the requirements for the timing of final paychecks for employees of Evergreen Solutions, Inc. This policy applies to all employees in all locations where Evergreen Solutions, Inc. operates, but complies with the strictest applicable law. Please see Section 1.02 for definitions of key terms used throughout this handbook, including “employee,” “termination,” and “resignation.”

Final paychecks will include all earned but unpaid wages, including accrued and unused vacation time where required by applicable state law. The timing of the final paycheck depends on the reason for the employee's separation from Evergreen Solutions, Inc. and the employee's work location.

*   **Involuntary Termination:** If an employee is involuntarily terminated, Evergreen Solutions, Inc. will adhere to the following:
    *   For employees whose primary work location is in California, final wages are due and payable immediately at the time of termination, as mandated by California Labor Code Section 201.
    *   For employees whose primary work location is in a state other than California, final wages will be paid no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following the date of termination, in accordance with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA).
*   **Voluntary Resignation:** If an employee voluntarily resigns, Evergreen Solutions, Inc. will adhere to the following:
    *   For employees whose primary work location is in California, if the employee provides at least 72 hours advance notice of their resignation, the final paycheck will be available on the employee's last day of employment, as required by California Labor Code Section 202. If the employee fails to provide at least 72 hours advance notice of resignation, the final paycheck will be available within 72 hours of the employee's last day of employment.
    *   For employees whose primary work location is in a state other than California, final wages will be paid no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following the date of resignation, in accordance with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). Evergreen Solutions, Inc. will make every effort to process final paychecks sooner than the next regularly scheduled payday where feasible.

Evergreen Solutions, Inc. reserves the right to withhold any amounts authorized by the employee or required by law. Employees with questions about their final paychecks should contact the Human Resources Department.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated HR Policy Manual**

**Section 3.2: Leave Policies**

**Policy 3.2.4: Family and Medical Leave**

(Revision 2.0; Effective Date: 2024-07-01)

Sterling Consolidated is committed to providing employees with leave benefits in accordance with applicable state and federal laws. This policy outlines our approach to Family and Medical Leave, including leave provided under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) and California Paid Family Leave (PFL).

**3.2.4.1 Eligibility and Entitlement**

Employees working at Sterling Consolidated locations in California may be eligible for both FMLA and California PFL. Eligibility for FMLA is governed by federal law; generally, this means you must have worked for Sterling Consolidated for at least 12 months (which need not be consecutive) and at least 1,250 hours in the 12 months prior to the start of the leave, and if Sterling Consolidated has 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of your worksite.

If an employee meets both the FMLA requirements and California PFL requirements, they are generally entitled to take up to 12 weeks of unpaid FMLA leave, followed by up to 8 weeks of California PFL, paid at approximately 60-70% of their normal wages, provided they contribute to the California State Disability Insurance (SDI) program.

However, any employee working at Sterling Consolidated may be terminated if they exhaust 12 weeks of FMLA leave and an additional 8 weeks of California PFL and are still unable to return to their position, and provided their employment status is not "terminated", "resigned", or "laid_off" during the leave period. Further, the leave must be related to parental leave to bond with a newborn child. In such cases, termination is at the discretion of the employee's manager and HR, and will be based on legitimate business needs. See Section 6.1 for further details on termination policies.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**

**Section 3.2: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

Acme Corp is committed to complying with all applicable state and federal laws regarding workforce reductions. This policy outlines the company's responsibilities under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, particularly as it applies to employees located in California. Note that California law provides additional protections compared to Federal law.

**3.2.1 California WARN Act Compliance**

Acme Corp adheres to the California WARN Act (California Labor Code Sections 1400 et seq.). This act requires the company to provide advance written notice to affected employees and relevant government entities in the event of a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation, as defined below:

*   **Mass Layoff:** A reduction in force that results in the termination of 50 or more employees within any 30-day period, where those employees represent at least 33% of the active workforce at the affected establishment.
*   **Plant Closure:** The shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, resulting in the termination of 50 or more employees within any 30-day period.
*   **Relocation:** The removal of all or substantially all of the industrial or commercial operations of an employer to a different location 100 miles or more away from the original location.

Acme Corp will provide 60 days advance written notice of any mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation to affected employees, the California Employment Development Department (EDD), and the local workforce investment board, provided that *both* the employer has 75 or more employees (regardless of full-time or part-time status) *and* the mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation affects 50 or more employees. The 75 employee threshold for California is lower than the 100 employee threshold under the federal WARN act; Acme Corp will always abide by the more stringent requirements of the California WARN act for employees whose employee.location_state is CA. Please refer to Policy 3.2.2 for federal WARN act considerations for other locations. Failure to comply with these notification requirements may result in significant penalties.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated, Inc. - Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Policy 3.14: Final Wage Payment**

**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01
**Revision Number:** 1.2

3.14.1. **General Policy:** Sterling Consolidated, Inc. is committed to complying with all applicable federal and state laws regarding the timely payment of wages. This policy applies to all Sterling Consolidated employees working within the State of California.

3.14.2. **Termination of Employment:** Notwithstanding any federal regulations to the contrary, and specifically pursuant to California Labor Code Sections 201 and 202, employees who are involuntarily terminated from Sterling Consolidated shall receive their final wages, including all accrued but unused vacation time (subject to Policy 5.0, Vacation Accrual and Use), immediately upon termination. This requirement is contingent upon the terminated employee completing all necessary paperwork, as determined by the Human Resources Department, prior to their departure from the company premises. Failure to complete such paperwork may result in a delay in the issuance of the final paycheck, not to exceed 72 hours from the time of termination.

3.14.3. **Voluntary Resignation:** Employees who voluntarily resign from Sterling Consolidated and provide at least seventy-two (72) hours' advance notice of their resignation shall receive their final wages on their last day of employment. However, if an employee fails to provide at least seventy-two (72) hours' advance notice, the employee's final wages shall be available for pick up no later than seventy-two (72) hours from the time of their resignation. An employee under the age of 18 and working less than 20 hours a week must provide five business days' notice, otherwise the 72-hour rule will apply.

3.14.4. **Payroll Procedures:** All final wage payments will be issued in accordance with standard payroll procedures, as detailed in Policy 3.0, Payroll Administration. Questions regarding final wage payments should be directed to the Human Resources Department.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Compensation and Benefits**
**Policy 3.2.4: Overtime Compensation (California Employees)**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

Acme Corp. is committed to complying with all applicable wage and hour laws. This policy specifically addresses overtime compensation for employees located in California and should be read in conjunction with Policy 3.2.1 (General Compensation) and Appendix A (Definitions).

**Overtime for Non-Exempt California Employees:**

For the purposes of calculating overtime for non-exempt employees working within the State of California, the following guidelines shall apply:

*   Non-exempt employees, as defined by applicable federal and California labor law and further detailed in Appendix A, are eligible for overtime pay under certain circumstances.
*   Overtime compensation will be paid at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times the employee’s regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) in a workweek. Please refer to Policy 3.2.1 for the method of calculating the regular rate of pay. However, if a non-exempt employee's location_state is not California, then the requirements of this policy shall not apply to said employee, and Policy 3.2.5 shall apply instead.
* Further, California law provides overtime compensation at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times an employee's regular rate of pay for any hours worked greater than eight (8) in a single workday. For clarity, the employer is required to provide overtime compensation as described by the above rules.

Acme Corp. reserves the right to modify this policy at any time, with or without notice, to comply with applicable laws and regulations. This policy does not create a contract of employment and is not intended to be a complete statement of all applicable laws and regulations. Employees should consult with their manager or the Human Resources Department with any questions regarding this policy.

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics, Inc. - Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks (California Employees)**
**Revision Date: 2024-01-01**

This policy outlines the requirements for meal and rest breaks for Sterling Dynamics, Inc. employees working in the state of California. Sterling Dynamics, Inc. is committed to complying with all applicable California Labor Laws regarding employee meal and rest periods. Please refer to Section 1.2, "Definitions," for clarification of terms used within this policy.

**3.4.1 Meal Breaks**

Employees working shifts exceeding five (5) hours are entitled to an unpaid meal break of no less than thirty (30) minutes. The meal break should commence no later than the end of the employee's fifth (5th) hour of work. Employees working shifts exceeding ten (10) hours are entitled to a second unpaid meal break of no less than thirty (30) minutes. The second meal break should commence no later than the end of the employee’s tenth (10th) hour of work. Employees must be completely relieved of all duties during their meal breaks. Employees can voluntarily waive the first meal break if the total hours worked in a workday is no more than six (6) hours, by signing a Meal Break Waiver Form. Any missed meal breaks, either first or second break, will result in one hour of premium pay paid to the employee.

**3.4.2 Rest Breaks**

Employees are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks should, to the extent practicable, be taken in the middle of each work period.

**3.4.3 Eligibility**

This Section 3.4 applies *exclusively* to Sterling Dynamics, Inc. employees whose primary work location is within the state of California. Employees whose primary work location is not in California are not covered by the rules in this section.

**3.4.4 Compliance**

Sterling Dynamics, Inc. maintains accurate records of employee work hours and meal/rest break compliance. Any employee who believes they have been improperly denied a meal or rest break should immediately report the issue to their supervisor or Human Resources. Repeated failure to provide required breaks may result in disciplinary action against the responsible manager or supervisor, up to and including termination of employment.

Policy text:
**Sterling-Cooper Draper Price (SCDP) HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.2: Compensation and Benefits**
**Policy 3.2.4: Final Paycheck Disbursement**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01, Rev. 2.0**

SCDP is committed to ensuring employees receive their final paychecks in compliance with applicable federal and state laws. This policy outlines the procedures for the disbursement of final paychecks to employees whose employment with SCDP has ended, whether through resignation, termination, layoff, or other separation from employment. Final paychecks will include all earned but unpaid wages, including but not limited to, regular wages, accrued vacation time (subject to Policy 3.3.1: Vacation Accrual and Usage), and any other earned compensation.

Generally, SCDP strives to disburse final paychecks as soon as administratively feasible. However, specific timing may vary depending on the circumstances of the employee's separation and the applicable jurisdiction. For employees not located in California, final paychecks will be issued no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following the employee's last day of employment, as per the Fair Labor Standards Act.

California employees present a nuanced situation. For California-based employees whose separation is classified as an involuntary termination, inclusive of layoffs impacting more than 50% of the workforce within a 30-day period, final pay, provided such termination did not involve an act of gross misconduct as determined by SCDP’s internal review process, shall be made available immediately upon termination, which, for the avoidance of doubt, means the time of termination, unless, pending review by payroll, extenuating circumstances prevent such immediate disbursement. Consult with the HR department for further guidance, but the California Labor Code controls.

SCDP reserves the right to make deductions from final paychecks as permitted by law, including but not limited to deductions for taxes, insurance premiums, and repayment of outstanding loans or advances. Employees are encouraged to review their final paystubs carefully and to contact the HR department with any questions or concerns.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated HR Policy Manual**

**Section 3.2: Meal and Rest Breaks (California Employees)**
**Revision:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01

Sterling Consolidated is committed to complying with all applicable laws and regulations regarding employee meal and rest breaks. This policy applies *exclusively* to employees physically working in the State of California. This policy supplements, and does not replace, other Sterling Consolidated policies, including Section 2.1 regarding work schedules and Section 4.5 regarding timekeeping. All California employees are required to accurately record their meal and rest breaks in the company timekeeping system.

**Meal Breaks:**

In accordance with California Labor Code Sections 512 and 516, employees who work more than five (5) hours in a workday are entitled to a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. This break must commence before the end of the employee's fifth (5th) hour of work. Employees working more than ten (10) hours in a workday are entitled to a second thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. This second meal break must commence before the end of the employee's tenth (10th) hour of work. Employees must be completely relieved of all duty during their meal breaks. Employees are free to leave the premises during their meal breaks. Any California employee classified as non-exempt who has worked at Sterling Consolidated for less than six months and is scheduled to work more than 8 hours daily, but whose employment status is *not* in "terminated", "resigned", or "laid_off" statuses, must have their schedule reviewed by their manager to ensure meal break compliance.

**Rest Breaks:**

California employees are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks should, to the extent practicable, be taken in the middle of each four-hour work period.

**Missed Breaks:**

If an employee is not provided with a compliant meal or rest break, Sterling Consolidated will pay the employee one (1) hour of premium pay for each missed break, in accordance with California law. Employees must report any missed meal or rest breaks to their supervisor immediately.

Policy text:
**Sterling Consolidated HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.4: Family and Medical Leave**
**Revision 1.2**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**

**3.4.1 Purpose**
Sterling Consolidated is committed to supporting our employees' needs to balance work and family responsibilities. This policy outlines the provisions for Family and Medical Leave, adhering to both federal and state laws. Employees should also refer to Section 3.5, entitled "Other Leave Options" for information about bereavement and other leave types.

**3.4.2 Eligibility for Family and Medical Leave**
Employees who meet the eligibility requirements outlined in both the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) and California Paid Family Leave (PFL) are entitled to certain benefits, although these may not necessarily run concurrently. FMLA, a federal law, provides eligible employees with up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave for qualifying reasons, including the birth or adoption of a child or to care for a seriously ill family member, as defined by federal regulation. Eligibility for FMLA requires that the employee has been employed by Sterling Consolidated for at least 12 months, and has worked at least 1,250 hours in the 12 months preceding the leave. Sterling Consolidated calculates the number of employees within 75 miles of a worksite according to guidelines established in the FMLA regulations, in order to make determinations about coverage under FMLA.

**3.4.3 California Paid Family Leave (PFL)**
California Paid Family Leave (PFL) provides wage replacement benefits to eligible employees who take time off work to care for a seriously ill family member or to bond with a new child. PFL is administered by the California Employment Development Department (EDD) and is funded through employee contributions to the State Disability Insurance (SDI) program. Employees who contribute to SDI are eligible for PFL benefits, up to 8 weeks at approximately 60-70% of their usual weekly wage. This benefit is not guaranteed and is subject to approval by the EDD based on their guidelines. If an employee is eligible for both FMLA and PFL for the same qualifying event and their location_state is California, they may initially take FMLA leave and then supplement with PFL, or vice-versa, though in no case will Sterling Consolidated supplement these payments to bring the employee to their full usual weekly wage, regardless of employee classification.

Policy text:
**The Phoenix Consortium, Inc. – Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision Number: 1.0**

3.  12.1 **Purpose**: This policy outlines The Phoenix Consortium, Inc.'s ("the Company") policy regarding meal and rest breaks for its employees within the United States, pursuant to applicable federal law. It is the Company’s intention to comply with all applicable laws and regulations. This policy supersedes all prior policies concerning meal and rest periods. Any inconsistencies between this policy and applicable law shall be resolved in favor of applicable law.

4.  12.2 **Eligibility for Meal and Rest Breaks**:

(a) Notwithstanding any state or local laws to the contrary, and in accordance with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), the Company provides meal and rest breaks as follows: Employees who are classified as non-exempt and whose daily hours worked are less than or equal to five (5) hours are not eligible for any meal breaks as described in section 3.12.3. All other non-exempt employees are eligible for meal breaks as per section 3.12.3. The provisions of this policy shall not be construed to create any contractual rights in favor of any employee.

5.  12.3 **Meal Breaks**: Non-exempt employees are entitled to an unpaid meal break of at least thirty (30) minutes when their daily hours worked are greater than five (5) hours, provided they are completely relieved of all duties during the meal break. Employees are responsible for accurately recording their meal breaks in the Company’s timekeeping system. Failure to do so may result in disciplinary action.

6.  12.4 **Rest Breaks**: The Company provides paid rest breaks of approximately ten (10) minutes for non-exempt employees for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof.

7.  12.5 **Policy Violations**: Employees are expected to adhere to this policy. Repeated failure to follow this policy could lead to disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment.

Policy text:
**Zenith Dynamics Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.4: Overtime Compensation**

**3.4.1 General Policy**

It is the policy of Zenith Dynamics that all non-exempt employees working within the State of California shall be compensated for overtime hours worked pursuant to the provisions of California Labor Code Sections 510 and 515. Notwithstanding any federal law or regulation to the contrary, this policy governs overtime compensation for all non-exempt employees physically working within California, regardless of the employee's residence or Zenith Dynamics' headquarters location. This policy is effective as of January 1, 2025, and supersedes all prior policies regarding overtime for California employees.

**3.4.2 Overtime Calculation**

(a) For all non-exempt employees whose location_state is California, overtime shall be paid at one and one-half (1.5) times the employee's regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of eight (8) hours in any workday or for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours in any workweek.

(b) For all non-exempt employees whose location_state is California, overtime shall be paid at two (2) times the employee's regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of twelve (12) hours in any workday.

(c) For all non-exempt employees whose location_state is California, overtime shall also be paid at two (2) times the employee's regular rate of pay for the first eight (8) hours worked on the seventh (7th) consecutive day of work in a workweek. Any hours worked beyond eight (8) on the seventh consecutive day of work shall also be compensated at twice the regular rate.

**3.4.3 Recordkeeping**

Accurate records of all hours worked, including overtime hours, shall be maintained for all non-exempt employees pursuant to California Labor Code Section 1174. Employees are required to accurately report all hours worked, and supervisors are responsible for ensuring accurate timekeeping. Any discrepancies should be reported immediately to the HR Department.

**Revision 1.0**

Policy text:
**Acme Corp Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction Notifications (WARN Act)**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

This policy outlines Acme Corp's responsibilities regarding workforce reductions under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act. Acme Corp is committed to complying with federal law in all situations involving mass layoffs or plant closures.

**3.12.1 Applicability:**
The WARN Act applies to Acme Corp when the employer employee count is 100 or more employees, excluding those who have worked less than 6 months in the last 12 months or those who work an average of fewer than 20 hours a week. In the event of a plant closing or mass layoff, Acme Corp must provide written notice 60 calendar days in advance of the planned action.

**3.12.2 Definitions:**

*   **Plant Closing:** The permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding part-time employees.
*   **Mass Layoff:** A reduction in force which is not the result of a plant closing and results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for at least 50 employees if these employees represent at least 33% of the employer’s active workforce, excluding part-time employees. Alternatively, a mass layoff also occurs when 500 or more employees experience an employment loss.

**3.12.3 Notification Requirements:**
If Acme Corp anticipates a plant closing or mass layoff that meets the criteria defined above, the Human Resources Department is required to notify all affected employees, the chief elected official of the local government, and the state's dislocated worker unit. The layoff timeframe days for affected employees will be considered during the 60-day notification period. The HR department will make a final determination of notification requirements.

**3.12.4 Exclusions:**
This policy adheres to federal law exclusively. State-specific WARN Act provisions (such as those in California with lower employee thresholds) do not apply to Acme Corp’s nationwide workforce.

Policy text:
**United Global Solutions, Inc. Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks (Effective Date: 2024-01-01, Revision 1.2)**

3.4.1. **Purpose:** This section outlines the Company's policy regarding meal and rest breaks for employees, pursuant to federal law. United Global Solutions, Inc. is committed to ensuring employee well-being and compliance with all applicable federal regulations. Nothing in this policy should be construed as creating any rights or obligations beyond those mandated by federal law.

3.4.2. **Applicability:** This policy applies to all non-exempt employees of United Global Solutions, Inc. throughout the United States, subject to applicable federal law. Exempt employees are not subject to the provisions of this policy.

3.4.3. **Meal Breaks:** In accordance with federal law, United Global Solutions, Inc. is not required to provide meal breaks. However, if United Global Solutions, Inc. elects to provide meal periods of thirty (30) minutes or more, such breaks will be unpaid, provided the employee is completely relieved of all duties and responsibilities during the entirety of the break. If the employee is not completely relieved of all duties and responsibilities, the meal period will be considered working time and must be compensated accordingly. Employees who voluntarily choose to work during their scheduled meal period may do so, but will only be compensated if they have explicit prior approval from their supervisor or manager to perform work during that time. This policy also incorporates Policy 3.7 regarding overtime compensation, which requires that all hours worked in excess of 40 in a workweek be compensated at a rate of one and one-half times the employee's regular rate of pay.

3.4.4. **Rest Breaks:** United Global Solutions, Inc. is not federally required to provide rest breaks to adult employees. However, if a manager permits short breaks of five (5) to twenty (20) minutes, such breaks shall be paid. It is the expectation of United Global Solutions, Inc. that any break period is used responsibly to allow the employee to adequately refresh and to maintain an acceptable standard of performance.

3.4.5 **Federal Break Provision:** Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, United Global Solutions, Inc. will allow a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break for any non-exempt employee if their shift.duration_hours is greater than five (5) hours.

Policy text:
**AlphaCorp Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**

**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01
**Revision:** 2.0

AlphaCorp is committed to complying with all applicable federal laws regarding workforce reductions. This policy outlines the procedures for mass layoffs and plant closures as defined by the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act of 1988 (29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq.). Note that this policy reflects federal regulations; individual states may have their own, potentially stricter, requirements regarding mass layoffs and plant closures, and it is the employee's responsibility to understand the regulations applicable to them. AlphaCorp will aim to provide advance notice of workforce reductions wherever possible, balancing legal obligations with the operational needs of the business.

*   **WARN Act Notice Requirement:** In accordance with the federal WARN Act, AlphaCorp is required to provide sixty (60) calendar days' advance written notice to affected employees before any plant closing or mass layoff, as defined below, unless unforeseen circumstances exist. While the spirit of the law is intended to apply where 50 or more employees are impacted, any reduction in force must meet the federal guidelines. Note that this requirement is activated, however, only if the employer (AlphaCorp) has 100 or more employees company-wide. The determination of whether a mass layoff or plant closing has occurred is complex and will be made on a case-by-case basis in consultation with legal counsel. If it is determined that AlphaCorp employs at least 100 individuals across all locations and a mass layoff as defined under federal guidelines impacts an active employee, AlphaCorp must provide 60 days advance notice of termination. For clarification on what constitutes "active" status, please refer to section 2.01.

*   **Definitions:**
    *   **Plant Closing:** The permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees excluding any part-time employees.
    *   **Mass Layoff:** A reduction in force which is not the result of a plant closing, that results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees and at least 33% of the employees at the single site of employment, or 500 or more employees, regardless of percentage of employees at the single site of employment.

Policy text:
**Golden Gate Technologies, Inc. - Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance (California)**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01, Revision 1.0**

This policy outlines Golden Gate Technologies, Inc.'s procedures regarding workforce reductions and compliance with the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, specifically as it applies to our employees in California. Golden Gate Technologies, Inc. is committed to treating all employees fairly and ethically during any workforce reduction. This policy is designed to ensure compliance with both the federal WARN Act and the California WARN Act, recognizing that the California WARN Act provides broader employee protections.

**3.12.1 WARN Act Notification Requirements**

In the event of a plant closing, relocation, or mass layoff affecting employees in California, Golden Gate Technologies, Inc. will adhere to the following notification requirements:

*   **California WARN Act Applicability:** Golden Gate Technologies, Inc. will comply with the California WARN Act if the company employs, or has employed within the preceding 12 months, 75 or more persons in California. This calculation includes both full-time and part-time employees.

*   **Federal WARN Act Applicability:** If Golden Gate Technologies, Inc. employs 100 or more employees, the Federal WARN Act will also be applicable, regardless of whether the California WARN Act is triggered. Should both Acts apply, the provisions affording the greater protection to employees will be followed.

*   **Notification Thresholds and Timing:** We will provide written notice at least 60 days prior to any covered plant closing, relocation, or mass layoff. A "mass layoff" under the California WARN Act is defined as a layoff of 50 or more employees within any 30-day period. A "plant closing" or "relocation" requires cessation of operations at a facility and may trigger similar notification requirements depending on the number of affected employees.

*   **Content of Notice:** The notice will be provided to affected employees, the California Employment Development Department (EDD), and the local chief elected official of the city and county government. The notice will contain, at minimum, the expected date of the plant closing, relocation, or mass layoff, a statement as to whether the action is expected to be permanent or temporary, and the job titles of positions to be affected. See Section 3.13 (Employee Separation) for information on severance benefits.

Policy text:
**XYZ Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck Distribution**
**Revision Number:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** January 1, 2025

3.12.1. **General Policy**. XYZ Corp. is committed to complying with all applicable federal and state wage and hour laws regarding the timely distribution of final paychecks. The timing of final paycheck distribution shall be governed by the employee's location of work and the circumstances surrounding their separation from employment.

3.12.2. **California Employees**. Notwithstanding Section 3.12.1, for employees whose primary work location is in the State of California, the following provisions shall apply. Pursuant to California Labor Code Sections 201 and 202, employees who are involuntarily terminated shall receive their final paycheck, including all wages earned and unpaid, immediately upon termination. Employees who resign and provide at least seventy-two (72) hours advance written notice of their intention to resign shall receive their final paycheck on their last day of employment. In the event an employee resigns without providing seventy-two (72) hours advance written notice, the final paycheck shall be available for pickup within seventy-two (72) hours of the employee's last day of employment. If the employee requests that the final paycheck be mailed, the company shall mail the paycheck within seventy-two (72) hours of the employee's last day of employment. If an exempt employee is terminated mid-pay period, the calculation will adhere to Section 3.5, Wages and Salary Calculations.

3.12.3. **Employees Outside of California**. For employees whose primary work location is outside of the State of California, but within the United States, the final paycheck shall be issued no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following the employee's date of termination, as required by the Fair Labor Standards Act. However, where state law requires a more expedited payment schedule, XYZ Corp. will comply with that state's requirements.

3.12.4. **Severance Pay**. This policy does not cover severance pay, which is addressed in Section 3.15.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck Timing**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision Number: 1.0**

This policy outlines the timing requirements for the distribution of final paychecks to employees of Acme Corp., in accordance with applicable federal and state laws. Acme Corp. is committed to ensuring accurate and timely payment of all wages owed to its employees. This policy applies to all employees, regardless of employment status, classification, or location, though specific requirements may vary based on applicable state law. (See Section 1.01 for Definitions).

**3.12.1 General Policy**

Final paychecks will include all earned and unpaid wages, including but not limited to regular wages, accrued vacation time (subject to Policy 4.02 regarding vacation accrual and payout), and any other earned bonuses or commissions. Acme Corp. will generally adhere to the requirements of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) for final paycheck timing, which mandates payment by the next regularly scheduled payday. However, recognizing the stricter requirements of certain states, Acme Corp. will comply with state law where it provides a greater benefit to the employee.

**3.12.2 California Employees**

For employees whose primary work location is in the State of California, the following policy applies, supplementing the general policy outlined in Section 3.12.1. If an employee is involuntarily terminated from Acme Corp, all earned wages are due and payable *immediately* at the time of termination. In the event that Acme Corp is unable to provide a physical check immediately at the point of termination, a final paycheck will be made available at the employee's designated mailing address, and mailed via USPS First Class within 24 hours. This accelerated timeline supersedes the federal next-regular-payday rule outlined above.

**3.12.3 Resignation**

For voluntary resignations, the timing of the final paycheck depends on the amount of notice provided. See also Policy 2.20 regarding employee resignation procedures.

Policy text:
**Apex Solutions, Inc. - HR Policy Manual**
**Section 5.7: Workforce Reductions and WARN Act Compliance**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

This policy outlines Apex Solutions, Inc.’s procedures for workforce reductions, including layoffs, plant closures, and relocations, to ensure compliance with both federal and California Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Acts. This policy applies to all Apex Solutions, Inc. employees in the United States.

**5.7.1: WARN Act Notice Requirements**

Apex Solutions, Inc. is committed to providing employees with as much advance notice as possible in the event of a workforce reduction. The federal WARN Act requires employers with 100 or more employees to provide 60 calendar days' advance written notice of a plant closing or mass layoff affecting 50 or more employees at a single site of employment. The California WARN Act, with stricter regulations, applies to employers with 75 or more employees and requires the same 60-day notice for a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation that affects 50 or more employees within a 30-day period. If Apex Solutions, Inc. initiates a mass layoff that impacts at least 50 employees and the employer.employee_count is greater than or equal to 75 and if at least one employee is located in the state of california (employee.location_state eq CA) the company is required to notify affected employees, the California Employment Development Department (EDD), and local government officials at least 60 days prior to the date of the first termination. This notification will include the date of the planned actions, the positions affected, and resources available to employees. The company also commits to adhering to any other state-specific WARN act legislation if applicable.

**5.7.2: Definitions**

*   **Plant Closing:** The permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees excluding any part-time employees.

*   **Mass Layoff:** A reduction in force that is not the result of a plant closing and results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees who make up at least 33% of the employers active workforce, or 500 or more employees.

*   **Relocation:** The removal of all or substantially all of the industrial or commercial operations of an employer to a different location 100 miles or more away.

**5.7.3: Exceptions**

[Further sections outline exceptions to the WARN act notification requirements, such as unforeseeable business circumstances or natural disasters (not included here for brevity).]

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy**
**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck**
**Revision: 1.0**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**

3.12.1. **General Policy:** It is the policy of Acme Corp. to provide employees with their final paycheck in accordance with applicable federal law, specifically the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). The timing of an employee's final paycheck shall be determined pursuant to the parameters outlined in this section.

3.12.2. **Timing of Final Paycheck:**
(a) Except as otherwise provided in subsection (b), final paychecks for employees whose employment is terminated, regardless of whether the termination is voluntary or involuntary, shall be issued on the company's next regularly scheduled payday following the date of termination. This provision applies to all employees irrespective of their employment status or tenure with Acme Corp, provided that federal law shall govern.
(b) Notwithstanding subsection (a), if an employee is terminated involuntarily and such employee’s employment is governed by a collective bargaining agreement that dictates a different timeframe for the issuance of final paychecks, the terms of that collective bargaining agreement shall supersede the requirements of subsection (a) to the extent permissible under federal law. However, should an employee’s employment status change from active to terminated due to a plant closure as defined under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, final payment shall be distributed in accordance with the WARN Act requirements, but no later than the next regularly scheduled payday unless specifically precluded by federal statute.

3.12.3 **Method of Payment:** All final paychecks will be disbursed according to the employee’s elected method of payment, as on file with the Payroll Department.

3.12.4 **Deductions:** All legally required and authorized deductions will be withheld from the final paycheck.

Policy text:
**The Daily Grind Coffee Co. - HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.7: Final Paycheck Distribution (Rev. 2.1; Effective 2024-01-01)**

This section details the procedures for distributing final paychecks to employees whose employment with The Daily Grind Coffee Co. has ended. The timing of final paycheck distribution varies depending on the reason for termination, the employee's location, and whether or not advance notice was provided.

For employees working outside of California, final paychecks will be issued on the next regularly scheduled payday following their termination date, as generally required under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). However, for employees whose primary work location is in California, different rules apply.

Specifically, in California, if an employee is involuntarily terminated (i.e., fired) by The Daily Grind Coffee Co., their final paycheck, including all earned wages, accrued vacation time, and any other compensation due, will be available for pickup immediately upon termination at their regular worksite. If the employee is unavailable to pick up their paycheck, it will be mailed to their last known address, but no later than 72 hours from the termination date. This adheres to California Labor Code Sections 201 and 202.

However, if an employee voluntarily resigns, and provides at least 72 hours of advance notice of their resignation to their supervisor, their final paycheck will also be available immediately upon their last day of employment. Failure to provide the required notice will result in final pay being available within 72 hours of the resignation date. The Daily Grind Coffee Co. reserves the right to fulfill final pay requirements on the next regular pay period, should unforeseen challenges arise. Questions regarding Final Paycheck Distribution may be addressed to the Payroll Department. See Section 5.2 for information about Vacation Payout policies.

Policy text:
**StellarTech Corporation – Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.4: Final Paycheck**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

This policy outlines the procedures for the timely disbursement of final paychecks to employees separating from StellarTech Corporation. StellarTech Corporation is committed to full compliance with all applicable federal wage and hour laws, including the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). This policy applies to all StellarTech employees throughout the United States. In the event of any perceived conflict between this policy and an applicable collective bargaining agreement, the terms of the collective bargaining agreement shall govern.

Final paychecks, encompassing all wages earned through the final date of employment, will be issued according to the following guidelines:

*   Employees who are terminated, whether voluntarily or involuntarily, will receive their final paycheck on the next regularly scheduled payday following their termination date. The final paycheck will include all earned but unpaid wages, including accrued vacation time as outlined in Section 5.2, "Vacation and Paid Time Off." No exceptions will be made to this next-regular-payday rule, irrespective of the type of termination or notice period given.
*   Regardless of an employee's employment status (e.g. terminated, resigned, or laid off), the final paycheck distribution will always be on the next scheduled payday. If an employee resigns and provides less than two weeks' notice, their final paycheck will still be processed and distributed on the next scheduled payday. Employees will be notified by their supervisor or HR representative regarding how their final paycheck will be delivered (e.g., direct deposit, mailed check). Please refer to policy 3.1 for definitions of resignation and termination.
* Any employee terminated on a Friday ( the last day of the company pay week) will receive their pay with the normal direct deposit to their account on the following Friday.

Policy text:
**Section 3.4 Overtime Compensation**

**3.4.1 General Policy**

It is the policy of Zenith Dynamics (hereinafter "the Company") to comply with all applicable federal and state laws regarding the payment of overtime compensation. This policy is effective as of January 1, 2024, and supersedes all prior policies related to overtime compensation. This policy applies to all non-exempt employees of the Company. Any changes to this policy will be communicated in writing and posted on the Company intranet.

**3.4.2 Overtime Eligibility and Calculation**

Pursuant to the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), 29 U.S.C. § 207, and California Labor Code Sections 510 and 515, non-exempt employees shall be compensated for overtime work as follows: For employees whose primary work location is in the State of California, any hours worked beyond eight (8) hours in a single workday or forty (40) hours in a workweek shall be compensated at one and one-half (1.5) times the employee’s regular rate of pay. Furthermore, for those employees in California, any hours worked beyond twelve (12) hours in a single workday or any hours worked beyond eight (8) hours on the seventh (7th) consecutive day of a workweek shall be compensated at two (2) times the employee's regular rate of pay. Notwithstanding the foregoing, employees classified as exempt are not eligible for overtime compensation. The regular rate of pay shall include all remuneration for employment paid to, or on behalf of, the employee, but shall not include items excluded under the FLSA, such as discretionary bonuses. Any questions regarding the calculation of overtime pay should be directed to the Human Resources Department. See also Section 2.1 regarding employee classification.

**3.4.3 Recording of Hours Worked**

All non-exempt employees are required to accurately record all hours worked, including start and stop times, as well as any meal or rest breaks taken, utilizing the Company’s timekeeping system. Failure to accurately record hours worked may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination.

**3.4.4 Out-of-State Overtime**
For non-exempt employees outside of California, the company will follow federal law requiring 1.5 times the normal rate of pay for hours worked over 40 in a work week.
