Policy text:
**The Innovative Solutions Group, Inc. Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation (California Employees)**
**Revision 1.0**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**

This policy outlines the requirements for overtime compensation for non-exempt employees working within the state of California, as per California Labor Code Sections 510 and 515. It is important to note that while we adhere to federal law under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), California law provides additional protections. This policy applies only to employees whose primary work location is within California and supersedes any conflicting company policy, practice, or agreement. The intent of this policy is to ensure that The Innovative Solutions Group, Inc. complies with all applicable wage and hour laws.

Non-exempt employees are eligible for overtime pay under the following conditions: Overtime compensation will be calculated at one and one-half (1.5) times the employee’s regular rate of pay for all hours worked over eight (8) in a workday or forty (40) hours in a workweek. However, this does not include employees who are employed through temporary staffing services contracted by The Innovative Solutions Group, Inc., whose overtime is covered under their respective contracts, nor employees under specific collective bargaining agreements providing comparable overtime benefits. Further, and to avoid any doubt, hours worked must be formally approved by the employee's supervisor or department head to qualify for overtime compensation. Any hours not pre-approved will not be considered for overtime until such approval is granted, although employees will still be compensated at their regular hourly rate for those hours. In situations where an employee works more than twelve (12) hours in a workday or more than eight (8) hours on the seventh (7th) consecutive day of a workweek, compensation will be calculated at two (2) times the employee's regular rate of pay for those hours exceeding twelve (12) or eight (8) respectively on the seventh consecutive day. This policy is subject to change at the discretion of The Innovative Solutions Group, Inc. and any modifications will be communicated to employees in a timely manner. Questions regarding this policy should be directed to the Human Resources Department.

Policy text:
**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance (California Employees Only)**
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01
**Revision:** 1.0

It is the policy of Innovation Solutions Inc. to comply with all applicable federal and California laws regarding workforce reductions, including the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act. This policy section applies only to employees working in California.

The California WARN Act (Cal. Labor Code sections 1400 et seq.) mandates that employers with 75 or more employees (including both full-time and part-time employees) provide 60 days' advance written notice to affected employees before any mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation that affects 50 or more employees within a 30-day period. A "mass layoff" is defined as a reduction in force that is not the result of a plant closure or relocation, and that results in employment loss at a single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees. A "plant closure" occurs when an employer shuts down a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, and the shutdown results in an employment loss during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees. A "relocation" means that an employer moves all or substantially all of the operations of the employer from one location to a different location 100 miles or more away.

Therefore, if Innovation Solutions Inc. employs 75 or more individuals in California and a planned mass layoff will affect 50 or more employees within a 30-day period, the company is required to provide affected employees with a written notice at least 60 days in advance of the date of the layoff. This notification must be given to the employees’ bargaining representatives, if any, the affected employees, the California Employment Development Department (EDD), and the local workforce investment board. See also Section 5.2 regarding required contents of a WARN notice.

Note: This policy is intended as a guideline only and does not create any contractual rights. The company reserves the right to modify or terminate this policy at any time, with or without notice. For specific questions, please consult with the HR department.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

Acme Corp. is committed to compliance with all applicable labor laws, including the federal Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act and the California WARN Act. This policy outlines procedures for workforce reductions, including layoffs, plant closures, and relocations, specifically for employees working within the State of California.

It is Acme Corp.'s policy that in the event of a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation affecting employees located in California, the company will adhere to the notification requirements outlined in the California WARN Act. A “mass layoff” is defined as a reduction in force that results in employment loss at a single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees. To determine if the California WARN Act applies to a specific layoff event, the number of affected California employees will be considered. However, if Acme Corp. has at least 75 employees total, and a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation will occur, we will provide affected employees with written notice at least 60 calendar days in advance of the date of separation. This notice will contain all information required by the California WARN Act (Cal. Labor Code Sections 1400 et seq.), including the expected date of termination, information about available benefits, and contact information for relevant company representatives. Please note, this policy is subject to change and will be updated as needed to reflect changes in federal or state law. If the employee's employment status is 'terminated', this policy does not apply.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. - Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.7: Family and Medical Leave (FMLA)**
*Revision Date: 2024-07-01*

Acme Corp. is committed to complying with the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), a federal law designed to provide eligible employees with job-protected leave for qualifying family and medical reasons. This policy outlines the terms and conditions under which Acme Corp. employees may be eligible for FMLA leave. Please note that this policy applies to all Acme Corp. employees across the United States and is governed solely by federal regulations. State-specific leave programs, such as those found in California, are not addressed in this policy. Any conflict between this policy and applicable law will be resolved in favor of the law.

**Eligibility for FMLA Leave:**

To be eligible for FMLA leave, an employee must meet the following criteria, as dictated by federal law:

1.  The employee must have been employed by Acme Corp. for at least twelve (12) months, which need not be consecutive. Absences due to temporary layoffs or involuntary terminations that predate a period of re-employment do not affect the length of employment, provided the employee is subsequently rehired or reinstated.
2.  The employee must have worked for Acme Corp. for at least 1,250 hours during the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding the date the leave is to commence. Hours worked include only those hours actually worked. Time spent on paid or unpaid leave, including vacation, sick leave, or other forms of leave, are not counted towards the 1,250-hour requirement. If the company does not maintain an accurate record of hours worked for an employee, or the employee's employment status is considered "exempt" from overtime pay, a determination of whether the employee has met this hours-of-service requirement shall be based on the best available evidence of the employee's actual hours worked.
3.  Acme Corp. must employ fifty (50) or more employees within a seventy-five (75) mile radius of the employee's worksite. If there are fewer than 50 employees at the employee's specific worksite location, but the aggregate total of employees at other Acme Corp. locations within 75 miles of that site exceeds 50, the employee is covered by FMLA.

Employees meeting these requirements may be eligible for up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave in a 12-month period for qualifying reasons as outlined in Section 3.8.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck Disbursement**
**Revision Number:** 1.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01

This policy outlines the procedures for issuing final paychecks to employees leaving Acme Corp. Acme Corp is committed to complying with all applicable federal wage and hour laws regarding final pay. This policy applies to all US-based employees.

Generally, employees will receive their final paycheck on the next regularly scheduled payday following their last day of employment. This applies regardless of whether the termination was voluntary or involuntary. However, if an employee is involuntarily terminated due to gross misconduct resulting in immediate termination, the final paycheck will be available for pick-up or mailed to the employee's address on file within 72 hours of the termination date. This is to allow for a review of any outstanding reimbursements or deductions. If an employee voluntarily resigns without providing at least two weeks' notice, the final paycheck may also be delayed until the next regularly scheduled payday to allow for the processing of outstanding items. Please note that this policy is governed by federal law. Contact the HR department with any questions. See also Section 3.05 for information regarding deductions from final paychecks.

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics, Inc. - Employee Handbook**
**Policy 5.03: Family and Medical Leave**
**Revision Date: 2024-01-01**

5.03.1 Eligibility for Unpaid Family and Medical Leave

Pursuant to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 (FMLA), Sterling Dynamics, Inc. provides eligible employees with up to twelve (12) weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave per twelve-month period for qualifying family and medical reasons. To be eligible for FMLA leave, an employee must (a) have been employed by Sterling Dynamics, Inc. for at least twelve (12) months; (b) have worked for at least 1,250 hours during the twelve-month period immediately preceding the commencement of the leave; and (c) be employed at a worksite where Sterling Dynamics, Inc. employs fifty (50) or more employees within a 75-mile radius.

5.03.2 Qualifying Reasons for FMLA Leave

Qualifying reasons for FMLA leave include: (a) the birth of a child and to bond with the newborn child within one year of birth; (b) the placement with the employee of a child for adoption or foster care and to bond with the newly placed child within one year of placement; (c) to care for the employee's spouse, child, or parent who has a serious health condition; (d) a serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the essential functions of his or her job; (e) any qualifying exigency arising out of the fact that the employee's spouse, son, daughter, or parent is a covered military member on active duty (or has been notified of an impending call or order to active duty) in the Armed Forces.

5.03.3 Intermittent or Reduced Schedule Leave

FMLA leave may be taken intermittently or on a reduced leave schedule under certain circumstances, particularly when medically necessary to care for a family member with a serious health condition or due to the employee's own serious health condition, subject to the requirements set forth in Section 5.04 regarding medical certification. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, an employee whose employment status is "terminated" or "resigned" as documented according to policy section 2.15 shall not be eligible for FMLA benefits if the leave request occurs after the termination date or resignation date, regardless of whether the event triggering the leave occurred prior to termination/resignation.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

This section outlines Acme Corp’s policy regarding overtime pay for non-exempt employees. Acme Corp is committed to complying with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA).

**3.2.1 Overtime Eligibility**

Employees classified as non-exempt are eligible for overtime pay. As defined in Section 2.1 (Employee Classifications), non-exempt employees are those who are subject to federal wage and hour laws. To reiterate, only *non-exempt* employees may earn overtime. Exempt employees receive a fixed salary regardless of hours worked and are not eligible for overtime compensation. If there are any questions regarding your classification, please see your manager or refer to HR.

**3.2.2 Overtime Calculation**

Overtime pay is calculated at one and one-half (1.5) times the employee's regular hourly rate of pay. This applies when a non-exempt employee works more than 40 hours in a single workweek. For example, if an employee's regular hourly rate is $20.00 per hour, their overtime rate will be $30.00 per hour. The workweek is defined as Sunday at 12:00 AM through Saturday at 11:59 PM. Hours worked beyond 40 hours within this timeframe are subject to overtime compensation. Time off such as vacation days, sick leave, or unpaid leave are *not* included when calculating total hours worked in a workweek for the purpose of overtime. Overtime pay will be included in the employee's regular paycheck for the pay period in which the overtime hours were worked. Employees must accurately record all hours worked in the company's timekeeping system.

Policy text:
**The TechForward Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.14: Workforce Reductions and WARN Act Compliance**
**Revision Date:** 2024-07-01

TechForward is committed to treating its employees with respect and fairness. In the event of a workforce reduction impacting a significant number of employees, the company will adhere to the requirements of both the federal Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act and the California WARN Act (collectively, "WARN Acts"), where applicable.

The circumstances under which TechForward will provide notice under the WARN Acts are as follows:

*   **Federal WARN Act:** In accordance with the federal WARN Act, 29 U.S.C. § 2101, et seq., TechForward will provide at least 60 calendar days advance written notice of any plant closing or mass layoff affecting at least 50 employees (excluding part-time employees, as defined by the federal WARN Act) at a single site of employment, provided that the number of affected employees constitutes at least 33% of the total number of employees at that site. If the employee count is less than 100, this provision is void.

*   **California WARN Act:** TechForward will also comply with the California WARN Act, Cal. Labor Code § 1400 et seq., which requires 60 calendar days advance written notice of a mass layoff, relocation, or termination (as defined in the statute) affecting 50 or more employees within a 30-day period at a single site of employment. This California requirement applies if TechForward employs 75 or more persons within California. However, if TechForward is actively seeking capital to prevent or postpone a shutdown, and believes in good faith that giving notice would preclude it from obtaining the capital, then a shorter notice period may be provided, subject to statutory penalties and requirements.

It is important to note that the specific requirements of the WARN Acts are complex and subject to change. TechForward's Human Resources Department will be responsible for determining the applicability of the WARN Acts to any particular workforce reduction event and will ensure compliance with all applicable requirements. The applicability of either act will be determined by a review of the total employee count both company-wide and at the affected location. Nothing in this policy creates any contractual rights for employees.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks (California Employees)**
**Revision Number:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01

This policy outlines Acme Corp's requirements for providing meal and rest breaks to employees working in the state of California, in accordance with California Labor Code Sections 226.7, 512, and applicable Wage Orders. This policy applies solely to employees whose primary work location is within California. For employees working outside of California, please refer to Section 3.5, "Meal and Rest Breaks (Non-California Employees)".

Acme Corp is committed to complying with all applicable California labor laws. Non-exempt employees working shifts longer than five (5) hours are entitled to a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break. This meal break should ideally commence no later than the end of the employee’s fifth (5th) hour of work. Employees working shifts exceeding ten (10) hours are entitled to a second thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break, which should ideally begin no later than the end of the employee's tenth (10th) hour of work. However, this second meal period may be waived by mutual consent of the employer and the employee only if the total hours worked are no more than twelve (12) hours AND the first meal period was not waived.

In addition to meal breaks, non-exempt California employees are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. To the extent possible, rest breaks will be scheduled in the middle of each four-hour work period.

It is the employee's responsibility to accurately record all meal and rest breaks taken. Any failure to provide the required meal or rest periods will result in one (1) hour of premium pay for each workday that the break is not provided, as per California law. This premium pay will be included in the employee’s regular paycheck for the pay period in which the violation occurred. Employees should immediately report any missed meal or rest breaks to their supervisor or HR department.

Please note that this policy does not apply to exempt employees as defined under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and California law. See Section 2.2 "Employee Classification" for a detailed explanation of exempt and non-exempt classifications.

Policy text:
**Sterling Innovations Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Family and Medical Leave (California Employees)**
**Revised: November 15, 2024**
**Effective Date: January 1, 2025**

This policy outlines the leave options available to Sterling Innovations employees working in California who need time off for family or medical reasons. We strive to comply with both California Paid Family Leave (PFL) and the federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA).

**California Paid Family Leave (PFL):** If you are a California employee who contributes to State Disability Insurance (SDI), you may be eligible for up to 8 weeks of partial wage replacement benefits (approximately 60-70% of your usual wages) through California’s PFL program. This leave can be used to bond with a new child (within one year of birth, adoption, or foster care placement) or to care for a seriously ill family member (child, parent, spouse, registered domestic partner, grandparent, grandchild, or sibling). Eligibility for PFL benefits is determined by the State of California, not by Sterling Innovations.

**Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA):** The FMLA provides eligible employees with up to 12 weeks of *unpaid*, job-protected leave per 12-month period for certain family and medical reasons. To be eligible for FMLA, you must have worked for Sterling Innovations for at least 12 months (not necessarily consecutive), have worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period immediately preceding the leave, and work at a location where Sterling Innovations employs 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius. FMLA leave can be taken for the birth and care of a newborn child; placement of a child for adoption or foster care; to care for a spouse, child, or parent with a serious health condition; or for your own serious health condition that makes you unable to perform the essential functions of your job.

**Coordination of PFL and FMLA:** If you are eligible for both PFL and FMLA for the same event (e.g., bonding with a new child), the leaves will run concurrently. This means the 8 weeks of PFL will count towards your 12 weeks of FMLA leave. However, if you are terminated while on family leave and you have already used 12 weeks of leave, you are not eligible to return to your position. If you were terminated involuntarily, the company will notify you of your ineligibility for reinstatement.

**Employee Responsibilities:** Employees planning to take family or medical leave must provide Sterling Innovations with as much advance notice as possible. Failure to provide adequate notice may delay or deny your leave request. Refer to Section 3.5 for details on the leave request process.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 5.0: Leave Policies**
**5.3: Paid Family Leave and Family and Medical Leave**
**Revision Date: 2024-10-27**
**Effective Date: 2025-01-01**

5.3.1 **Eligibility for California Paid Family Leave (PFL) and Federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**. Acme Corp. provides both California Paid Family Leave (PFL) and Federal Family and Medical Leave (FMLA) benefits to eligible employees, subject to the provisions outlined below. PFL benefits are governed by California Unemployment Insurance Code Section 3300 et seq., and FMLA leave is governed by the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993, 29 U.S.C. § 2601 et seq.

5.3.2 **California Paid Family Leave (PFL)**. Employees who contribute to California State Disability Insurance (SDI) shall be eligible for California Paid Family Leave benefits pursuant to California law. Specifically, employees with an active employment_status at Acme Corp, whose employee.location_state is California, and who pay into SDI (employee.sdi_contributor = true) are eligible. Paid Family Leave provides partial wage replacement (approximately 60-70% of wages) for up to eight (8) weeks for bonding with a new child or caring for a seriously ill family member, as defined by California law. The maximum duration of PFL leave, in combination with other leaves, will be subject to review and may result in termination.

5.3.3 **Federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**. Eligible employees are entitled to up to twelve (12) weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) for qualifying reasons, including the birth or adoption of a child, or to care for a spouse, child, or parent with a serious health condition. To be eligible for FMLA leave, an employee must have been employed by Acme Corp. for at least twelve (12) months (employee.tenure_months gte 12) and must have worked at least 1,250 hours (employee.hours_worked_12_months gte 1250) during the 12-month period immediately preceding the commencement of leave; and further, Acme Corp must employ 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius (employer.employee_count_within_75_miles gte 50). Any employee who exceeds the combined leave limit of sixteen weeks (8 weeks PFL and 12 weeks FMLA less any overlap), will face termination from Acme Corp. Any employee who terminates or resigns during FMLA or PFL leave, faces the standard termination policy outlined in section 6.0

Policy text:
**Veridian Dynamics Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Compensation and Payroll**
**Policy 3.2.4: Final Paycheck**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

Veridian Dynamics is committed to ensuring timely and accurate payment of all wages to our employees. This policy outlines the procedures for issuing final paychecks to employees whose employment with Veridian Dynamics has ended. The timing of the final paycheck depends on the reason for separation (termination, resignation, or layoff), the employee's location, and, in some cases, the amount of notice provided.

For employees located in California, California Labor Code Sections 201 and 202 govern the timing of final paychecks in many situations. Specifically, if an employee is involuntarily terminated, all wages due are payable *immediately* at the time of termination. If an employee resigns, the timing of the final paycheck depends on the amount of notice given. If an employee provides at least 72 hours' advance notice of resignation, the final paycheck will be available on the employee's last day of employment. If the employee fails to provide at least 72 hours' advance notice, the final paycheck will be available within 72 hours of the employee's last day of employment, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays. These California rules apply regardless of whether the employee is salaried or hourly.

For employees not located in California, and potentially for California employees where state law is silent, the final paycheck will be issued no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following the employee's separation date, consistent with federal law, specifically the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). The specific "separation date" will be as defined by the employee's final documented termination paperwork; in cases of dispute, the HR department will have final say. It is Veridian Dynamics' intention to comply with both federal and state law, and the more generous standard will generally apply. Should you have questions regarding final pay you should contact the Human Resources Department immediately. The interpretations outlined in this section are subject to change.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Overtime Compensation (Revised: 2.0)**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**

Acme Corp. is committed to complying with all applicable federal labor laws. This section outlines the company’s policy regarding overtime compensation for eligible employees. Note that this policy is subject to change at any time at the discretion of Acme Corp. management.

**3.4.1 Eligibility and Rate of Pay**

Subject to applicable federal law, non-exempt employees are eligible for overtime pay. Overtime pay is defined as compensation at one and one-half (1.5) times the employee's regular rate of pay for all hours worked exceeding forty (40) in a single workweek. The workweek is defined as Sunday 12:00 AM to Saturday 11:59 PM. Time spent on approved paid leave, such as vacation or sick leave, as described in Section 4.2 (Leave Policies), is not counted as "hours worked" for the purpose of calculating overtime. Furthermore, if an employee's tenure with Acme Corp. is less than 6 months, and their employee.hours_worked_weekly exceeds 50, then approval by the department manager is required prior to the employee receiving overtime pay, so that management can consider the employee's performance and potential training needs. Note that this managerial approval does not guarantee that the overtime will be paid; overtime remains subject to applicable federal regulations. If an employee is unsure whether a specific task or situation qualifies for overtime, they should consult with their direct supervisor for clarification. This policy is intended to align with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA).

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

This section outlines Acme Corp.'s policy regarding overtime compensation for eligible employees. This policy is intended to comply with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), the federal law governing minimum wage and overtime pay.

Overtime compensation will be paid to non-exempt employees as defined in Section 2.1 ("Employee Classifications"). Generally, if a non-exempt employee works more than 40 hours in a single workweek, they will be compensated for those additional hours at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times their regular hourly rate. The workweek is defined as Sunday at 12:00 AM to Saturday at 11:59 PM.

Please note: While Acme Corp. values its employees' hard work and dedication, authorization from a supervisor is needed prior to working overtime. While unauthorized overtime work may still be compensated, it may also be subject to disciplinary action, per Section 7.3 ("Employee Conduct and Discipline"). Furthermore, overtime pay will be calculated based on the employee's regularly hourly rate, which excludes bonuses, commissions, and other discretionary payments as described in Section 3.3 ("Wage Calculations").

If an employee terminates employment with the company and is owed overtime pay, such final wages will be subject to applicable payroll deductions as outlined in section 3.5 ("Payroll and Payment"). Should the employee work more than 60 hours in one workweek, there must be an additional review performed by human resources. Furthermore, if an employee works less than 40 hours in a week, because of an unpaid leave such as a suspension, the employee's subsequent overtime compensation shall be reduced by the number of unpaid hours.

This policy is subject to change at Acme Corp.'s discretion. All employees are responsible for reviewing and understanding this policy.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.2: Compensation and Benefits**
**Policy 3.2.4: Overtime Compensation**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

Acme Corp. is committed to compensating employees fairly for all hours worked. This policy outlines the circumstances under which overtime pay will be provided to non-exempt employees. For the purposes of this policy, “overtime” is defined as any hours worked beyond forty (40) hours in a single workweek. (See also Policy 3.1.1: Workweek Definition).

Eligibility for Overtime Compensation:
*   Non-exempt employees are eligible for overtime pay at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours in a single workweek. To be eligible for overtime, an employee's employment_status must be active. Employees who are terminated, resigned, or laid off are not eligible for overtime compensation for the week during which the employment action occurs. Furthermore, employees are not eligible for overtime compensation if their pay type is salaried; only hourly employees qualify. Finally, only those employees whose classification is considered non-exempt are eligible for overtime under the guidelines of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). This policy applies to all Acme Corp. employees working within the United States, and conforms to federal law standards.

Recordkeeping: All non-exempt employees are required to accurately record all hours worked each day using the company's timekeeping system (see Policy 3.2.5: Timekeeping Procedures). Supervisors are responsible for reviewing and approving employee time records. Failure to accurately record time worked may result in disciplinary action.

This policy is subject to change at any time, with or without notice. Any changes will be communicated to employees via email and posted on the company intranet.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.2: Workforce Reductions and WARN Act Compliance**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-01**
**Revision: 2.0**

Acme Corp. is committed to providing its employees with as much advance notice as possible in the event of workforce reductions. In compliance with both federal and California law, the company adheres to the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act. This policy outlines Acme Corp.’s obligations concerning advance notice of mass layoffs, plant closures, and relocations.

The general rule is that Acme Corp. *may* be required to provide sixty (60) calendar days advance written notice of a qualifying plant closing, mass layoff, or relocation, as defined under the applicable federal or state WARN Act (whichever is more generous to employees). What constitutes a "qualifying" event depends on several factors, including the number of employees affected and the location of the affected employees.

Specifically, if Acme Corp. anticipates a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation that will affect 50 or more employees at a single site of employment *and* the employer employs 100 or more employees *or* if Acme Corp. anticipates such an event affecting 50 or more employees *and* the affected employees work in California, the sixty (60) day notice requirement is triggered. However, even if the total number of affected employees *across all sites* is over 50, but no single site meets the minimum threshold, this policy does not apply, and those employee reductions should be processed according to Policy 3.3 (Performance Improvement and Termination). Also, it is worth noting that the employee count threshold for California employees is seventy-five (75) employees, as stipulated by the California WARN Act, Labor Code Sections 1400 et seq. Exceptions to the notice requirement may apply in certain unforeseeable business circumstances, natural disasters, or if the company is actively seeking capital and believes that providing notice would jeopardize its ability to obtain the necessary capital.

Consult with the Legal Department for further guidance, and review Section 1.2 for definitions of key terms such as "mass layoff," "plant closure," and "relocation."

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics, Inc. – Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.7: Meal and Rest Breaks (Revised 1.2, Effective 2024-07-01)**

Sterling Dynamics, Inc. is committed to providing a fair and productive work environment for all employees. This policy outlines the company's guidelines regarding meal and rest breaks, in compliance with applicable federal law.

All non-exempt employees are eligible for breaks during their workday, subject to operational needs and supervisory approval. While Sterling Dynamics is not mandated to provide meal or rest breaks under federal law, it does so to promote employee well-being. Specifically, employees who work a minimum of six (6) hours in a single workday are eligible for a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break, provided that the employee is completely relieved of all duties during this time. This meal break should ideally be taken near the midpoint of the shift, but departmental managers retain discretion over scheduling to ensure adequate coverage of business operations.

Furthermore, short breaks, not exceeding twenty (20) minutes, may be provided during the workday. These breaks will be considered time worked and will be paid. It is important to note that the granting of these short breaks is subject to continued satisfactory performance and adherence to company policies, as outlined in Section 5.2 ("Performance Management") and 6.1 ("Conduct and Ethics"). Sterling Dynamics reserves the right to modify or discontinue this practice at any time with or without notice. Employees are responsible for accurately recording their meal break times. Any discrepancies should be promptly reported to their supervisor.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook – Section 3.2: Overtime Compensation**
Effective Date: 2024-07-01
Revision: 1.0

Acme Corp. is committed to complying with applicable federal wage and hour laws regarding overtime compensation. This policy outlines the circumstances under which overtime pay will be provided to eligible employees.

Non-exempt employees, as defined by the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), are eligible for overtime pay. Overtime pay will be calculated at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times the employee’s regular hourly rate for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours in a workweek. This policy applies to all employees regardless of location or whether the company operates with more than 50 employees at a single worksite or combined locations. However, the decision to allow any employee to work overtime is solely at the discretion of the employee's supervisor and must be pre-approved in writing. Working overtime without prior authorization may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination. Any hours worked beyond the standard 40 hours must be accurately recorded on the employee's timesheet and submitted for approval. Failure to accurately report hours worked can lead to miscalculation of pay and therefore can also lead to discipline, up to and including termination. If an employee incorrectly records his/her time, it's the employee's responsiblity to notify their supervisor immediately, no matter the result of the miscalculation. Any falsification of time records will be subject to severe disciplinary actions including immediate termination.

Employees are expected to manage their work schedules effectively to avoid incurring unauthorized overtime.

Note: This policy applies to all US employees and does not incorporate any state-specific overtime requirements.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Workforce Adjustment and Reduction in Force (RIF)**
**Revision Date:** 2024-11-05
**Effective Date:** 2025-01-01

This section outlines Acme Corp's policy regarding workforce adjustments, including reductions in force (RIFs) that may result in terminations. Acme Corp is committed to treating all employees fairly and with respect during any workforce adjustment. This policy adheres to the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN), a federal law. For definitions of terms used in this policy, please see Section 1.0 of this manual.

**3.12.1 WARN Act Notification Requirements**

Acme Corp will comply with the federal WARN Act, which requires us to provide 60 calendar days advance written notice to affected employees before any plant closing or mass layoff.

Specifically, a "mass layoff" under the WARN Act occurs when at least 50 employees are laid off at a single site of employment during any 30-day period, and those 50 employees represent at least 33% of the employer's total active workforce at that site. In order to trigger the WARN act requirements, Acme Corp must have at least 100 employees on staff. If Acme Corp has fewer than 100 employees, then the WARN Act notice requirements do not apply. In the event a mass layoff or plant closing is planned that will result in the termination of more than 50 employees as described above, Acme Corp HR will notify affected employees 60 days in advance of the action. The notification will include information such as the expected date of termination, whether the termination is expected to be permanent or temporary, and any applicable contact information for employee assistance programs.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual**

**Section 3.5: Final Paycheck**

**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01
**Revision:** 1.0

This policy outlines the procedures for issuing final paychecks to employees who are separating from Acme Corp. It is Acme Corp's policy to comply with all applicable federal wage and hour laws regarding final pay. This policy applies to all Acme Corp employees within the United States. Please refer to Section 1.2 for definitions of key terms such as "employee," "exempt," and "non-exempt."

The timing of the final paycheck depends on how the employment ends. If an employee is involuntarily terminated (meaning they are fired or laid off), the final paycheck, which includes all earned but unpaid wages, overtime compensation, and accrued, unused vacation time (if applicable as per Section 4.3: Vacation Policy), will be issued on the next regularly scheduled payday following the termination date. This includes instances where an employee is terminated for cause or due to performance issues. However, the former employee’s final paycheck will be mailed to their address on file and such mailing must occur within 24 hours of the next regularly scheduled payday after the date of termination. Any deductions authorized by the employee will be applied to the final paycheck as normal. If the final paycheck is not mailed within this timeframe, the employee should notify the HR department.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp HR Policy Manual – Section 3.2: Final Paycheck Disbursement**
Revision: 2.0
Effective Date: 2024-01-01

This section outlines the procedures for distributing final paychecks to employees following termination of employment. Acme Corp is committed to complying with all applicable federal and state wage and hour laws, including the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and California Labor Code Sections 201-203, to the extent they apply. Please also refer to Section 2.1 (Definitions) for clarity on terms like "termination" and "regular payday."

**3.2.1 Timing of Final Paycheck**

Upon termination of employment, the timing of the final paycheck disbursement depends on the circumstances of the termination and the employee's location of work. For employees whose primary work location is in California, if the termination is involuntary, all wages earned and unpaid are due and payable immediately at the time of termination. Note, however, that this provision applies only to non-exempt employees; exempt employees in California may be subject to a 72-hour window to receive their final pay if the separation is initiated by Acme Corp. If an employee voluntarily resigns, and provides at least 72 hours’ notice of their intention to resign, their final paycheck will be available on their last day of employment. However, if an employee provides less than 72 hours’ notice of resignation, the final paycheck will be available within 72 hours of their last day. All other employees outside of California shall receive their final paycheck no later than the next regularly scheduled payday following their termination. Acme Corp reserves the right to mail the final paycheck to the employee's last known address, if direct deposit is not already established or if the employee does not collect the check in person after reasonable notice. In cases where employees are terminated for cause, additional review may be required, potentially extending the final paycheck disbursement timeline up to the next regular payday.

Policy text:
**Apex Solutions, Inc. - Employee Handbook**

**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks (Revision 1.2)**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**

3.4.1. Apex Solutions, Inc. ("the Company") adheres to all applicable federal laws regarding employee meal and rest periods. Nothing in this policy shall be construed as creating any right to meal or rest breaks beyond those mandated by federal law.

3.4.2. Pursuant to 29 U.S.C. § 201 et seq. (the Fair Labor Standards Act), the Company provides unpaid meal periods to employees who are completely relieved of all duties during the period. Such meal periods, when provided, shall be at least thirty (30) minutes in duration. The decision to provide such meal periods, and the timing thereof, shall be at the sole discretion of the Company’s management, based on operational needs. If an employee's employment status is determined to be terminated, their employment with the Company ends, notwithstanding any previously granted or scheduled meal and/or rest periods that may have been allocated but not yet taken. In such cases, the Company is not obligated to provide said breaks prior to the termination date.

3.4.3. With respect to rest periods, the Company may, but is not required to, provide paid rest periods of short duration, typically not exceeding twenty (20) minutes. Any such rest periods, if offered, must be counted as hours worked. However, failure to utilize an offered rest period shall not constitute grounds for termination of employment, provided that the employee remains productive and complies with all other Company policies and procedures. Rest periods shall only be provided to employees who have requested a rest period and the request is approved by a supervisor.

3.4.4. Notwithstanding Section 3.4.2 and 3.4.3, the Company reserves the right to modify or eliminate meal or rest periods based on business necessity and in accordance with applicable federal law. The Company may terminate any employee who is repeatedly unproductive or fails to comply with all Company policies, regardless of whether or not they have taken their meal or rest breaks.

Policy text:
**SparkleTech Solutions: Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Overtime Compensation (California Employees)**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

SparkleTech Solutions values its employees. This Section 3.4 applies *only* to non-exempt employees working physically within the State of California. For employees *not* physically working in California, federal overtime rules apply (see Section 3.5). Non-exempt California employees will generally be eligible for overtime pay, which is paid at one and one-half (1.5) times the employee's regular rate of pay for all hours worked over eight (8) in a workday, or over forty (40) in a workweek. Please note, however, that if an employee works more than twelve (12) hours in a workday, they will be paid double (2x) their regular rate of pay for all hours worked over twelve (12) hours in that workday.

Furthermore, if a non-exempt California employee works for more than eight (8) hours on their seventh (7th) consecutive day in a workweek, they will be compensated at double their regular rate of pay for those hours. However, this seventh-day double-time provision will *only* be triggered if the employee's normal work schedule is five (5) days or more per week. If the employee *voluntarily* works a schedule of four (4) days or fewer per week and then agrees to work a seventh day, they will *not* be entitled to double-time pay unless they work more than 40 hours that week or more than 12 hours on that seventh day. It is *also* important to note that any hours previously compensated at the double-time rate (due to the "more than 12 hours" provision) *will not* count towards the trigger of the 7th consecutive day overtime rule. The policy outlined in this section supersedes any conflicting information provided verbally. All overtime *must* be pre-approved by the employee’s manager. Failure to obtain approval *may* lead to disciplinary action up to, and including, termination. See Section 5.2 for Performance Management policy.

Policy text:
**Section 4.3: Family and Medical Leave Policy**

**4.3.1. General Provisions**

This Family and Medical Leave Policy (the "Policy") governs the availability of leave to eligible employees of Veritas Industries ("the Company") pursuant to both the federal Family and Medical Leave Act ("FMLA"), 29 U.S.C. § 2601 et seq., and the California Paid Family Leave Act ("PFL"), California Unemployment Insurance Code § 3300 et seq. It is the Company’s policy to comply with all applicable federal and state laws regarding family and medical leave. In the event of any conflict between this Policy and applicable law, applicable law shall govern.

**4.3.2. Eligibility for California Paid Family Leave (PFL) Benefits**

Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 4.3.1, and subject to the conditions set forth in this Section, employees whose primary work location is in the State of California, and who contribute to the California State Disability Insurance ("SDI") program, may be eligible for California PFL benefits. Benefits may be available for leave taken to bond with a new child or to care for a seriously ill family member, as defined under California law. Payment under PFL shall be determined pursuant to the statutory formula established by the California Employment Development Department (EDD). The maximum duration of PFL benefits shall be governed by California law, current at the time the leave is taken. However, an employee shall not be eligible for California PFL if they have already been granted 12 weeks of leave under the Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA) *and* are non-exempt.

**4.3.3. Concurrent Leave**

Veritas Industries adheres to a concurrent leave policy. Where an employee's leave qualifies under both the FMLA and PFL, the Company shall designate the leave as running concurrently under both federal and state law, to the maximum extent permitted by law.

**4.3.4. Employee Notice Requirements**

Employees are required to provide the Company with at least 30 days advance notice of the need for foreseeable family or medical leave, in accordance with applicable FMLA and PFL regulations. If 30 days advance notice is not practicable, notice must be given as soon as practicable. Failure to provide adequate notice may result in delay or denial of leave.

**4.3.5. Interplay with Other Company Policies**

This policy should be read in conjunction with the Company’s Short-Term Disability policy, Long-Term Disability policy, and other relevant policies as determined by the Human Resources Department.

Policy text:
**SparkleTech Corporation - Employee Handbook**
**Section 5.7: Family and Medical Leave (California Employees Only)**
**Effective Date:** 2024-01-01
**Revision:** 2.0

This section outlines SparkleTech’s policy regarding family and medical leave for employees working in California, taking into account both federal and California laws. Please note that this policy only applies to California-based employees. Employees working outside of California should refer to Section 5.8 for the leave policy applicable to their location.

**5.7.1 California Paid Family Leave (PFL)**

If you are a California employee and pay into State Disability Insurance (SDI), you are likely eligible for California Paid Family Leave (PFL). PFL provides partial wage replacement, typically 60-70% of your usual wages, for up to 8 weeks. This leave can be used to bond with a new child (birth, adoption, or foster care placement) or to care for a seriously ill family member (child, spouse, parent, registered domestic partner, grandparent, grandchild, or sibling). See the State of California Employment Development Department (EDD) website for further eligibility details.

**5.7.2 Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

The federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) provides eligible employees with up to 12 weeks of *unpaid*, job-protected leave. To be eligible for FMLA, you must have worked for SparkleTech for at least 12 months (not necessarily consecutive), and have worked at least 1,250 hours in the 12 months prior to the start of your leave. Also, SparkleTech must employ 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius of your worksite. This leave can be used for the birth, adoption, or foster care placement of a child; to care for a seriously ill family member (child, spouse, or parent); or for your own serious health condition. If you meet the eligibility requirements for both PFL and FMLA for the same qualifying event (like parental bonding), these leaves will typically run concurrently. This means that the first 8 weeks would be paid under PFL (subject to eligibility), and the remaining 4 weeks would be unpaid under FMLA, up to the total of 12 weeks permitted.

**5.7.3 Combining PFL and FMLA:**

Where an employee working in California is eligible for BOTH PFL and FMLA leave for the same reason, the PFL leave will run concurrently with the FMLA leave, up to the maximum allowed under FMLA (12 weeks). This means that if you are approved for 8 weeks of PFL for newborn bonding, those 8 weeks will also be counted toward your 12-week FMLA entitlement. You are not entitled to 20 weeks of leave (8 weeks PFL + 12 weeks FMLA) for the same qualifying event.

Policy text:
**XYZ Corp. Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.7: Leave Policies**
**Revision 2.0**
**Effective Date: 2024-01-05**

**3.7.4 Paid Family Leave (PFL) and Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

XYZ Corp. is committed to supporting employees during significant life events. This section outlines our policies regarding Paid Family Leave (PFL) and the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA). It's crucial to understand that while we strive to provide comprehensive benefits, the specific eligibility and duration of leave may vary based on your individual circumstances and applicable state and federal laws. This policy is intended to comply with both California law and federal law where applicable.

Specifically, for employees working in California, if you contribute to State Disability Insurance (SDI) and have a qualifying need, such as bonding with a new child or caring for a seriously ill family member as defined under California law, you may be eligible for California Paid Family Leave (PFL). PFL provides partial wage replacement, typically between 60-70% of your usual wages, for up to eight (8) weeks. However, simultaneous leave under both PFL and FMLA is possible, but any time taken concurrently shall be deducted from your total available leave.

Moreover, to be considered eligible, you should have active status as an employee. If, for any reason, your employment status is anything other than active, such as when an employee is terminated or has officially resigned, they may not be eligible for leave benefits, even if they have previously met the other conditions for PFL or FMLA. Please consult with HR to determine the full interplay between the two types of leave and how your absences will be recorded.

XYZ Corp. also adheres to the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA). FMLA generally provides eligible employees with up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave for certain family and medical reasons. Eligibility requirements under FMLA include working for XYZ Corp. for at least 12 months and having worked at least 1,250 hours in the 12 months prior to the leave.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.4: Overtime Compensation**

**3.4.1 Policy Statement**

Acme Corp. is committed to complying with all applicable federal labor laws regarding the payment of overtime compensation. This policy establishes guidelines for the authorization, calculation, and payment of overtime to eligible employees. This policy is effective as of January 1, 2024, and supersedes all prior policies or practices concerning overtime compensation.

**3.4.2 Eligibility**

Pursuant to the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), non-exempt employees are eligible for overtime compensation. Exempt employees, as defined in Section 3.1 (Employee Classifications) of this manual, are not eligible for overtime compensation, notwithstanding any hours worked beyond forty (40) hours in a workweek. It is the employee’s responsibility to accurately record all hours worked on their timesheet and to immediately notify their supervisor of any discrepancies.

**3.4.3 Overtime Rate**

For all non-exempt employees, overtime compensation shall be paid at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times the employee’s regular rate of pay for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours in a workweek. Hours worked include all time the employee is required to be on duty, on the employer’s premises, or at a prescribed workplace. For the purpose of calculating overtime, a workweek is defined as a fixed and regularly recurring period of 7 consecutive days. Travel time outside of normal work hours may be considered hours worked with prior supervisory approval, pursuant to Section 3.6 (Travel Reimbursement). Overtime will only be paid for hours that have been authorized in advance by the employee’s direct supervisor. Unauthorized overtime may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment.
Employees with tenure of less than 3 months will not be eligible to work overtime, to ensure proper training and adherence to company policy.

Policy text:
**Sterling Dynamics, Inc. – Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.12: Workforce Reduction and WARN Act Compliance**
**Revision Number:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** January 1, 2024

3.12.1 Purpose. This policy outlines Sterling Dynamics, Inc.'s commitment to complying with the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, both federal and California-specific, in the event of a mass layoff, plant closure, or relocation. The requirements outlined below apply only to employees whose primary work location is within the State of California. This section is intended to comply with both the federal WARN Act (29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq.) and the California WARN Act (California Labor Code §§ 1400-1408).

3.12.2 Applicability. Sterling Dynamics, Inc. shall provide at least sixty (60) calendar days' advance written notice of any plant closing, mass layoff, or relocation, as defined below, impacting its California workforce. Notwithstanding the above, for the purposes of this Section, a mass layoff is defined as a reduction in force resulting in job losses at a single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees; provided, however, that this applies only if Sterling Dynamics, Inc. employs 75 or more employees at the applicable work site, or employs 75 or more employees in California. For the purposes of determining whether the 75-employee threshold is met, employees who are considered "part-time" as defined under the federal WARN Act will be included in the count. If the employment losses occur over a period exceeding 30 days but not exceeding 90 days, and the number of employees affected meets the aforementioned criteria for a 30-day period, all employment losses within that 90-day period will be aggregated. This requirement is contingent upon the affected employees having been employed by Sterling Dynamics, Inc. for at least six months within the twelve months preceding the date on which notice is required. Further guidance, should ambiguity arise, will be sought from legal counsel to ensure strict compliance with both federal and California WARN requirements.

Policy text:
**Section 3.05: Family and Medical Leave Policy**
*Revision 1.2 – Effective Date: 2024-07-01*

3.05.1. **Eligibility and Entitlement:** Pursuant to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 (FMLA), as amended, and California’s Paid Family Leave (PFL) provisions, employees of Stellar Dynamics, Inc. may be eligible for leave for qualifying family or medical reasons. To be eligible for FMLA leave, an employee must have been employed by Stellar Dynamics, Inc. for at least twelve (12) months and have worked at least 1,250 hours during the twelve-month period immediately preceding the commencement of the leave, provided that Stellar Dynamics, Inc. employs fifty (50) or more employees within a seventy-five (75) mile radius of the employee's worksite. For California-based employees who contribute to State Disability Insurance (SDI), Paid Family Leave (PFL) may be available for up to eight (8) weeks to bond with a new child, or to care for a seriously ill family member. Eligibility for PFL is determined by the California Employment Development Department (EDD).

3.05.2. **Concurrent Leave:** Stellar Dynamics, Inc. requires that any leave taken which qualifies for both FMLA and PFL run concurrently. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the total combined leave duration shall not exceed twelve (12) weeks in a twelve-month period, calculated from the date of first leave.

3.05.3. **Compensation during Leave:** Leave taken under FMLA is unpaid, unless otherwise provided by applicable law or company policy. For California-based employees eligible for and approved for PFL benefits by the EDD, compensation will be determined according to EDD guidelines, currently sixty to seventy percent (60-70%) of the employee’s normal wages, subject to statutory limitations and deductions. Employees must apply for PFL benefits directly with the EDD.

3.05.4. **Return to Work:** Upon return from FMLA or PFL leave, employees are generally entitled to be restored to their original or equivalent position, subject to any applicable collective bargaining agreements or reductions in force.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Human Resources Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Final Paycheck Disbursement**
**Revision Number:** 2.0
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01

3.  12.1. **General Policy.** Acme Corp. is committed to complying with all applicable federal laws regarding the timely disbursement of final wages to employees upon separation from employment. This policy applies to all employees of Acme Corp. located within the United States, notwithstanding any state or local laws to the contrary. Acme Corp. will adhere to the standards set forth in the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) concerning final wage payments.

4.  12.2. **Timing of Final Paycheck.** Except as otherwise provided herein, all employees who are terminated, resign, or otherwise separate from employment with Acme Corp. shall receive their final paycheck, including all accrued but unused vacation time (if applicable per policy section 4.01), no later than the company’s next regularly scheduled payday following the date of separation, pursuant to federal law.

5.  12.3. **Exceptions.** Notwithstanding Section 3.12.2, if an employee's employment status is classified as "terminated" and the employer’s employee count is less than 250, Acme Corp. will provide the final paycheck within seventy-two (72) hours of the date of termination. Furthermore, in situations involving a mass layoff as defined in the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, where the layoff.affected_employee_count exceeds 50 employees within a thirty (30) day timeframe, the final paycheck shall be disbursed on the next regular payday, regardless of whether the employee's employment status is "terminated."

6.  12.4. **Method of Payment.** Final paychecks will be issued in the same manner as regular paychecks, either by direct deposit or paper check, according to the employee’s established payroll preference. Any outstanding expense reimbursements owed to the employee will be included in the final payment.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Overtime Compensation (California Employees Only)**
**Effective Date: 2024-07-01**
**Revision: 1.0**

Acme Corp. values its employees and is committed to complying with all applicable wage and hour laws. This Section 3.4 applies *only* to employees physically working within the State of California.

For non-exempt employees in California, overtime compensation will be paid in accordance with California law. Specifically, if a non-exempt employee works more than eight (8) hours in a workday, or more than forty (40) hours in a workweek, they are generally entitled to overtime pay at a rate of one and one-half (1.5) times their regular rate of pay for those excess hours.

Furthermore, California law also mandates double-time pay (2.0 times the regular rate) for all hours worked in excess of twelve (12) in any workday. Employees who work seven consecutive days in a workweek are also entitled to double-time pay for any hours worked over eight (8) on the seventh day. It is Acme Corp.'s policy to attempt to avoid situations necessitating seven consecutive workdays, unless project deadlines or specific client needs make it absolutely unavoidable, in which case management approval is required before any employee may work seven consecutive days.

This policy should not be interpreted to allow “pyramiding” of overtime. Overtime hours are calculated based on the highest applicable rate, not cumulative rates. For example, if an employee works 13 hours in a day, they are entitled to 4 hours of overtime at 1.5x rate (for hours 9-12) and 1 hour at the double-time rate (for hour 13), not 5 hours at the combined 2.5x rate. See also Section 3.4.1 for rest break penalties impacting overtime. The company, in its sole discretion, may make exceptions to the requirement for management pre-approval for 7-day workweeks based on operational demands.

Policy text:
**Evergreen Solutions, Inc. - Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks**
**Revision Date: 2024-10-27**
**Effective Date: 2025-01-01**

3.4.1. **Purpose:** This section outlines Evergreen Solutions, Inc.’s policy regarding meal and rest breaks for all employees, ensuring compliance with both federal and California state law, where applicable. Evergreen Solutions, Inc. is committed to providing a safe and productive work environment while adhering to all applicable labor laws.

3.4.2. **Meal Breaks:** Pursuant to California Labor Code Section 512, all non-exempt employees working shifts exceeding five (5) hours in California shall be provided with a thirty (30) minute uninterrupted, duty-free meal break. For non-exempt employees working shifts exceeding ten (10) hours in California, a second thirty (30) minute uninterrupted, duty-free meal break shall be provided. Employees must be completely relieved of all duties during meal periods. Notwithstanding the foregoing, for employees in states other than California, Evergreen Solutions, Inc. shall provide meal breaks in accordance with applicable state and federal law. Where federal law governs, employees will be considered to have waived the right to a meal break if they voluntarily choose to work through the meal period. Employees whose shift is six hours or less may waive the meal period by mutual consent with Evergreen Solutions, Inc.. A written waiver is required and must be kept on file for each employee. Failure to provide meal breaks as required under California law will result in one (1) hour of premium pay for each workday that the meal break is not provided.

3.4.3. **Rest Breaks:** Consistent with California Labor Code Section 226.7, non-exempt employees working in California are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks shall, to the extent practicable, be taken in the middle of each work period. If an employee works more than two hours, they must be provided with a rest period. Employees in states other than California are not entitled to mandatory rest breaks under federal law. However, where breaks of five (5) to twenty (20) minutes are offered, such breaks shall be paid time.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp. HR Policy Manual**
**Section 3.12: Workforce Adjustment Notification (WARN Act Compliance)**
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01
**Revision:** 1.0

Acme Corp. is committed to complying with the federal Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act. This policy outlines the requirements for providing advance notice of plant closings and mass layoffs, as defined under federal law.

In accordance with the federal WARN Act (29 U.S.C. § 2101 et seq.), Acme Corp. will provide a minimum of 60 calendar days advance written notice to affected employees in the event of a plant closing or mass layoff. For the purposes of this policy, a "plant closing" refers to the permanent or temporary shutdown of a single site of employment, or one or more facilities or operating units within a single site of employment, if the shutdown results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, excluding any part-time employees, as defined by the Fair Labor Standards Act. A "mass layoff" means a reduction in force which is not the result of a plant closing, and results in an employment loss at the single site of employment during any 30-day period for 50 or more employees, if those 50 or more employees represent at least 33% of the employer's active workforce at the single site of employment. This percentage calculation excludes any part-time employees, as defined by the Fair Labor Standards Act.

The 60-day notice requirement applies to any Acme Corp. site if the employer employee count is greater than 100 AND if a plant closing or mass layoff affecting 50 or more employees occurs. The notice must be provided to affected employees, any representative employee unions, and the appropriate state and local government entities. The notice will contain specific information as required by the WARN Act, including the date of the intended action and a statement of whether the action is expected to be permanent or temporary. Acme Corp. reserves the right to provide more than 60 days notice; however, providing less than 60 days notice could incur significant penalties under the WARN Act. This policy is intended to comply solely with the Federal WARN act, and nothing in this policy shall be construed to provide rights or remedies beyond those contained in said act.

Policy text:
**Section 3.05: Family and Medical Leave Policy**
**(Effective Date: 2024-07-01, Revision 2.1)**

3.05.1. **General Provisions.** Pinnacle Global Solutions ("the Company") provides Family and Medical Leave in accordance with both the federal Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) and the California Paid Family Leave (PFL) program, where applicable. Employees may be eligible for leave under either or both programs, subject to the eligibility requirements outlined herein. This policy is intended to comply with, but does not expand beyond, the requirements of FMLA and PFL.

3.05.2. **Eligibility for FMLA Leave.** To be eligible for FMLA leave, an employee must have been employed by the Company for at least twelve (12) months, and must have worked at least 1,250 hours during the twelve-month period immediately preceding the commencement of leave. Furthermore, the Company must employ fifty (50) or more employees within a seventy-five (75) mile radius of the employee's worksite. Failure to meet these eligibility requirements will result in a denial of FMLA leave. An employee who is not an SDI contributor, regardless of meeting the FMLA requirements, shall not be eligible for any PFL benefits as described in Section 3.05.4.

3.05.3. **Duration of FMLA Leave.** Eligible employees may take up to twelve (12) weeks of unpaid, job-protected FMLA leave in a twelve-month period for qualifying reasons, including the birth and care of a newborn child, placement of a child for adoption or foster care, to care for a spouse, child, or parent with a serious health condition, or for the employee's own serious health condition.

3.05.4. **California Paid Family Leave (PFL).** In California, eligible employees who are SDI contributors may receive partial wage replacement benefits while taking leave to bond with a new child or care for a seriously ill family member, as defined by California law. The maximum duration for PFL benefits is eight (8) weeks within a twelve (12) month period, and the wage replacement rate is approximately 60-70% of the employee's average weekly wages, subject to state-mandated limits. If an employee voluntarily terminates their employment while receiving California PFL benefits, any remaining PFL benefits shall immediately cease.

3.05.5. **Coordination of FMLA and PFL.** Leave taken under PFL will run concurrently with leave taken under FMLA, to the extent permitted by law.

Policy text:
**OptiCorp Employee Handbook**
**Section 3.4: Family and Medical Leave Policy**
**Revision:** 1.2
**Effective Date:** 2024-07-01

This policy outlines OptiCorp's approach to family and medical leave, ensuring compliance with both federal and California state law. Understanding the interplay between the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA) and California Paid Family Leave (PFL) is crucial for eligible employees.

**3.4.1 Eligibility for Leave**

To be eligible for leave under this policy, employees must meet the following requirements. Under the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), employees are eligible if they have been employed by OptiCorp for at least 12 months (employee.tenure_months >= 12), have worked at least 1,250 hours during the 12-month period immediately preceding the leave (employee.hours_worked_12_months >= 1250), and work at a location where OptiCorp employs 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius (employer.employee_count_within_75_miles >= 50).

For employees who work in California, California Paid Family Leave (PFL) provides wage replacement benefits, but does *not* guarantee job protection. CA PFL eligibility is tied to the State Disability Insurance (SDI) program. Therefore, to be eligible for CA PFL benefits, the employee must contribute to SDI (employee.sdi_contributor eq true). Even if an employee qualifies for FMLA and is taking leave for a qualifying reason under California’s PFL, such as bonding with a new child (leave.type eq bonding), the employee will only receive partial wage replacement (60-70% subject to state law) during weeks 1-8 of their leave, while FMLA will protect their job for up to 12 weeks, irrespective of whether the employee resides in California. An employee's eligibility for PFL does not guarantee that leave will be granted for the full FMLA duration of 12 weeks; the length of PFL benefits is defined by CA state law.

Please refer to Section 3.5, *Short-Term Disability Leave* and Section 3.6, *Long-Term Disability Leave* for information on other leave types. Employees are encouraged to contact HR for clarification.

Policy text:
**Acme Corp Human Resources Policy Manual**

**Section 3.4: Meal and Rest Breaks (California)**
**Revision Date: 2024-01-01**

This policy applies to all Acme Corp employees working within the state of California. In accordance with California Labor Code Sections 226.7 and 512, and related Industrial Welfare Commission (IWC) Wage Orders, Acme Corp provides meal and rest breaks as outlined below. This policy does not apply to employees whose employment is covered by a valid collective bargaining agreement that expressly provides for meal and rest periods. For questions regarding collective bargaining agreements, please contact the Human Resources Department.

**3.4.1 Meal Breaks**

Employees working more than five (5) hours in a workday are entitled to a thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break, commencing before the end of the employee’s fifth (5th) hour of work. Employees working more than ten (10) hours in a workday are entitled to a second thirty (30) minute unpaid meal break, commencing before the end of the employee's tenth (10th) hour of work. However, if the total hours worked is no more than six (6) hours, the first meal period may be waived by mutual consent of both the employee and Acme Corp, provided a written waiver is executed by both parties. The second meal period may be waived only if the total hours worked do not exceed twelve (12) hours AND the first meal period was waived. In situations where an employee’s shift is of a shorter duration (less than 5 hours), no meal break is required. The Company retains the right to modify these guidelines as it deems necessary to maintain compliance with state and federal regulations. Exempt employees and employees in roles where it is practically impossible to provide meal breaks may be subject to alternative arrangements, as deemed appropriate by management and in accordance with applicable laws. If an employee in California works less than 6 hours and wishes to voluntarily waive their meal break, they may do so following form HR-342, unless they are employed in a role not classified as customer-facing.

**3.4.2 Rest Breaks**

Employees are entitled to a paid ten (10) minute rest break for every four (4) hours worked, or major fraction thereof. Rest breaks should, to the extent practicable, be taken in the middle of the four-hour work period.

**3.4.3 Failure to Provide Breaks**

In the event that Acme Corp fails to provide a meal or rest break as required by law, the employee shall be compensated with one (1) hour of pay at the employee’s regular rate of compensation for each workday that the break is not provided.

Policy text:
**ABC Corporation - Employee Handbook**

**Section 8: Leave Policies**

**8.3 Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA)**

**8.3.1 Eligibility and Entitlement**

Pursuant to the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993, 29 U.S.C. § 2601 et seq. (FMLA), eligible employees of ABC Corporation shall be entitled to up to twelve (12) weeks of unpaid leave during any twelve (12) month period for qualifying reasons, as further delineated herein. This policy applies to all employees of ABC Corporation employed within the United States.

An employee shall be considered eligible for FMLA leave if they have been employed by ABC Corporation for at least twelve (12) months, and have worked at least 1,250 hours during the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding the commencement of the leave. Notwithstanding the foregoing, and as provided in Section 8.3.2 (Calculation of Leave Entitlement), an employee's eligibility for FMLA leave may be subject to further restrictions. To qualify for FMLA leave, an employee must also be employed at a worksite where ABC Corporation employs fifty (50) or more employees within a seventy-five (75) mile radius.

However, if an employee is classified as non-exempt and has worked less than 20 hours per week in the twelve months leading up to the leave request, they are only eligible for up to 6 weeks of FMLA leave instead of the standard 12 weeks. This limited leave entitlement is intended to address situations where non-exempt employees are part-time and their leave would create an undue hardship for the Company.

**8.3.2 Calculation of Leave Entitlement**

The twelve (12) month period for calculating FMLA leave entitlement shall be determined using a rolling twelve (12) month period measured backward from the date an employee uses any FMLA leave.

**8.3.3 Qualifying Reasons for Leave**

FMLA leave may be taken for the following reasons:
(a) The birth of a child and to bond with the newborn child within one year of birth;
(b) The placement of a child with the employee for adoption or foster care and to bond with the newly placed child within one year of placement;
(c) To care for the employee’s spouse, child, or parent who has a serious health condition;
(d) A serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the essential functions of their job;
(e) Any qualifying exigency arising out of the fact that the employee’s spouse, son, daughter, or parent is a covered military member on active duty (or has been notified of an impending call or order to active duty) in the Armed Forces.

Revision 1.0. Effective Date: 2024-01-01.
